In this paper, we construct equivariant A-algebras for nonorientable Lagrangians. Our main result shows that the equivariant A-algebra for a nonorientable Lagrangian is deformally equivalent to the mirror algebra of the corresponding nonorientable symplectic manifold. This provides a new example of mirror symmetry for symplectic manifolds.

We also give a general construction of the equivariant A-algebra for a symplectic manifold with a group action, and show that it is deformally equivalent to the equivariant cohomology of the symplectic manifold with coefficients in the representation ring of the group. This provides a new way of computing equivariant cohomology.

We present DiNTS, a differentiable neural network topology (DiNTS) search framework for 3D medical image segmentation. DiNTS leverages a fully differentiable hierarchical encoding architecture inspired by self-supervised learning to simultaneously optimize a shared encoder, a set of segmenter architectures, and a topology encoding network. This enables training an ensemble of segmentation models without requiring explicit freezing, saving, or loading of models during training. Furthermore, our framework backpropagates through the entire search process, providing a gradient-based optimization path for the topology search. We demonstrate the efficacy of our approach on challenging 3D medical image segmentation tasks for which state-of-the-art model ensembles yield significant performance gains compared to single models. We show that DiNTS can identify an optimal ensemble topology that outperform fixed model ensembles by 2.7%, 2.3%, and 2.6% for OT, CT, and PT segmentation on the ISLES dataset, respectively.

The novel follows the life of an anonymous narrator whose life is marked by two great sorrows: his sister's death from lupus shortly before his graduation from college, and a crushing defeat his favorite baseball team suffers in the World Series. The narrator's sister, Amalie, appears only briefly in the narrative but has a profound influence on the narrator, mainly through the letters she writes to him while he is in college. After her death, the narrator searches for some kind of meaning in her life and, through historical research, concludes that she lived a life of tragedy marked by sadness and struggle that she struggles heroically to overcome.

The narrator's baseball team, the Brooklyn Dodgers, provides another focal point for the narrator's obsession with suffering and defeat. The narrator becomes obsessed with the Dodgers after seeing a Dodgers game on his way to attend his sister's funeral. He becomes convinced that the Dodgers' history is marked by failure and sadness, starting with the team's departure from Brooklyn to avoid a tax bill. The team's failure to win the World Series, despite many chances, only reinforces the narrator's belief in the Dodgers' doom. However, the narrator's belief that the Dodgers' front office is filled with greedy, selfish people who prioritize winning over fair play and kindness leads him to believe that the Dodgers' misfortunes result from divine justice.

The narrator's own life is filled with sadness and suffering. He fails to make meaningful connections with other people, in part because of his own self-centeredness and detachment. He marries twice, has a son, and becomes a successful writer, but he is unable to prevent his life from being haunted by the deaths of his sister and his father, who dies a few years after his wife's death. In the end, the narrator concludes that there is no meaning in life and that humanity's attempts to find meaning are doomed to failure. The novel ends on a note of hope, however, as the narrator reflects on seeing a baseball game with his son and feeling content in spite of his beliefs.

The story is a tale of two cats, Miss Moppet and Grabbit, and the fun they have with a little mouse named Fluffy. Miss Moppet is a sleek, grey cat, with blue eyes and a pink nose. Grabbit is a fat, yellow cat with green eyes and a brown nose. Fluffy is a tiny mouse with short brown fur and a long tail.

Miss Moppet and Grabbit live together in an old farmhouse, with their human family, consisting of a grandmother, a mother, and a father. The two cats spend their days napping in the sunshine, chasing butterflies, and playing with Fluffy the mouse.

One day, Miss Moppet is lying in the sunshine, when Grabbit comes bounding up, with Fluffy in his mouth. Grabbit drops Fluffy, and Miss Moppet pretends to spurn him for his cruelty. But when Grabbit has gone, she comforts the terrified mouse, and they play together until it is time for Miss Moppet to go hunting with her brother.

They hunt birds, and although Miss Moppet catches nothing, she congratulates Grabbit on his skill. When they return home, they find that Fluffy has collected some nuts and is hiding them in a shoe. The two cats steal some of the nuts and Fluffy gets angry, but when Grabbit pretends to be asleep, Miss Moppet and Fluffy play together with the nuts until it is time for Miss Moppet to go to sleep too.

In a European town in the late 1930s, a young man named Jacob is struggling to survive in the face of overwhelming odds. He has lost his job, his friends, and his family, and he is now facing eviction from his home. But despite these challenges, Jacob remains optimistic and determined to find a way to overcome his difficulties.

One day, while walking through the town square, Jacob encounters a mysterious old man who offers him a job as a carpenter. Jacob is initially skeptical, but he is soon won over by the old man's kindness and wisdom. Under the old man's guidance, Jacob learns to master the art of carpentry and becomes a skilled craftsman.

As Jacob's skills and reputation grow, so do his ambitions. He soon sets his sights on a beautiful young woman named Rachel, and he is determined to win her heart. But as he works to build a future with Rachel, he is forced to confront a dark secret from his past that could threaten to destroy his new life.

Despite this challenge, Jacob remains steadfast in his love for Rachel and his determination to build a better future for them both. With the help of his friends and family, he is able to overcome the obstacles in his path and achieve his dreams. In the end, Jacob's courage and determination pay off, and he is able to build a fulfilling and happy life with Rachel by his side.

Having saved the Mouse Nation's princess from the evil cat Sith, Mara, aided by the clans of the Acoma and Xacatecas, must now face thePrices of theach nation and other enemies in a battle for the imperial throne of Kelewan.

With the death of his father, Emperor Kellen, and the extinction of the mighty line of warrior kings who had ruled for three thousand years, Luke, the new Emperor, is little more than a boy governed by his advisers. The political factions united in support of the Emperor are plotting to rid themselves of Kellen's outlander wife, Mara, and her young son, Justin. To save her family, Mara must do more than fight for her life. She must fight for the soul of the Empire itself in a game of Sharps, political intrigue, and bloody warfare.

As factions within the Empire move to destroy the Acoma, Mara rallies her forces, preparing to match wits with the cunning, powerful Lord Daimyo of the Shinzawai, Kaleska. But when a dangerous tape that could change the course of the Empire is stolen, Mara is forced to do what she fears most: send her son away to safety.

With threats inside and outside the palace, Mara turns to the one man she can trust -- her warrior lover, Turakamu -- to keep her son safe. Determined to protect his family, Turakamu takes Justin away, knowing that he is leading his loved ones into a trap.

As Mara reads the translation of the stolen tape, she realizes that her enemies have framed her. Knowing they will strike against her in the morning, she plans a bold night attack, hoping to rid herself of as many enemies as possible. Meanwhile, Turakamu's warriors are outnumbered, and he must fight a desperate battle to protect Justin and himself.

Mara's night raid is a success, but at a terrible cost. The enemy lord is dead, but so is one of Mara's beloved aides, and Turakamu and Justin are missing and presumed dead. Mara is bitterly grieving when she discovers a tape with a secret that may enable her to defeat her enemies forever. But before she can act, she must survive an assassination attempt.

When Mara at last faces her enemies at a great imperial conference, she brings a warning that some of them may not survive. As Mara's enemies fall before her, one question remains: Where is Turakamu?

In 1966, at the Bristol Royal Infirmary, Dr. Edward Radlaw, a gynecologist, is asked to examine Janet Smith, a pregnant 17-year-old who has been brought by her boyfriend, Jeremy Dixon, and her aunt, Charlotte Collins, from Wales. He learns she is approximately fourteen weeks pregnant. Radlaw, who had previously performed illegal abortions, arranges for her to have one in Bristol, with professor of anesthesia Alfred Cutner. He also persuades Matt Morris, the hospital porter, to arrange a room for her. Morris arranges for her to stay in the nurses' quarters on the top floor of the hospital, under the pseudonym "Mrs. Morgan". Smith's boyfriend Dixon is not informed of the abortion. Radlaw performs the abortion in the hospital's basement with Cutner, Matt Morris, and Tom Burke, a medical student.

Radlaw discovers a lump on Smith's abdomen, and fears it is a pregnancy complication  a ruptured uterus. After the abortion, Smith appears to recover, and she is taken back to her room. The next morning, Radlaw discovers that Smith has died of septicemia caused by a urinary tract infection. The hospital conducts an inquest, at which Radlaw, Cutner, Morris and Burke all give false accounts of Smith's treatment. The coroner concludes that Smith died of cardiac arrest, "arising from shock, due to abortion".

Radlaw becomes anxious when he learns that police constable Len Lawton is investigating the death of a girl found dead in a Bristol hotel, and could link it to Smith's death. Morris and Burke are both eventually arrested and confess to their roles in Smith's death, as does Cutner, who attempts to hide his involvement by claiming to have had a dream. Radlaw spends a weekend in Birmingham with his wife Lucy and son Justin, but on the way back confesses to his wife about his involvement. He then confesses to the police, and arranges for them to interview Cutner. Radlaw is charged with felony murder, as it occurred during an illegal act.

The novel begins in 2025, with the nation plagued by inflation and a severe energy crisis. The economy has collapsed and unemployment is at 24%. The setting is an oppressive United States, now called the "United States of Amerika," run by a corrupt, totalitarian government, and served by a police state. The story follows the life of Benjamin "Ben" Richards, a 29-year-old unemployed writer who is struggling to survive in Los Angeles, now known as "Nu-York," along with his wife, Lori, and his daughter, Cathy. On the way to arrest him, a police officer causes a major traffic accident, killing Lori and Cathy and leaving Ben paralyzed from the waist down. Unable to afford proper medical treatment, Ben has metal prosthetics installed in place of his legs, though he still cannot walk. While undergoing rehabilitation at a government-run hospital, Ben's rehabilitation therapist, Anna, convinces him to enroll in a new experimental program known as "The Running Man" in which he receives an experimental surgery that restores the use of his legs.

Ben is told the surgery is a success and is offered a job at the hospital. While celebrating with Anna, Ben is suddenly attacked and knocked out by two men working for the government. He awakens to find himself paralyzed once again and bound to a chair. It is then that Ben is informed by the hospital's head of security, Captain Freedom, that the "Running Man" program was actually a trap to lure in those who oppose the government, and that he is to be the star of the government's newest reality show, "The Running Man", where he will be chased through a series of kill zones by professional killers with orders to kill him. The only way to escape is to survive for 30 days. If he survives, he will be set free and awarded a large sum of money; if he is caught, he will be executed by being shot in the head.

Despite his situation, Ben is determined to survive for his own sake and also to expose the government's cruel manipulation of its people, and he agrees to be the star of the show. He is transported to the location of the first kill zone, a shopping mall, and the hunt begins. Ben manages to elude his pursuers and reaches the roof, where he is rescued by a mysterious helicopter pilot known only as "Harold." Harold explains that he has been monitoring Ben's progress on the show and that he believes Ben's story will resonate with the public, which has grown weary of

The novel follows the crew of the LM-34, a space tug ferrying a trajectories cargo container across the solar system. The narrator, engineer Bill Calvin, reveals that he has been in love with his friend Alice Leete ever since they attended college together. On the flight, Alice confesses that she, too, has always felt the same way, and the two decide to marry after the ship returns to Earth. But before they can do so, a crewman named Crowell, who has been experimenting with a hallucinogenic drug called "Better Than Life," offers the drug to Alice. Once consumed, the drug induces a realistic, vivid hallucination which overrides the user's memory and senses. Alice decides to take the drug and experiences a hallucination in which she falls in love with Crowell. When the drug's effect wears off, Alice attempts to abandon her engagement with Bill and pursue a relationship with Crowell. Bill confronts Crowell, who admits that he had hoped to exploit Alice's hallucination to seduce her. Bill attempts to attack Crowell, but falls unconscious after a fistfight. When he wakes, he discovers that the ship has arrived at Saturn, and that both Alice and Crowell have left the ship to explore Saturn's moons. Bill pilot the ship's capsule to Titan, where he discovers Alice and Crowell in each other's arms. Distraught, he launches himself into space, but his oxygen supply runs out before he can reach Saturn. As he dies, he sees a vision of Alice, smiling and holding a childhood teddy bear of Bill's, which she had kept all those years as a memento of their relationship.

Waiting for Anya is a novel written by Michael Morpurgo, author of War Horse. In the US, it was published as Shadow.

Set in Austria in 1938, it features three boys who live in a village near the Nazi border. They encounter a girl named Anya, who is destined to bear a child that the Nazis would consider "impure". The boys decide to help Anya reach safe territory, and they begin a perilous journey through Austria and Yugoslavia, attempting to stay one step ahead of the Nazis in order to keep Anya safe.

Throughout their journey, the boys encounter several obstacles. One of their biggest challenges is crossing a border river with Anya. Their efforts appear fruitless until they meet a sympathetic Serbian policeman who understands the danger Anya is in and assists them in crossing the river undetected. However, their problems are far from over. The boys still must find a way to reach England, the destination they believe will provide Anya with the safest refuge from the Nazis. They turn to Stefan, a smuggler who has been helping people cross borders. He agrees to help the boys reach Italy, where they can finally take a boat to England. However, Anya falls seriously ill, and the boys are forced to seek medical attention for her, which delays their journey. While Anya is hospitalized, the boys are assisted by an Italian doctor who, like the Serbian policeman, helps them out of sympathy for Anya's situation. When they finally reach Italy, the boys learn that the boat they hoped to take to England has already left, but they are able to secure passage on another ship.

Finally, the boys reach England, where they are separated from Anya. The boys are heartbroken at having to leave Anya behind, but are reassured that she will be able to stay with relatives and live a happy, safe life in England. The novel ends with the boys returning home and vowing to keep fighting against the Nazis in any way they can.

The Changeover: A Supernatural Romance is a 1984 novel by New Zealand writer Margaret Mahy. It is a supernatural romance about a girl, Laura, whose life becomes intertwined with two rival supernatural "brothers", one good and one evil.

Laura is a 16-year-old New Zealand teenager who is troubled by periodic lapses of memory. Her mother, Anne, becomes increasingly concerned about Laura's moods and behavior and believes that Laura is deliberately trying to hurt herself. Laura's friends, including her boyfriend Nick, do not appear to be aware of her problems. In reality, Laura is caught in the middle of a supernatural battle between two brothers, one of whom is evil and the other good, and Nick is the good one's next victim.

At the novel's opening, Laura is at a party with her friends when she feels a sudden pain in her hand. She runs to the bathroom to inspect the damage, but the cuts she sees on her hand are not her own. When she returns to the party, her friends behave strangely, and Nick is nowhere to be found. Laura discovers a note from Nick, explaining that he does not love her anymore and has found a new girlfriend. Laura becomes distraught and runs away from the party.

While on the run, Laura encounters a group of people performing a ritual in a park. She is attracted to one of the men, who introduces himself as Greg and offers to help her. Later, at Greg's house, Laura meets his family and learns that they are witches. Greg's father, Joe, explains that Greg is a psychopathic killer and that Laura must choose between Greg and Nick. Laura is shocked to discover that Greg has been killing women and using their spirits to power his magic. She also learns that Nick is in danger and must be rescued immediately.

Laura decides to help Nick and joins Joe and his two daughters, Helen and Odelle, on a mission to rescue him. They discover that Nick has been taken to the brothers' spiritual realm, known as the "Other Side," and must pass through it to rescue him. In the Other Side, Laura is confronted by Greg, who tries to convince her to join him in his evil deeds. Laura is tempted by Greg's offer of power and immortality, but ultimately refuses and chooses to save Nick instead.

With the help of Joe and the girls, Laura succeeds in rescuing Nick and defeating Greg. She returns to her own world with Nick and learns that her memory lapses were caused

In the summer of 1895, three childhood friendsMontgomery Starr, a railroad president; Fred Gilbert, a newsman; and OscarFRAKE, a paintergo on a trip together in France, accompanied by Starr's daughter, Leslie. During the trip, Leslie announces that she wants to marry Frake, but he appears to hesitate about entering into a marriage with anyone. After the group returns to New York, Frake announces that he intends to marry Leslie, and the two are quickly married. Shortly after their marriage, Frake becomes severely ill with pneumonia, and it becomes apparent that he has been hesitating because he has a poor opinion of himself and does not think himself good enough for Leslie. When he begins to recover, Frake announces that he intends to go to Camelot to become whole again, and he and Leslie set sail on his boat, the Valhalla.

Meanwhile, Gilbert becomes engaged to Helen Lorring, and Starr becomes engaged to Frake's former lover, Constance Garth. At the same time, Frake and Leslie encounter Carlyle, an author, and his wife, who are also sailing to Camelot. The Carlyles offer a strange explanation of Camelot, claiming that it is a city on a peninsula that is inaccessible on all sides and that one can reach it only by crossing an invisible bridge. When the Valhalla runs out of fuel, the party goes ashore on the peninsula, and Frake asserts that he can hear the sound of horses and a sword being sharpened. The group decides to explore the forest, but Leslie grows afraid and returns to the boat. While the others are away, the boat floats away with Leslie on it, and she is carried down the river to Camelot, where she is taken into the city by a knight on horseback.

Searching for Leslie, the others find the invisible bridge and cross it, where they meet Sir Pellinore, who takes them to King Arthur. Arthur announces that Leslie has already arrived and is pregnant with Frake's child; accordingly, Frake is made a knight and marries Leslie. The group then returns to New York, where Frake and Leslie's son, Montgomery, is born. Having become whole, Frake returns to painting and achieves great success.

Remix is a novel written by Noni Carter, and published in 2022. It depicts the stories of three women of color in an urban setting in South London, and explores themes of gentrification, sexuality, and class.

The novel is divided into three stories, each told from the perspective of a different woman: Mona, a queer Jamaican British woman who is struggling to come to terms with the disappearance of her sister; Odelle, a young black woman who is trying to find her place in the world as she deals with the consequences of her mother's mental illness; and Sele, a gay Nigerian woman who is trying to make sense of her relationship with Mona as gentrification changes the dynamic of their South London neighborhood.

As the novel progresses, the stories of the three women begin to intersect with each other, and they must navigate their relationships with each other and with the changing world around them.

The novel was well-received by critics, who praised its exploration of complex themes and its portrayal of diverse characters. It was also nominated for several awards, including the Women's Prize for Fiction and the Booker Prize.

The novel is about a woman named Lakshmi who is a newly married woman. She travels to visit her in-laws in India. While there, Lakshmi must cope with the complexities of her relationships with her husband, her mother-in-law, and her sister-in-law. During her visit, she opens a letter left by her husband which includes a pair of blue eyes drawn on itwhich matches the eyes of a woman named Naresh, her sister-in-law. Disturbed, Lakshmi tears up the letter. Thereafter, strange things happen to Lakshmi: she begins to have visions of a blue-eyed woman; she almost suffocates when trapped in a room with a statue of a blue-eyed goddess; and she sees the tail of a snake slip into her mother-in-law's room. Subsequently, Lakshmi's mother-in-law is found dead, having apparently drowned in the bathtub. Lakshmi's husband is convinced that his mother's death was suicide, but Lakshmi is convinced that she was murdered. Following the funeral, Lakshmi's father-in-law tells her that he wants her to stay on as the mistress of the house, as her vision of the blue-eyed woman was actually a vision of his dead wife, and that Lakshmi reminded him of her. However, Lakshmi becomes increasingly convinced that it is her husband's mysterious letter that is at the heart of the mysteries surrounding her, and finally opens it completelythereby releasing the spirit of Naresh. Naresh moves into the body of her husband, who was driving Lakshmi back to Delhi at the time, and attempts to kill Lakshmi. However, unable to control the body, Naresh/husband drives off a cliff, killing them both.
