The Key of Solomon is a 2008 novel written by Canadian author Steven Savile. It follows the story of a locksmith, who is in Jerusalem to investigate a 900-year-old key that reportedly opens the door to any lock. He discovers that the key is somehow connected to Solomon, and that it has been used throughout history to unlock various mysterious and dangerous things, finally culminating in the unlocking of something that can destroy the world.

Broch's novel focuses on an administrative employee named Peter Soames, who works as a middle manager at a large, unnamed organization (often described as a conglomerate). Soames' job is to write a memorandum stating whether or not the organization should purchase a machine designed to make a noise that resembles the human voice. The machine would be purchased for use in a telephone system the organization is developing. Soames is unable to verify the utility of such a machine, as the organization's guidelines and policies require that a decision like this be supported by a document prepared by another department, which does not exist. Soames' repeated attempts to find out who is responsible for preparing such documents lead him into a futile search through the organization's many departments and divisions.

Soames encounters many strange and surreal characters throughout the novel, including a woman who never blinks; a man who claims to be responsible for preparing documents for the missing department, but is unable to explain how to contact him; a woman who engages in conversation with Soames while remaining underwater in a swimming pool; a man who believes the year is 1922; a man who continuously repeats the phrase " cheats, lies, greed, filth "; and several people who claim to be Soames himself. All of these people impede Soames' attempts to complete his task.

In the spring of 1963, in the fictional town of Oxford, Connecticut, a blind woman named Laura Hargrave ( clairvoyant ) goes for a walk with her guide dog Norton. Upon returning to her home, she discovers a man sitting in her backyard, but he disappears when she attempts to get a closer look. That night, Laura has a vivid dream about a strange man, but refuses to think about it further. Jack Carmichael is a 22-year-old college student and decides to take a shortcut through the woods on his way home from a party. In the middle of the woods, he is startled by a woman who screams and runs away. When he arrives at his home, he is confronted by his angry father David, who harshly criticizes Jack for his latest poor grades. Jack decides to join the military to avoid attending graduate school.

Later that day, Jack's mother Kate goes shopping in town and runs into Laura at the grocery store. The two women quickly become friends, and Kate soon becomes intrigued by Laura's blindness, as it brings back memories of her own recent blindness, caused by a surgical procedure. Jack's sister Caroline is annoyed by Kate's infatuation with Laura and her pushy, overbearing ways. Caroline is a 17-year-old high school student who has a crush on Chuck, a popular, athletic boy in her class. She becomes jealous when she learns that Chuck may be dating Donna, the daughter of a wealthy family.

Jack returns home from military training and becomes attracted to Laura's neighbor, Helen Benson. One afternoon, Helen's daughter Ellen appears at Laura's home, asking for help locating a missing bookmark that had belonged to her mother. Laura grows agitated, and insists that she must speak to Helen in person, but becomes ill and dies shortly thereafter. The contents of her will are revealed, and both Jack and Caroline are shocked to learn that she has left her estate to them, with a hefty inheritance for Norton. The rest of Laura's family is surprised to learn that she has a brother, Roger, who is described in the will as a "malicious, evil man." No one knows where he lives or how to contact him.

As the story progresses, secrets about Laura's past begin to unfold. It is revealed that she had a premonition about the death of her husband, and that she felt responsible for his death. It is also revealed that she knew about Jack's father's affair with his secretary, and chose not to tell anyone.

While holidaying in Cornwall, Bill Masen encounters a meteor shower, the meteors strangely vanishing before they hit the ground. He is then attacked by a sleeping local man, who is subsequently killed by a speeding car. Several weeks later, Bill recovers from his injuries and returns to London. His employer, Harringway, explains that the meteors were nuclear satellites launched by the Soviet Union and points out that the newspapers largely ignored the incident.

Bill returns to his flat where he finds his girlfriend, Jo, in a state of panic. She explains that most of the population of Britain have suddenly and inexplicably fallen asleep; those who have not are behaving strangely. She witnessed a woman being attacked by her own pets and then ripped to shreds by vines which had grown throughout the night. She also mentions that she saw a walking statue in a neighbouring building.

When Jo goes to investigate a scream, she is attacked and seemingly killed by mysterious, ambulatory plants, which Bill later identifies as triffids. Escaping through the window, he is confronted by a crowd of triffids and is knocked unconscious. He regains consciousness three days later in a deserted hospital. He finds that most of the human population has been killed by the triffids and that he is blind in one eye.

Eventually he meets up with a group of survivors, including a woman named Susan, with whom he falls in love. The group finds a radio and learns that the triffids are a result of the previously mentioned Soviet satellites, which were launched to seed the British Isles with a new, genetically engineered species of plant. The satellites were hit by lightning and crashed to Earth, releasing the triffids, which promptly began to kill and feed on the population. The group learns via the radio that a coastal town in Devon has been evacuated and a ship will soon bring supplies and take the survivors to safety.

The group decides to seek refuge in a castle situated near the coast, a week's walk away. On the way, they are attacked by a pack of wild dogs which they manage to kill. Later, they come across a house occupied by a seemingly blind man, who turns out to be a triffid which has learned to mimic human behaviour. It is killed by the group, who then move on.

When the group arrives at the castle, they discover that a small group of people are already occupying two rooms at the top of the building. The group's leader, Coker, initially

The novel begins when teenager Mark Holloway arrives in Boston to look for his brother, Andy. Mark sees a man whom he eventually realizes is Andy, but Andy does not acknowledge him. Mark follows him and learns that Andy is living with a woman named Ellen and her daughter, Diane. One night, Mark hears a scream and finds Ellen murdered. Panicking, he runs to Andy, who calls the police. The investigating detective, Lieutenant MacGregor, has doubts about Mark's story, so he arrests him. At the police station, Mark confesses that he is really the murderer, but MacGregor does not believe him and assumes he is covering for Andy.

Mark is bailed out by a mysterious man named Christian, who claims to be a friend of Andy's. Mark realizes that Christian is a vampire. Christian tells Mark that Ellen was also a vampire and that she had turned Andy. Christian admits that he murdered Ellen because he thought she had gone mad. He offers to turn Mark into a vampire so that Mark can have eternal life with Diane, but Mark refuses.

Mark goes to MacGregor for help. MacGregor tells him that Diane has been missing for two days. They find a box of jewelry that Diane had hoped to sell to pay for her abortion. Mark realizes that Christian has taken Diane to have the baby, which will be born with fangs.

Mark and MacGregor locate Christian just as he completes the delivery. MacGregor shoots Christian. The baby attacks Mark, who kills it. MacGregor realizes that Mark is telling the truth and lets him go. Mark is upset that he will never see his brother again and realizes that he has lost the chance for eternal life with Diane because of his fear of Christian.

Seven hundred years after the events of "Hyperion", the old empire of man has fallen and the Galactic Empire now rules with an iron fist. After the completion of the Time Tombs and the subsequent mysterious disappearance of the Hegemony's leaders, the new emperor, Wrath-Amon, decided to take no chances and decreed that Time Tomb number one should be opened immediately. It is opened after a costly and difficult war and the mysterious weapon it contained was not enough to protect the imperial fleet from the attacking rebels. The empire is forced into a stalemate with the rebel forces.

Meanwhile, in the valley of the Time Tombs, the old poet Martin Silenus is confronted by an old man who accuses him of having stolen his life in order to write epic poems about the mythical warrior-hero, Hyperion. The old man, who calls himself Shadow, is really the mysterious and powerful figure known as The Shrike, who is worshiped by the Ousters and hated by both the empire and the rebels. Silenus and the Shrike battle each other in a vicious and brutal fight, ending in a stalemate with both of them apparently dying in the valley.

Centuries later, at the university on the planet Hain, a group of scholars uncovers a secret about the original Time Tombs: not only do they contain weapons, but they also contain the ancient and outlawed technology of the "man-machine interface", or "cybernetic immortality". The scholars are arrested by Empire troops and the cyborg known as The Harvester of Souls is sent to retrieve the secret of cybernetic immortality. The Harvester is a monster who is actually a converted human named Flagg, who was tortured and forced to become a cyborg after he killed the previous emperor. The scholars are subjected to the most horrible torture so that Flagg can learn from their pain; when it seems that all hope is lost, the rebel soldier Silenus (the poet's descendant) arrives and kills Flagg.

Silenus and the scholars escape and they decide to seek refuge with the rebels. On the way, they are attacked by the Shrike, who has survived his battle with Silenus' ancestor and has come to retrieve the cyborg Flagg's soul. During the attack, the Shrike severs the head of one of the scholars and takes it with him. The rebels manage to capture the Shrike and force it to lead them to the empire's greatest military might, the Battle

When fifteen-year-old Clary Fray heads out to the Pandemonium Club in New York City, she hardly expects to witness a murder --- much less a murder committed by three teenagers covered with strange tattoos and brandishing bizarre weapons. Then the body disappears into thin air. It's magic, Clary decides. But when the body turns up again, apparently whole, Clary and her best friend, Simon, are drawn into the world of the Shadowhunters, a secret clan of warriors dedicated to ridding the earth of demons. But Clary finds she can never return to her former life --- for hiding in the body of a dead girl is a demon, who has murdered before and will murder again.

As children, Cecilia Ross and Alison Doherty are inseparable, sharing every aspect of their lives together. As they grow into young women, however, their relationship becomes more complex. Cecilia, the more impulsive of the two, becomes consumed by her romantic fixation on Sam, a young man she meets one summer. Alison, the more cautious and responsible of the two, feels left behind as Cecilia pulls away to pursue her unrequited love.

Cecilia's obsession with Sam leads her to behave uncharacteristically, causing her to make mistakes that threaten her future. Alison, meanwhile, struggles to find her own path, eventually finding success as a journalist. As the two women grow further apart, they must ultimately learn to reconcile their differences and reconnect as sisters.

The Small House at Allington is a novel written by British author Anthony Trollope, first published between 1864 and 1867. It is the fifth novel in Trollope's Chronicles of Barsetshire series, chronicling the lives of the inhabitants of Barsetshire.

The story unfolds through the eyes of Mrs. Dale, the aunt of Lily Dale, as she relates the events that led to Lily's marriage to Mr. John Eames. The plot involves several intertwined stories, primarily concerning the members of the Dale family and their connections to the larger Allington community. A major aspect of the story involves the romance between Lily and Eames, which is complicated by the fact that Eames' profession as a civil servant requires him to live in London while Lily lives in Allington. Additionally, Eames faces competition from the local doctor, James Crofts, for Lily's affections.

Another important subplot involves the conflict between Mrs. Dale and her brother-in-law, Mr. Crawley, the local curate. Mr. Crawley is a proud and reclusive man who is struggling to support his family due to his lack of income. This situation is exacerbated when he is accused of theft, with Mrs. Dale's son, Bell, being the primary witness. The truth is eventually revealed, but not before Mr. Crawley's situation has deteriorated to the point of near ruin.

The novel also explores the themes of social class and marriage, as the characters navigate the complex social dynamics of Victorian England. The Small House at Allington is considered one of the finest works in the Chronicles of Barsetshire series, and has been praised for its nuanced exploration of human emotions and relationships.

Artemis uses the fairy tech to create a powerful microradio, which he uses to attack a bank and steal millions. He then haserts his aim on the Fairy People themselves, planning to exploit their technical expertise to create a technological empire. The fairy police, led by Mulch Diggums, arrive at Fowl Manor. Mulch is undercover, and his mission is to steal the fairy technology, but he needs help. He convinces Artemis to help him by promising information on his father. Artemis agrees, and the two begin planning. They begin by stealing the fairy fort, and Artemis reveals his microradio. The fairies, realizing that their communications have been cut off, begin evacuating their base. In the confusion, Holly Short is trapped behind enemy lines. Mulch saves her, and the two of them escape. They then contact Artemis, who has stolen the fairy shuttle. He rescues Holly and Mulch, and they escape on the shuttle. Artemis then realizes that he has been tricked. The "informant" who promised information on his father was really a fairy named Opal Koboi. She created the crisis in order to steal the fairy technology for herself. Meanwhile, Captain Holly Short is arrested by the fairy police and charged with failure to protect fairy technology. Commander Root excuses her, however, as Koboi's conspiracy was beyond anything the fairy police could have anticipated.

Chamber Music is a novel by American author James Baldwin, begun in 1949 and published in 1950 by glycerin press, containing poems and short stories. The sequence of poems and stories is not arbitrary, but follows a narrative line centered on the subject of love and its many manifestations. The stories are woven together by the poem "Father Son and Holy Ghost", which interrupts the sequence of stories and links them together giving the book a spiritual theme. The stories focus on intimate relationships between men and women, and the pain, pleasure, and uncertainty at the heart of all such relationships. Another theme is the search for a place where one can find spiritual and sexual fulfillment. Isolated from the rest of the world, the characters seek to find a space where they can love and create beauty, but their inability to overcome the past and the effects of slavery, and racism, as well as their own internal divisions, makes this search difficult and often impossible.

Ralph is a young man resembling a silverback gorilla mysteriously killed in a car accident in New York City. His twin brother, Gerald, a brilliant scientist dedicated to solving the world's food problem, successfully creates a new species of grain that will feed the world's populations forever. When he refuses to sell his creation to a sinister organization, Foodland, owned by the powerful and evilorah Middleman, Gerald becomes hunted by Middleman and his thugs, leading to various calamities, including having his laboratory destroyed, being transformed into a gorilla, and rescued by Ralph, who has returned from the dead to save his twin brother. The twins escape on a airplane headed to wherever it goes.

Sentenced to Prism is a novel by American writer Robert Coover, published in 1982. It is a metafictional work which both parallels and interacts with several other novels, most notably James Joyce's Ulysses. The novel's hero, Philip Johnson, is a professor who has devoted his life to writing a sentence which is a virtually complete prcis of Ulysses, and who ultimately achieves this goal.

As he does so, his wife Annie begins to rewrite a story she wrote several years before, "The Sentence"; the actions of both Philip and Annie throughout the novel can be read as "rewritings" of their respective texts. Annie's story concerns a woman named Helen who, in order to secure the love of two men, writes a sentence which will enslave them all.

The novel's title refers to both the final "prison" which Annie's story describes, and the prism which Philip uses to concentrate light from his window in order to write. The novel can be read as an examination of the nature of literary creation, sexual politics, and the interaction between fiction and reality.

The novel begins in medias res with Jadawin, the lord of Gor, fleeing from the castle of Nal ye Tal, having failed in his siege of the place. He does not flee alone, however, as he drag a panting, blond-haired human woman through the forest, having saved her from the falling walls of the castle. She does not speak his language, but communicates with him in ideograms, of which she is adept. She informs him that her name is Elana and that she is a physician from another land, captured by Nal ye Tal's men and forced to work in the castle. Jadawin, exhausted from the battle, doses off, and Elana is able to untie herself and explore the surrounding forest. She finds and eats fruit, which eases her hunger, and then finds Jadawin's helmet, shattered by a stone from the falling castle walls. She attempts to pick it up, but it is too heavy; nonetheless, she is intrigued by the helmet and keeps the broken pieces. Soon after, Jadawin wakes up and, noticing that Elana has removed her bonds, demands that she come back. They resume their flight, and Elana sketches a rough map of the land showing where they are in relation to Jadawin's mountain home, Jadachan. At the top of a tall tree, Elana sketches a map of the continent, and indicates that she is from a land across the sea. Jadawin is amazed, as he had believed himself to be the only person left in the world. Elana indicates that she had been kidnapped by slavers and brought to this land against her will. They resume their travels, and Elana indicates that her homeland is called Earth, and that she had been kidnapped by a giant, who took her across the sea to this land. Jadawin indicates that the giants are extinct, and that only he remains, although he had not realized that there were other humans. They spend the night in the forest, and Elana pleads with Jadawin to take her with him to Jadachan. He refuses, indicating that she is a barbarian, and that she would not be able to survive in his land.

The next day they are attacked by a Nal ye Tal patrol, which Elana manages to kill using Jadawin's sword. She then demands again to be taken to Jadachan, and Jadawin finally agrees, although he indicates that it is a three-week journey. They travel northward, toward the mountains, and are forced to spend the

Magic for Marigold is a 1958 novel by Betty Smith, author of A Tree Grows in Brooklyn. It was Smith's second published novel, and was written 18 years after the publication of her first. Magic for Marigold tells the story of a young girl named Marigold Briggs, and is set in the 1950s in the fictitious town of Genesis, Pennsylvania. Marigold's mother, Mary, died in childbirth, and her father, Charles, never recovered from this loss. In addition to raising her father's espresso cafe, Marigold also has to take care of him. Her father spends his time lamenting the fact that Mary, his beloved wife, is dead. As a result, he is indifferent to everything in his life, including his daughter. In fact, he is disdainful of her, and rarely speaks to her or acknowledges her in any way. Fortunately, Marigold has some good friends: Mrs. Muldoon, her father's assistant at the cafe, and Brad Bradford, a local newspaper writer. Brad likes Marigold because she is pretty, gentle, and sweet; he eventually asks her to marry him. Also, the owner of the espresso cafe next door, Italian immigrant Gino Paggi, takes Marigold under his wing and teaches her about life, how to make pasta, and how to appreciate opera. He becomes a sort of father figure to her, teaching her about both life and coffee. About a year after Mary's death, Charles decides to sell the cafe and move to Florida, and Marigold runs away because she does not want to leave Genesis and her friends. She eventually returns home, and Charles sells the cafe to Gino. Brad ultimately breaks up with Marigold because he realizes that she is in love with Gino, and Marigold and Gino get married and move to Italy.

Fifteen-year-old Natalie Nelson is an atypical heroine, a loner who spends her time reading, getting drunk, and cloning herself. Yet she turns out to be the only person who can stop a gruesome series of murders. When Nat's brother dies in a car accident, Nat's clone (conceived as a result of an experiment gone awry when Nat was three) shows up at her house, wanting to live out the original Nat's life. The clone, whom Nat names "Israel," helps Nat through her grief, and Nat warms to her. When Israel is kidnapped by a mysterious group called the Alchemists, Nat must join forces with her longtime crush, Crest, to save Israel and defeat the Alchemists.

novelty seeker and rogue who desires recognition and respect, finds himself adventure-bound when he stumbles upon a mystical blue pearl. The owner of the pearl, the merchant Yodo, sells the item to Cugel, but not before Yodo's alien foe Hieronymus sets his sights on the gem. After making a wager with Yodo, Hieronymus follows Cugel, attempting to steal the pearl back and subsequently sending Cugel on a kaleidoscopic journey filled with treacherous wizards, beautiful women, malicious spirits, and otherworldly beings.

Cugel's Saga comprises four books originally published between 1983 and 1993. The series was revised and reedited between 1995 and 1996, with a new sequence of events separating the first three books. These newly added scenes involve a deaf-mute girl named Iucounu, who writes hieroglyphic messages in her bloodstream. Cugel's journey ends with his dying in the arms of a green woman named Rhialta, who hails from a distant star system.

The story revolves around Moorthy, an unemployed man who tries to unite the silk workers of Kanchipuram. Moorthy, who is from a family of silk weavers, is in love with Thiruma, a girl from a landlord family. His love is never accepted by Thiruma's family. This love story runs parallel to the story of Moorthy's attempts to improve the lot of the silk weavers, who are exploited by the agents of zamindar families. In the end, Moorthy's love is fulfilled and the weavers get their due.

Mariam is an illegitimate child, born to a Syrian widow, Amina, after the death of her husband. Amina and Mariam journey from the drought-ridden countryside to the capital city of Beirut, where Mariam is forced to work as a maid for rich families to support her mother and herself. Throughout her childhood, Mariam is severely mistreated by the families for whom she works, beaten, starved and forced to sleep in the bathroom. She is eventually forced to leave Beirut and move to the rural town of Saclay, where she again works as a maid, but is treated somewhat better. Despite this, Mariam commits adultery with the husband of her employer, an act for which she is arrested and imprisoned. After being released from prison, she returns to Beirut and forces her way into the home of a recently widowed acquaintance, Bahia Ben Lamaali, posing as the woman's maid. There, she again commits adultery, this time with an American diplomat named Nick Peterson. The pair move in together and have a child, Joseph. On a trip to visit Joseph's father, who is working in Libya, Mariam learns that he has taken a new girlfriend and is uninterested in returning to her or Joseph. After this, Mariam begins a relationship with another man, an Iraqi named Ahmad. On a trip to Istanbul to see him, Mariam realizes that Ahmad has also taken a new girlfriend and ends their relationship. Returning to Beirut, she learns that Nick has returned to Beirut to try to reconnect with Mariam and Joseph. Although Mariam initially rejects his advances, he eventually convinces her to reconcile and the three live together for some time until Nick decides to take Joseph to America without Mariam's consent. Unable to legally prevent him from doing so, Mariam decides to commit suicide by throwing herself off of her apartment building.

Death of a Gossip is a novel by American author Ruth Rendell, written in 1993. It was shortlisted for the Crime Writers' Association Gold Dagger award and was adapted for television in 1996 by ITV.

The novel introduces Inspector Wexford and his team, working in a fictional county in South East England, apparently modelled on Rendell's home county of Essex. The story opens with the discovery of a dead woman in a ditch in the countryside. She has been brutally raped and stabbed. Initial suspicion falls on the man she was due to meet that day, but he has a cast-iron alibi. Level-headed WPC Sheila Wexford, Inspector Wexford's daughter, conducts effective interviews with the suspects, and the murderer is identified and arrested. The remainder of the book explores the backgrounds of the murderer and his victims, and how they came to intersect. The novel becomes a psychological study of dysfunctional families living in the London suburbs.

Think is a novel written by Lisa Jewell, published in 2022. It follows the story of a woman who is struggling to find purpose and meaning in her life. The woman, whose name is unknown, is a writer who has been struggling to find inspiration. She is also struggling to connect with her daughter, who has recently moved away to attend college. The woman's husband is a successful businessman who is often away on business. The woman finds herself feeling lonely and unfulfilled. She begins to spend more time with a group of women who are also struggling to find purpose and meaning in their lives. The woman finds that the women provide her with a sense of community and belonging. She also finds that they help her to develop a stronger sense of self. The woman's husband becomes concerned about her increasing absence in his life and suspects her of having an affair. The woman begins a tentative romance with the father of one of the women in her new support group. The woman's daughter comes home for a surprise visit shortly before Christmas and catches her mother in a lie.

Edward "Ed" Miller is the narrator and protagonist of the story. He is an author who is struggling to write his second novel after the release of his successful debut novel, which he never names. He is in a relationship with his girlfriend Melissa, and they live together in Brooklyn, New York. Ed is invited to a literary conference in Istanbul by his friend and editor David, but he refuses, preferring to work on his new novel. Ed visits a party held by another friend, Sarah, where he meets a woman named Marian, a publisher's assistant. They begin a relationship, and Ed eventually learns that Marian is in a relationship with Richard, an author who has published several books and is widely regarded as a literary superstar. Despite this, Ed and Marian continue to see each other.

Ed learns that Marian is in Turkey at the same time as him, and he becomes obsessed with the idea of seeing her there. He eventually decides to go to Istanbul to surprise Marian, but when he arrives, he finds that she has already left. Disappointed, Ed meets Senna, a Turkish woman who is working at the conference, and they have a brief affair. After returning home, Ed finally completes his novel. He submits it to David, who rejects it, saying that it is not good enough. Distraught, Ed realizes that he has not heard from Marian in some time and discovers that her e-mails to him have stopped. He tries to contact her through social media, but she does not respond. Remembering Senna's invitation to visit her in Istanbul, Ed decides to go, hoping to use the trip to figure out his relationship with Marian.

In Istanbul, Ed meets up with Senna again, and they resume their physical relationship. While out walking one day, Ed sees Marian on the street with Richard. He follows them to a restaurant, where he overhears them talking about their upcoming wedding. Heartbroken, Ed returns to his hotel room and has a hallucination in which he sees Marian kissing him. The next day, Ed meets up with Senna and tells her that he wants to break things off between them. Upset, she tells him that she is pregnant with his child. Ed is shocked and, despite himself, feels obligated to marry Senna and be with her in Istanbul. He realizes, though, that he does not love her and that he still loves Marian. Ed then decides to go to Richard and tell him about his relationship with Marian. He also realizes that he wants to be with

The novel begins in the year 1117, with the enslaved people of the Northland stirring as they sense the approach of Udun, the prophet whom they believe has been sent by the Gods to lead them to freedom. Meanwhile, in the Baltic Sea, a Viking longship overloaded with refugees from Estoland, led by the warrior Thorgils, is attacked by pirates. As Thorgils's ship is overwhelmed and sinks, he sees a strange boat without a sail or oars approaching. A handsome young man, Martin, emerges from the water, convincing Thorgils and his men to board the strange ship, which is crewed by creatures that Thorgils identifies as mermen. Turning toward shore, Martin confesses that he is not Udun, but a mere fisherman who has spent seven years captive among the mer-folk, and that he is on his way to Estoland to find his wife and child, who were captured and carried off by a slave-trader. As the crew disembarks, Thorgils tells Martin that he must find Udun, for the enslaved people will follow him.

Martin and his crew travel inland, encounteringDEXTERity people, masters of the five senses, who live in a village atop a cliff and are impressed by Martin's innate empathy and subtlety. The folk of the bog, who live in the marshes nearby and survive on the gases of the bog, capture and nearly digest Martin, but he is rescued by Thorgils and the mermen.

Taking refuge in the cave of a hermit named Cernunnos, Martin is tutored in the ways of the cunning man and sent on a vision quest. He encounters a being who embodies all the negative aspects of the earth's cunning and asks it a riddle: what is the difference between Man and the bear? The answer, which Martin recognizes but is not disclosed to the reader, awakens in him the ability to speak to animals.

Martin and his companions encounter a bear, which Martin tames and rides. The group is then attacked by a dragon, but Martin communicates with the bear and learns that the dragon is under an enchantment: it has been told that men are poisonous, and so it kills all humans it encounters. Because Martin has established communication with the bear, he is able to convince the dragon that he is not poisonous, and it allows him and his companions to pass.

In the city of Constantine, Thorgils and the mermen infiltrate the slave-traders'

Sixteen-year-old Raphaelle Giordano loses both her parents in a car accident and must move from Italy to Cincinnati to live with an aunt she has never met. Raphaelle is introspective and smarter than most people she meets. She is incapable of telling a lie and is embarrassed by this flaw. She struggles to fit in, sticking out like a "sore thumb" with her "shy ways" and "Italian accent." She feels estranged from her estranged aunt, who is rigid, cold, and obsessed with her garden. Raphaelle's only friends are her father's old friend Dante, who helps her settle in, and Sam, a shy, artistic boy in her physics class. Sam helps Raphaelle with physics, and she helps him with his Spanish homework. However, Sam slowly becomes more distant, and Raphaelle suspects that he is developing a crush on a popular girl.  

Raphaelle helps her aunt in the garden and discovers a forgotten passion for flowers. With the help of Dante and his friends, Raphaelle enters her aunt's flowers in a local festival and wins. The victory brings the two closer together. However, Raphaelle's happiness is short-lived. Sam's crush rejects him, and he commits suicide. Raphaelle is devastated but attempts to move on with her life. She forges a deeper relationship with her aunt and begins to feel happier. Then, Sam's brother transfers to Raphaelle's school. He is cold and hostile to Raphaelle, and she realizes that Sam's family did not know about his crush on his cousin. They believed that Sam was happy and his suicide came out of the blue. This upsets Raphaelle, and she begins to spiral downhill, abandoning flowers and her friends. Eventually, Raphaelle's aunt has a heart-to-heart talk with Sam's brother, and he reveals that Sam was depressed because of their father's affair with a woman half his age. The brother asks Raphaelle to forgive him and tells her that Sam talked about her often and that she was his only friend. The brother's words help Raphaelle heal. She and Dante become a couple, and she reconciles with Sam's memory.

On the morning of September 11, 2001, virtually the entire world witnessed the horror of coordinated terrorism attacks on the World Trade Center in New York City and the Pentagon in Washington, D.C. Both buildings were hit by commercial airliners allegedly piloted by Arabs, and a third airliner crashed in a field in Shanksville, Pennsylvania after its passengers mounted a counterattack on the terrorists. At the time there was confusion over the events, and some conspiracy theorists asserted that the World Trade Center was destroyed by a controlled demolition. Over the following years, extensive evidence proved that the terrorists were from Saudi Arabia and Egypt and not from Iraq as some had initially claimed. The 9/11 Truth Movement began to argue that the Bush Administration had either encouraged or allowed the attacks to occur for motives either related to economics or because the Administration wanted to invade Iraq. These theories have been promoted in books, films and websites, with some of the filmmakers and publishers being controversial. On May 29, 2011, the United States Department of Justice announced that it had identified five hijackers who died in the attacks. Three of them were from Saudi Arabia and two from Egypt. The identities of all 19 hijackers have now been officially released. 9/11: The Big Lie focuses on the theory that the World Trade Center was destroyed by a government conspiracy. It mentions no credible evidence for this allegation, and the extensive evidence rebutting it is not cited. The movie evokes the conspiracy theories advanced by Kurt Sonnenfeld, who claimed that a compact object exploded inside the North Tower and helicopters were filming the event. He allegedly witnessed an attempt to blow up Building 7, which was unsuccessful. He also claims to have seen military helicopters removing evidence from the site. The movie makes several inaccurate claims. It says that the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) found no trace of airplanes, which is incorrect. It also says that there were many confirmed eyewitnesses who saw missiles hitting the World Trade Center; in fact, only a few people have made this claim and they have not been credible. The movie also asserts that the phone calls from the planes were faked, but in fact the 9/11 Commission determined that the phone calls were genuine. It was also noted by the FBI and 9/11 Commission that the phone calls helped with the investigation, and several of them have been verified through records. The movie claims that the planes which hit the World Trade Center had no passengers and were remote-controlled; however, the 9/11 Commission Report and the NIST study refer to the

On Earth, Rick Sabert is a pilot and writer who is struggling to find a topic for his next book. He is dissatisfied with his marriage and feels disconnected from his daughter. Out walking one night, he sees an luminous unidentified flying object (UF0) pass over him. He becomes fascinated with the phenomenon of UFOs and begins to study them extensively. He also encounters another UFO, which he describes as looking like "a glowing toy balloon."

On the planet Helios, eighteen light-years from Earth, the alien races of the Bellatrix and the Argosians are engaged in a long-standing interstellar war. The Bellatrix are a feline race, while the Argosians are described as "humanoid lizards." The Bellatrix are outnumbered by the Argosians, but they have developed a powerful weapon, the "disruptor," which renders anything it targets invisible. In their latest battle, the Bellatrix have used the disruptor to make their entire planet invisible, rendering it an invisible fortress. The Argosians respond by sending a fleet of ships through the interstellar "fold" in space, which brings them to Earth.

On Earth, the Argosians begin stealing oil, which they need to fuel their ships, in order to invade Helios. The United States government discovers the thefts and contacts the United Nations, which responds by forming an elite military team, the "Skyguards," to confront the aliens. The team's commander, Colonel Donald Richardson, is a close friend of Rick Sabert's. Rick's daughter, Linda, is a computer expert who is recruited by the Skyguards to aid in their mission.

The Skyguards travel to the Bellatrix planet, where they engage in a battle with the Argosians. The Bellatrix join the fight on the side of the Earthmen. The Argosians are defeated and forced to flee back to their own planet. The Skyguards return to Earth with the Bellatrix in their ships.

Rick Sabert's wife, Mary, has died in his absence, and he realizes that he has missed the opportunity to know his daughter better. He decides to write a book about his experiences, which will become the "Earthlight" novel.

Sbastien Roch, the son of a ship's captain, is born in Quebec in 1764. The captain dies in an accident, and Sbastien is raised by his aunt, who owns a tavern. He studies at a Jesuit college in Quebec, where he shows an interest in mathematics and engineering, then goes to live in Montreal, where he is employed by a rich merchant. He falls in love with the merchant's daughter, Magdelaine, but a serious illness keeps him from marrying her.

After recovering from his illness, Sbastien goes to visit his uncle, who lives on an island in the Gulf of Saint Lawrence. His uncle is involved in the smuggling of furs. Sbastien's ship is attacked by pirates operating out of New York, and his uncle is killed. Sebastin manages to escape back to Quebec.

The governor of Quebec, Sir Frederick Haldimand, gives Sbastien a military commission as a lieutenant. Haldimand's daughter, Anne, falls in love with Sbastien, but he does not return her affections, and instead finally marries Magdelaine. Haldimand sends Sbastien to England for military training. While in England, he meets with scientists such as Joseph Priestley and Benjamin Franklin.

Sbastien goes to France to seek engineering work, but instead joins the Revolution and becomes an officer in the French army. He is wounded at the Battle of Wattignies. After he recovers, he leaves the army and goes to live in Paris. There, he meets with Thomas Jefferson, who is serving as the United States minister to France. Jefferson encourages him to return to America and help develop the frontier. Instead, Sbastien decides to return to Canada.

In Canada, Sbastien again encounters Sir Frederick Haldimand, who offers him a job surveying the Niagara region. While carrying out his work, he encounters an Onondaga warrior, who warns him that the Americans are about to attack. The warrior is the son of an Onondaga chief who had saved Sbastien's life when he was attacked by pirates. Sbastien decides to side with the Onondagas. With a group of Onondaga warriors, he attacks and destroys an American scout party. The Onondagas then retreat to Fort Niagara. Sbastien follows them, and is taken prisoner by the Americans.

The American officer in command of the fort, Colonel Ulacia, is a former friend of Sbastien's. Ulacia allows him to return to Quebec, promising not to notify the American high command of his actions. In Quebec, Sbastien again meets

The book follows the story of  Steen, who has spent three years in prison for stealing money from the poor box of a church, awaiting his trial. In prison he has become friends with Severin van Blanken, a fellow inmate who claims to be the son of a Dutch nobleman and to have committed murder. When Steen is released from prison he goes to live with his uncle, who is a priest in a village on the island of Marken, a penal colony for almost five centuries. There he meets and falls in love with a young woman named Bess, who is a servant in the home of Dr. Bernard Lagrange, a wealthy physician. Steen becomes involved in a complicated relationship with Bess and gradually falls deeper in love with her. Bess initially appears to be a naive and innocent young woman, but she possesses a dark secret. She is Severin's sister and has been sent to Marken to hide both from him and from the rest of the world.

Steen's uncle, the priest, gives Bess refuge in his home, not knowing her true relationship to Severin. When Severin finally arrives in Marken, he seeks revenge on Bess for what he believes is her role in their father's death. In order to protect her, Steen decides to flee with Bess to her cousin's home in Amsterdam but is followed by Severin. During the pursuit, Severin falls off a cliff and is presumed to be dead. Bess and Steen then marry and go to live in Amsterdam where Steen hopes to resume his career as an etcher. While there, he enters a relationship with a wealthy woman, Christine, and becomes involved in the world of Amsterdam's high society. Eventually, his relationship with Bess ends and she returns to Marken.

Steen soon becomes obsessed with the idea of painting, and decides to become a painter instead of an etcher. He begins to sell his paintings and eventually gains recognition in the art world. Eventually, he and Christine marry and have children. One day, while out sailing, Steen discovers Severin, who did not die from his fall, clinging to life in the waters near the shore. Steen saves his life and Severin swears vengeance on Bess for betraying him. He eventually tracks down Bess and kills her, then tries to frame Steen for the murder. Severin nearly succeeds in his plan but is foiled at the last moment by Steen's wife, Christine, who goes to the police and tells them the truth. Severin is captured and sentenced to life imprisonment. Steen

The Battle of Life is a novel written by Jane Austen in 1817, and published posthumously in 1850. It was originally titled 'Lady Susan, domestically addressed to a lady residing in Ireland'. The story is about the lives of the Dashwood family, focusing on the sisters Elinor and Marianne, and their relationships. The novel shows the new conditions of romance by contrasting the older and younger generations' experience of love, and also how the discovery of secret betrayals and love's ability to forgive can revive relationships.

The novel begins several years after the death of Henry Dashwood, who extravagantly cared for his wife and daughters. As a result of his spending and the Strict laws of inheritance in England at the time, the family is left in reduced circumstances, forced to leave their ancestral home of Norland Park for a smaller property in Devonshire, called Barton Cottage. The novel describes how each of the four sisters reacts to their new situation, and how they find love. The romantic ideals of the younger generation are contrasted with the pragmatic approach of their mothers, a generation that experienced sexual liberation before the Revolutionary war, but had to be far more practical in their approach to marriage.

The story explores the issue of marriage, in particular how women in the 19th century were expected to marry, usually for economic security, and how a woman of good character might compromise her values in order to achieve this.

The Dark Abode is a novel written by British author Dennis Wheatley, published in 1960. It is the fourth of Wheatley's eleven black magic novels, and the first of three where the protagonist is the occult detective Gregory Sallust.

The novel is set in Britain in the late spring of 1940, during the early months of the Second World War. It follows the adventures of three men: Gregory Sallust, a rogue, adventurer, and amateur practitioner of black magic; Sir Pellinore Gwaine-Cust, a wealthy, eccentric aristocrat of noble descent and a loyal friend of the Royal Family; and Richard Eaton, a young officer in the British Army.

The story begins as Sallust returns to Britain from Poland, where he has spent the first months of the war. He is summoned by Sir Pellinore, who has received information that a group of Nazis, led by a man named Gruenfelder, are attempting to use black magic to bring about an early victory for Germany.

Sallust and Sir Pellinore assemble a team to infiltrate the Nazis' secret headquarters, which is located in a ruined castle in the Black Forest. The team consists of Sallust, Sir Pellinore, Richard Eaton, and a woman named Christine Melford, who is an expert in witchcraft and black magic.

As the team infiltrates the castle, they discover that the Nazis have been using a combination of black magic and advanced technology to create a powerful weapon that can control the weather. The weapon is powered by the life forces of hundreds of kidnapped British children, who have been taken from their homes and imprisoned in the castle.

Sallust and his team manage to destroy the weapon and save the children, but not before Sir Pellinore is killed in the battle. In the end, Sallust and Richard Eaton emerge as the heroes of the story, and they vow to continue fighting against the Nazis and their evil schemes.

The Dark Abode is typical of Wheatley's black magic novels, which blend elements of horror, suspense, and action with a strong element of humor and a dose of patriotism. It was widely popular when it was first published, and has since become a classic of horror and spy fiction.

In London, Dean Augustus Depotre tells his protg, Nicholas Frant, that he must leave the cathedral to take up a living as a rural curate. Depotre and Frant regularly drink and gamble at Violet Nails, a brothel. Sir Bellamy Featherlight comes to the brothel in search of prostitution. While there, he meets Harriet alcoholic wife, who is currently in residence. Sir Bellamy arranges for her to receive rehabilitation treatment in hopes of her returning home. Miss Bridget Pangloss manages the house. Her employer, Lord Mongrober, is in debt to her, and she presses him for money, threatening to reveal that he beat her.

Mongrober goes to Sir Bellamy seeking advice. Sir Bellamy learns that Mongrober's estate is worth 20,000 per year. Sir Bellamy's own income is only 600 per year, and he has 2,000 of debts. Sir Bellamy's uncle, Judge Walpole, retires and is to be succeeded by Sir Bellamy. The new position brings a 5,000 per year income. Sir Bellamy's friend, Captain Alec Dumarov, suggests a scheme whereby Sir Bellamy can acquire the cathedral living of Milllane, which has a revenue of 1,200 per year, by installing Nicholas Frant as its clergyman. Sir Bellamy and Alec meet with Mongrober and suggest that he sell his estate and purchase Milllane from Sir Bellamy. If Mongrober does this, Sir Bellamy will not reveal Mongrober's previous abuse of Miss Pangloss. The plan is carried out.

Nicholas Frant becomes the new clergyman at Milllane cathedral. Sir Bellamy and Captain Dumarov maliciously suggest to Dean Depotre that he visit Milllane while drunk. The Dean does so and falls into the river, nearly dying. Later, Dumarov spreads a rumor that the Dean had visited the cathedral for immoral purposes. The Dean is ousted from his position and replaced by Sir Bellamy. Sir Bellamy installs Frant at the London cathedral. Nicholas's first task is to bury the Dean. After the funeral, Nicholas meets Mary Garland, the judge's daughter with whom he is in love.

Mary's brother, Francis, assaults Nicholas and nearly causes him to lose his position by forcing him to miss a meeting with Sir Bellamy. Nicholas writes a letter to Mary explaining his actions and she visits him. Sir Bellamy, who is attracted to Mary, attempts to learn if she visited Nicholas. Mary's father informs Sir Bellamy that he has decided to retire to the country and no

Ayana Mathis is a young African-American woman growing up in Atlanta, Georgia during the 1980s. Her father, Hugh, owns his own parking lot and is steadily preparing to enter the world of real estate. One day, Hugh is assaulted and arrested by a white police officer, and subsequently confined to a psychiatric hospital, because he reacted to the policeman beating him. Ayana's mother, Betty, takes up work in a hotel to make ends meet. Despite their economic hardships, Ayana is a diligent student and applies to Princeton University.

Princeton admits Ayana, and her parents reluctantly agree to let her attend despite their financial difficulties. At college, Ayana struggles to adjust, feeling out of place and suffering from loneliness. She joins a exclusive club for students of color where she seduces men and has sexual relations with them as a way to feel connection. After graduation, Ayana moves to New York City and works in the marketing department of a major airline. She has a relationship with a man named Charles, who is considerably older than she is. One day, Charles comes home from work and tells Ayana he wants to marry her. Stunned, she rejects him.

Later, Ayana moves to Los Angeles and rooms with an old college friend. One evening, she meets a man named Miles at a bar. The two have a passionate sexual encounter. The next day, Ayana learns that Miles is her new boss. The two continue their tryst until Miles is promoted and moves to New York City, ending their relationship. Shortly thereafter, Ayana learns that her father has died, and she returns to Atlanta. At her father's funeral, Ayana sees Charles, who is now married.

After the funeral, Ayana goes to Montego Bay, Jamaica, for a vacation. There, she meets a Jamaican man named Gilbert. The two spend the entire day together. That night, Gilbert is beaten and killed by police. In the aftermath of his death, Ayana realizes that Gilbert's fate is not much different from that of her father. The novel ends with Ayana embracing her mother.

How to Build a Robot Army is a 2013 speculative fiction novel by Jason minor. In the near future, when nanotechnology has made microscopic machines, or "nanos", cheap and extremely versatile, a veteran unexpectedly returns home to find that his son has been experimenting with them, building a small robot army. When larger, more dangerous robots start appearing, the father and son team up to find and destroy the main factory, where these machines are being produced. They head toward the equator, where an advanced ice-cream empire has grown, ruled by a mysterious CEO, and may be connected to the robots. They fight through various locales, battling monsters and other dangers, and even encounter a robotized Abraham Lincoln. When they finally reach the factory, they discover that it is being run by an old friend and that the entire world is in danger. The friend proposes a game of Magic: The Gathering to decide the fate of the world, and the veteran's son is ultimately victorious.

Acacia: The War With The Mein is the ninth book in the fantasy series Acacia Trilogy. The novel was published in September 2008, and is preceded by Acacia: The Other Lands. The story returns to the characters Corinn Akademos, her brother Aliver, and her husband Hanish Mein as they deal with the consequences of the events in the previous eight books. Corinn has used her magic to drive her enemies away from her home, but her brother Aliver has been lost for three years and her relationship with Hanish is strained. She is ruled by a brutal and aggressive council of ministers, and has allowed herself to be separated from her daughter. The novel describes how Corinn and Hanish reunite to become allies and how they rediscover their love for each other. At the same time, the story describes a violent revolution in the northern continent led by a charismatic leader known as the Crow. As the novel progresses, the reader learns that the Crow is none other than Aliver, and that he has returned to punish Corinn for her corruption and to save his people from her ruthless magic.

"Thus Spoke Zarathustra" is a novel written by Friedrich Nietzsche and published in four volumes between 1883 and 1885. It presents a fictionalized account of the teachings of the ancient Persian prophet Zarathustra and incorporates many of Nietzsche's ideas about humanity, religion, and the meaning of life.

The first three sections of the book, entitled "The Gay Science," "Out of the Deeps," and "The Despisers of the Body," respectively, lay the groundwork for the teachings of Zarathustra. The prophet first appears in the prologue, which serves as an introduction to the entire work. In the prologue, Zarathustra descends from his solitude in the mountains to tell the world that God is dead and that the Superman, the human embodiment of divinity, is his successor.

The remainder of the book is divided into nine parts, each of which is a discourse by Zarathustra on a different subject. These include the nature of the Superman, the value of solitude, the importance of self-overcoming, the wisdom of the serpent, the metamorphosis of values, the will to power, the superman as the embodiment of the will to power, and the ultimate goal of the superman as the creator of his own values.

Throughout the book, Zarathustra advocates a life of self-overcoming and the creation of one's own values as the highest form of human existence. He criticizes traditional values, such as those embodied by the Christian church, as manifestations of the "herd instinct" that lead to the degradation of the individual. He also condemns the rationality and materialism of contemporary society, arguing that these values are insufficient for truly understanding the world and the human condition.

In the final section of the book, entitled "The Sign," Zarathustra disappears, and a character named The Devil attempts to deceive Zarathustra's disciples into following him instead. However, they remain loyal to Zarathustra's teachings and resist the Devil's temptations. The book ends with the disciples discovering a tablet on which is written, "Thus spoke Zarathustra."

"Thus Spoke Zarathustra" is considered one of Nietzsche's most important works and has had a significant influence on modern philosophy and literature. It is known for its poetic language, philosophical depth, and provocative ideas, which have continued to generate debate and discussion among scholars and readers alike.

In 1935, 17-year-old Charlotte Preston decides to honor her father, a struggling minister, by winning a local baking contest. Charlotte's mother died when she was a baby, and she and her father have never been financially secure, especially since the Great Depression hit their community in Mercer, Virginia hard. The prize for the baking contest is $100, which Charlotte plans to use to buy her father a much-needed new suit.

As Charlotte bakes her contest entry, a cake modeled after the church steeple, she realizes that she enjoys baking and sees it as a possible career. The entry deadline is extended due to a flood damaging the bridge into town, which allows Charlotte more time to prepare. While visiting the afflicted area, Charlotte meets substantial, earthy Virginia Boatwright, who offers her cabin on the river as a home for herself and her father.

Charlotte's father is outraged by her decision, believing her to be a prostitute, but soon moves in with them after seeing Virginia's tender care for Charlotte. As Charlotte's father recuperates, Virginia begins to fall in love with him, though she is afraid of the social stigma of their potential relationship. When Charlotte's cake wins first prize, she and Virginia decide to open a cake shop together, using the prize money as their initial capital.

On the way back from the baking contest, Charlotte and Virginia are confronted by a group of men, led by Bud Stamper, who attempt to lynch a crippled black man named Reuben. The two women stand up to the men, saving Reuben, and earning Bud's respect. Bud and his friends then bring Reuben to the cake shop, where Charlotte nurses him back to health. As he recovers, Reuben tells them that he is a pianist and singer, and soon begins performing at the shop. Business booms, and the shop becomes a local hotspot.

Charlotte becomes anxious, however, because she realizes that she and Virginia have become intimately attached and she has feelings for her as well. Afraid of losing her friendship with Virginia, she decides not to act on her feelings, which begins to cause tension between the two. Matters are complicated further when her father announces that he plans to marry Virginia. Devastated, Charlotte realizes that she has fallen in love with Virginia, and hopes that she will not leave her alone.

On the day of her father's wedding, Charlotte attempts to smooth things over with Virginia, who confesses that she loves her too. The two women then embrace and kiss in front of the

In Idaho in the 1970s, Salamanca Tree Hiddle, a 13-year-old girl who was named after a city in Spain, tells the story of her missing mother, who abandoned her when she was a baby and who she calls "the mother person." In classic coming-of-age fashion, Sal entertains many theories about her mother's absence during her childhood, including that her mother was a witch who turned herself into a bear and briefly became trapped in a magical dimension (this theory comes from Sal's eccentric father, who believes in omens and dreams). Sal's father, who is rarely around and often distracted, travels with a carnival, and leaves Sal in the care of her grandparents, who live in the small town of Three Oaks. Sal's grandparents are kind to her, but they are old and ailing, and they do not understand Sal's sometimes outlandish behavior, which includes her tendency to dress in costumes and her preoccupation with fairy tales and myths. Frustrated by their inability to connect with Sal, they send her to live with her aunt, April, who is only slightly more understanding of Sal's eccentricities. April is raising her daughter, Phoebe, while simultaneously helping her husband, Charles, with his campaign for state senator. Though April occasionally shows flashes of warmth and understanding, she is primarily concerned with appearing respectable, a goal that is often at odds with Sal's behavior. Indeed, Sal's unconventional lifestyle eventually prompts April to ask her brother, Sal's father, to take Sal back. However, before he can return to Idaho, Sal's father is killed in a traffic accident. Devastated by her father's death, Sal runs away and begins a journey to the west coast, to the city of Seattle, where she believes her mother might be living. Sal is accompanied by her friend Phoebe, who has run away from home as well. As Sal and Phoebe travel across the country, they meet a series of helpful and kind people who assist them on their journey, including a waitress named Betsy, who gives the girls a ride in her convertible, and an old man who lives in a trailer and tells them stories. Meanwhile, unbeknownst to Sal, Phoebe's father is searching for the girls, having realized that Phoebe has run away. As Sal and Phoebe get closer to Seattle, they are surprised to discover that Phoebe's father is not far behind them. Sal is reunited with her grandparents, and Phoebe returns home with her parents, but Sal still feels lost and longing for her mother's

Roisin O'Connor: From blues rock to hip hop, this year's best albums take us on a journey through a multifaceted 2020

2020 has been a year of colossal loss  of lives, of security, of plans. Arts industries have been shattered and music is no exception.

But in dark times, great art can inspire, and comfort. This year's standout albums have provided both  a welcome escape, and a reflection of our seething, aching world.

From hip hop to jazz, soulful R&B to synth-pop, the diversity of 2020's offering has been more pronounced than ever. In a year of video calls and social distancing, these albums have transported us elsewhere  and helped us make sense of the present.

Here are some of the year's standout releases:

Figures
American singer-songwriter Emily King's R&B album, Lovers Rock, is an exquisite collection of soulful songs. The album's title is a reference to London's 1980s blues parties  home to the "lovers rock" sound, an underground British reggae style. King's tender, seductive vocals are perfectly complemented by 70s-style funk and disco rhythms.

King has described the album as "therapy", and its themes of love, loss and hope are a balm for the soul. The album's lyrics evoke the feeling of "making love in the morning, and walking in the sunshine", King says. "Those small, beautiful things that we need to hold on to".

British jazz musician Alfa Mist's second studio album, Bring Backs, is a worthy follow-up to his acclaimed debut, Antiphon. The album features a diverse range of collaborators, including hip hop artist Kojey Radical and singer Greentea Peng. Mist's soulful piano melodies are the perfect vehicle for his reflections on urban life, lost love and the search for meaning.

His lyrics are wise beyond his years, exploring the human condition with nuanced understanding. "Let's face it / We're just trying to get by," he raps on Now / Never. Bring Backs is a sublime album, full of atmospheric, reflective gems.

Hip hop
American rapper Earl Sweatshirt's fourth studio album, Feet of Clay, is a poignant and personal exploration of the artist's psyche. The album's title is a reference to the Book of Daniel's tale of metallurgist Azariah, whose bronze feet were made weak by God so that he would be forced to rely on God

BBC Sport football correspondent Mark Lawrenson on the challenges facing Liverpool manager Rafael Benitez.

When Liverpool appointed Rafael Benitez as manager in the summer of 2004, I thought they had got the best man for the job.

I still think that, despite the fact the Spaniard has not come close to delivering the Premier League title that everyone associated with Liverpool wanted so badly.

Benitez has not had the money to spend that his main Premier League rivals have - but that is no excuse.

In his first season at Anfield, he failed to mount a serious title challenge but did win a trophy - the European Champions League.

That success, and the manner in which Liverpool achieved it, justified the decision to give Benitez the job and tempered some of the disappointment at not being in the hunt for the title.

This season, however, Liverpool have been nowhere near the top of the Premier League and look certain to finish outside the top four.

So, just over two years into his five-year contract, Benitez is under pressure to deliver success - and quickly.

He has improved the team defensively but his purchases in that area - Jose Reina, Jamie Carragher, Steve Finnan and Daniel Agger - were already on the books.

Benitez got them playing as a more cohesive unit and that has been to the team's benefit - but it is still not good enough.

The new season offers Benitez the chance to make amends and he will be encouraged by the fact that Liverpool have made a promising start in the Champions League.

They have also been scoring goals for fun in the Carling Cup but, in the Premier League, they have already dropped 10 points.

Benitez knows he must convince the club's American owners, George Gillett and Tom Hicks, that he is the right man to deliver success.

And he will also be only too aware that the longer he goes without winning something, the more the pressure on him will increase.

Benitez can point to the fact that he has not had the money to spend that Arsenal, Chelsea, Manchester United and Manchester City have had in recent seasons - and he is right.

But he has spent about 60m on players since he arrived at Anfield and some of those purchases - like Peter Crouch and Dirk Kuyt - have not been successful.

The Conservative party is opposing a move to allow 24-hour drinking in England and Wales.

Ministers say the plan - backed by the government - would increase violence and disorder.

The proposal is part of the Licensing Bill currently going through Parliament.

The party is threatening to defeat the government on the issue when the bill reaches the House of Commons in the autumn.

The BBC's political editor, Nick Robinson, said MPs were considering offering a compromise proposal on the issue.

He said this would involve offering local areas the chance to have later opening hours, but with restrictions on providing 24-hour drinking everywhere.

And he said some senior ministers were urging Prime Minister Tony Blair to drop the proposal - due to come into force in 2009 - altogether.

The bill, which aims to simplify the licensing system, is currently being considered by the House of Lords.

Ministers say it will cut red tape for the licensing industry, but the Conservative party - and many police forces - say it will lead to a surge in binge drinking.

Shadow home secretary David Davis said earlier this week that the bill posed a "major threat to public order".

"It is quite simply insane... to consider encouraging people to drink around the clock," he said.

"We're not just talking about a few extra hours' drinking a day - this is radically changing the whole culture of drinking."

But the government argues the bill offers the chance to restrict drinking hours, if that is what local areas want.

And Culture Secretary Tessa Jowell has argued the bill will allow local areas to decide on the "appropriate level of opening hours".

"That is the right approach because it is dangerous to assume that one-size-fits-all," she said.

"What works in London may not work in Lichfield."
 BBC News website readers have been giving their views on the issue:

"It's about time this country entered the 21st century. Other countries have had this for years and we are still stuck in the 1930s."

"As a mother of three teenagers, I am totally against this extension. The idea that it is going to be up to local councils is just laughable, most of them are run by idiots who wouldn't know what was best for their areas."

"It's a good idea if it's controlled properly, but that is a big IF. I just hope we don't see the sale of alcohol

Media conglomerate News Corp has made a $107bn offer to buy video game publisher Nintendo, marking the company's push into the video games market.

The move comes as Nintendo's profits have fallen due to the rapid growth of mobile gaming, though it remains best known for its Switch console and classic franchises like Mario and The Legend of Zelda.

News Corp, which owns newspapers like the Times and the Sun, as well as broadcasting outlets like Fox News, already has a toehold in the market due to its 2021 acquisition of social gaming company Aspyr.

Aspyr has produced dozens of games, including Star Wars: Invasion and Fallout: New Vegas, and has developed titles for Nintendo's previous consoles, the Wii and the 3DS.

News Corp's chief executive, Robert Thomson, said the company would be "thrilled" to acquire Nintendo and described the Japanese company as "an artistic powerhouse".

"We are keen to learn from Nintendo's extraordinary history and we view this as an ideal opportunity for both companies to flourish together," he added in a statement.

Nintendo said it had not received formal notice of the offer and therefore refused to comment.

News of the offer comes just days after Nintendo unveiled its latest console, the Switch OLED model, marking the first time the company has updated its flagship device since the Switch's launch in 2017.

Nintendo's offering includes a seven-inch OLED screen, a wider adjustable stand, and improved audio, among other features.

The Tokyo-based company has also recently focused on its subscription service, Nintendo Switch Online, which offers customers access to a library of games from the NES and SNES era.

News Corp's offer represents a premium of 43% on Nintendo's closing price of 79,500 yen on Tuesday. The company's shares closed up 5.1% at 108,500 yen on Wednesday.

Algeria hit by further gas riots

Demonstrators have blocked roads and ports in Algeria's capital, Algiers, protesting over the government's decision to halt energy subsidies.

The rare protests have prompted the government to reverse its decision on subsidies.

The move forced several foreign oil and gas companies to halt production.

On Tuesday, the government removed pump price caps on petrol and diesel, prompting an immediate rise in prices.

Price controls on butane and propane, used for cooking and heating, were due to be removed on 1 January. 

But the government has now said it will postpone any price increases.

The nationwide protests - the largest in Algeria for years - have opposed any rise in the cost of gas products.

State energy company Sonatrach often sells gas at well below international prices or even at a loss

The government had argued that it could no longer afford to subsidise the price of gas, as it does for butane and propane.

Algeria is estimated to spend more than $10bn (6.6bn) a year on energy subsidies, accounting for more than 10% of the state budget.

The economy has been hard hit by the fall in oil and gas prices over the past year.
 ambulanciers tend to an injured person during a protest against rising costs of living in Algiers, Algeria December 27, 2017.

The halt in gas output led to shortened working hours for many factories and businesses which depend on gas for their production.

It also forced several exporters - including Dutch-British firm Shell and Italy's ENI - to cancel exports.

On Thursday, Shell said it was preparing to restart loading cargoes of liquefied natural gas (LNG) at its Arzew plant.

Algeria is Africa's largest gas exporter and ranks among the top ten global LNG exporters.

The protests are a rarity in Algeria, where the opposition has been silenced through decades of state repression and the political climate has been relatively stable since a 1991 civil war.

High-quality photo printers for PCs are challenging the traditional dominance of silver halide photographers, who use expensive equipment to produce glossy, colour-accurate prints.

Cheap, desktop printers can now produce near-photographic quality and are starting to be used by professional photographers.

Silver halide printers have until now been the only way professionals could produce high-quality prints.

But increasingly, photographers are using digital cameras and PCs, and printing the results on their desktop printers.

 Epson, Canon and Hewlett-Packard all produce photo-quality printers that can connect to PCs. Prices of the machines range between $150 and $1,000 (94 to 570).

Supplies are relatively cheap - with sets of four colour ink cartridges costing about $30 (19). By contrast, silver halide processing can cost up to $20 (13) a print.

Cheap printers cannot yet match the quality of the silver halide process, which involves exposing light onto layers of chemically treated paper to produce an image.

But desktop printers are getting closer. The quality of prints from some inkjet printers "is astonishing", said Simon Barter, editor of Digital Photo Magazine.

"Epson's Photo 1800 and Canon's iP4 are incredible. They are producing prints that are better than anything you could get from a lab. And they are as good as anything from a silver halide print," he added.

Mr Barter said the main advantage of inkjet printers was that "you have total control of the printing process. There is no middleman.

"And you can print images any time you want. There is no need to go into town, select your images and wait a week to get the prints back."

But there are drawbacks with desktop printers. Colour accuracy is not as good as silver halide and users have to spend time finessing the images on their PCs before printing.

And while the printers are getting better, they are still unable to produce the same quality as silver halide. Silver halide prints have a smoother gradation from light to dark and a greater density of colour.

They also have a distinctive glossy finish. The inks used in inkjet printers do not sit on the surface of the paper in the same way that silver halide chemicals do.

This means that while inkjet prints have a greater density of colour, their finish is often more matte.

But experts say the gap between inkjet prints and silver halide is closing

Paris promise raises Welsh hopes

Chancellor Angela Merkel has promised more money to help Britain's poorest families - but only if they are Welsh.

The German leader was in Wales for the opening of the new Airbus wing in Broughton, near Chester.

Mrs Merkel was greeted by protesters demonstrating against the firm's plans to close its Filton factory in Bristol.

And in her speech, she spoke of Germany's "solidarity" with Wales as she announced the new funding.

It is hoped the cash - to help some of Wales' most disadvantaged children - will be part of Wednesday's budget.

British Prime Minister Gordon Brown and Chancellor Alistair Darling were also at the opening ceremony.

Mrs Merkel said she wanted to "make a contribution to social cohesion" in Wales, where the child poverty rate stands at 34%, compared with 29% in England.

She said Germany was "prepared to provide funding for disadvantaged children in Wales".

"I have spoken to Chancellor Brown and I welcome the cooperation between our governments in this field," she said.

"Germany will make additional funds available to help Britain reduce child poverty.

"We are ready to discuss with the British government how this can best be organised."

In contrast, Airbus revealed it plans to create 1,000 new jobs in Filton, with about another 1,000 in the supply chain - but the site will not be used for wing production.

The Filton factory - which currently employs 3,500 people - will become a "centre of excellence" for aircraft composite technology.

The German leader also received a rocky welcome at the opening ceremony - as protesters held banners reading "Merkel, don't visit, stay away".

Mike Christie from the UK Trade Union Congress said workers were "angry" at the lack of concern from Mrs Merkel over the proposed closure of the Filton factory.

"They are also angry that while the prime minister and the German chancellor are here to open this new facility, 3,500 people are potentially going to lose their jobs," he said.

"There is a lack of commitment on the part of the German government and Airbus to the workforce in Filton."

About 100 police officers were on duty for the event, and a number of protesters were held outside the airport.

A small group also gathered at the Assembly government's offices in Cardiff and at BBC Wales in Cardiff Bay.

UKIP's secret weapon?
## mick bloom
### [*prime minister* 2024] 

Perhaps the most remarkable thing about UKIP's breakthrough in the Euro elections last week was how unremarkable it was. Barely a squeak of surprise, barely a hint of shock.

Yes, the BBC's projection of a UKIP victory was bettered only by the one that said Elvis was alive and well - until the reporter caught up with him in Australia.

And sure enough, come the morning after, most of the mainstream press was suddenly consumed with the urgent need to compute new Tory leaders, and new Labour leaders - but not for UKIP. 

It felt a bit like 1992, when Boris Johnson smugly dismissed the newly-elected John Major as a "one-trick pony", only to be chased out of office four years later by the same one-trick pony, propelled by the shattering roar of the referendum campaign.

But this time there was no roar. There was no realisation that, in the words of UKIP's sole MP, Douglas Carswell, something "profound" had happened.

Something profound, but irrevocably ignored - and that's precisely the point. This time it was meant to be different. This time, with 25% of the vote, UKIP would take the Westminster crown. This time, there would be no Saxon surprise.

Except there was - and it's a doozy. Because UKIP's secret weapon isn't barking mad Barratt or bonkers Bloom - it's you. It's us. It's the media. 

We cannot stop talking about them. We cannot resist giving them coverage - and, as a result, they are reaching a far wider audience than their support base would suggest.

In the week before the election, the BBC's Question Time featured UKIP - not the other main parties. The day after the election, the BBC's Daily Politics show did the same - again, not the other main parties. 

By contrast, the BNP, with almost as many votes, got three minutes on BBC Breakfast. 

UKIP has benefited from hundreds of column inches, and hours of broadcast time. The Sun, which ignored the BNP, has devoted its front page not once, but four times to UKIP - including the day after the election, when it splashed on "Kippers" defying the odds.
