Star Wars Battlefront 2 review

It's the game Star Wars fans have been waiting for, but that doesn't mean it's perfect.

Star Wars Battlefront 2 has plenty of bugs and some confusing design decisions, but if you can look past those there's plenty here to love.

It's taken three years and a change of developer, but we finally have a proper successor to the original Star Wars Battlefront games.

They're online multiplayer shooters, but with a Star Wars skin.

The original Battlefront games were essentially Battlefield games in disguise, and that's still true here.

The highlight is definitely the multiplayer modes - preferably played with a friend.

The meat of the multiplayer is made up of three different modes - Galactic Assault, Starfighter Assault and Strike.

They're basically your standard team deathmatch, vehicle deathmatch and conquest modes, but with a Star Wars skin.

They're simple, but still pretty exhilarating, especially when playing as or against iconic Star Wars characters and vehicles.

The controls are fairly simple, but it takes a while to get used to the floaty cover system.

The lack of a proper single player campaign is still pretty baffling though, and the one included here doesn't even come close to filling that void.

The campaign is a series of battles against the Empire, essentially a prolonged tutorial.

It's not particularly engaging, but at least it's short - lasting around two hours.

Battlefront 2 has some frustrating design decisions, but it has heart.

It looks gorgeous, and sounds amazing, but a lack of content and some baffling design decisions hold it back.

The original Battlefront games had a seemingly endless number of modes, but this one feels sparse in comparison.

The lack of a single player campaign is also confusing, especially when the one included here is so lacklustre.

But if you can look past those issues there's still a lot of fun to be had - especially when playing as a Jedi.

Star Wars Battlefront 2 was released on November 17 for PS4, Xbox One and PC.

Our review is based on the PS4 version.

Game description

Star Wars Battlefront 2 is an action game played from either a first-person or third-person perspective. The game, inspired by the Star Wars franchise, is designed primarily as a multiplayer game, but also includes a single-player story mode

Textile jobs: Millions 'to lose jobs' 

The UK textile industry could lose almost 400,000 jobs in the next decade, an industry body has warned.

The Textile Institute said jobs would go because of rising energy prices, competition from India and China, and the cheap availability of textiles on the internet.

It wants the government to provide more support for the industry.

The institute's Russellislife Hall said there was a danger that the UK would end up simply being a designer of textiles, with the actual making of fabrics taken over by abroad.

Textiles are the UK's largest manufacturing industry, with 73,000 directly employed in the sector and a further 135,000 in related industries.

But the Textile Institute, which commissioned the Nomis consultancy to carry out the study into the future of the sector, believes that by 2012, the number of directly employed will have fallen to 47,000, with an additional 77,000 in related industries.

This suggests that 350,000 jobs could go, although the Textile Institute admits it is difficult to be precise because the figures are based on trends and there is a certain amount of uncertainty involved.

'Potent combination'

"There is a potent combination of factors [that threaten jobs]," Mr Hall said.

"It is the rise of energy prices, the internet - which has dramatically changed the retail landscape - and most importantly the massive increase in capacity in China and India.

"While the markets in the US and Europe have been fairly stable, the growth markets of China and India represent a significant threat to the UK textile industry as their disposable incomes rise and their demand for textiles increases."

The study also found that the average age of those employed in the industry was increasing, with a quarter of the workforce due to retire in the next 10 years.

This will create a skills gap, it said.

The Textile Institute is now calling on the government to do more to support the industry, including greater funding for training and help in combating rising energy prices.

World Trade Organization (WTO) negotiators met in Geneva on 13-15 June for the first in a series of meetings to try to finalize the details of an intellectual property (IP) waiver for COVID-19 vaccines.

But despite a new pledge by Switzerland to donate vaccines to low-income countries, no further agreements were reached.

 WTO members are trying to finalize texts on a proposal first made by India and South Africa in October 2020 to waive IP rights for COVID-19 vaccines and treatments.

United States President Joe Biden had previously backed the idea but Western pharmaceutical companies and EU nations have opposed it.

India's Ambassador to the WTO, Brajendra Navnit, told negotiators it was important to conclude talks on the waiver "in a timely manner".

"Given the scope, coverage and duration of the proposal, it represents a meaningful opportunity to address the pandemic and save lives," he said.

India and South Africa have argued that IP rights have created barriers to increasing the production of vaccines and other tools needed to fight the pandemic.

If agreed, the waiver would be the first ever of its kind under the WTO's Agreement on Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property (Trips).

But talks have stalled, with a group of more than a dozen countries, including the UK, Switzerland and the European Union, opposing the plan.

The World Health Organization (WHO) estimates that around 80% of the population in richer countries has received at least one vaccine dose, but this drops to around 15% in low-income countries.

Ambassadors from the WTO's 164 member states met in Geneva last month but failed to reach an agreement.

They are due to meet again on 29 June, with a final round of talks scheduled for 6-7 July.

India's role in the WTO talks is crucial as it is a major vaccine manufacturer.

It has produced more than 600 million doses of the AstraZeneca vaccine, widely used in the UK, and more than 110 million doses of the Covaxin vaccine, developed by Indian company Bharat Biotech.

Dr Soumya Swaminathan, the chief scientist at the WHO, said she hoped that India's strong role in the WTO talks would help find a solution.

The UK government should increase its support for manufacturing, or risk losing jobs to Europe, an industry group is warning.

The Manufacturing Technologies Association (MTA) said a "perfect storm" of factors meant investment in the sector was needed.

It said high energy prices, increased labour and raw material costs and a shortage of skilled engineers were combining to create a crisis.

The MTA, which represents 400 firms in the sector, said one-third of those firms were considering moving some operations abroad.

The call for action comes in the same week that car maker Nissan announced it was turning its UK plant into an electric vehicle (EV) hub.

It also comes ahead of the government's ongoing review of business rates, a tax paid on non-residential properties, which have added to the pressures facing firms.

The MTA's call was backed by engineering companies, including Siemens and Rolls-Royce.

 MTA chief executive James Selka said: "There is a perfect storm of problems impacting on the sector.

"High energy prices are making it extremely difficult for manufacturers to invest in increasing output in the UK, whilst increased labour and raw material costs are causing a crisis in the supply chain as suppliers are finding it difficult to absorb these costs and pass them on."

He added that a shortage of skilled engineers and a lack of investment in technology was "stopping our members from taking on new work and increasingly they are considering moving operations abroad".

"This is a very real concern that needs addressing urgently by the government," he added.

A government spokesperson said: "We are taking decisive action to support British manufacturers during these global price surges, including introducing a 5bn Energy Bill Relief Scheme that offers discounts on energy bills for eligible firms, and a 1bn programme to help businesses improve their energy efficiency.

"We are supporting firms with skills development and have recently expanded the eligibility for the annual investment allowance to help businesses invest in plant and machinery this year."

Microsoft is urging computer users to patch a security vulnerability that could allow hackers to spread malicious software through infected emails.

The US computing giant released a software fix for the problem on Tuesday.

It said a malicious "trojan horse" could be hidden inside email attachments, or sent via links to malicious websites.

Once infected, the trojan could download further malicious code without the user's knowledge.

The software giant said the vulnerability affected users of its older Windows XP operating system, as well as those using its newer Windows Vista and Windows 7 platforms.

Microsoft often releases security and other updates on what it calls "patch Tuesday".

This month's security update also covers vulnerabilities in Microsoft's ubiquitous web browser, Internet Explorer.

India has thrown open its skies to foreign airlines, breaking the dominance of the country's state-run airline, Air India.

The move is expected to usher in cheaper air fares on some routes.

India's Minister for Civil Aviation, Praful Patel, said it was a "historic" decision.

Foreign airlines can now invest up to 49% in Indian carriers.

And they will be able to operate any number of flights to and from India, as long as they have permission from the respective governments.

Only two US airlines - Delta and American Airlines - currently fly to India.

Mr Patel said the decision would increase competition and bring down fares.

Currently, Air India has a near-monopoly on flights between India and the US, operating seven flights a week between New Delhi and New York.

But now, foreign airlines will be able to fly directly to India, without having to take permission from Air India.

However, the decision to allow foreign airlines to invest up to 49% in Indian carriers has been postponed until later this year.

Air India has been struggling to compete with private airlines and had to be bailed out by the government earlier this year.

The government has said it wants to sell a stake in the loss-making airline, but the political opposition has said it would rather see the airline privatised.

France has switched on its first digital television transmitter as part of a plan to improve broadcasting.

The transmitter at Tourves in the south of France was switched on at 09:00 local time (08:00 GMT) on Friday.

France's four existing TV networks will be broadcast digitally, alongside new free and pay-TV services.

Digital television requires a set top box to work, but TV sets with built-in digital receivers are also available.

The government expects half of all French households to have digital television by 2007.

Digital TV will offer better picture and sound quality than existing analogue signals and there will be more channels available, many of them in high definition.

It will also free up space for other uses, such as mobile phones and emergency services, because different signals can be used for different purposes.

France is one of the last European countries to adopt the new system

The UK completed its digital switchover in October 2012 and Spain finished earlier this year.

Italy has also started its switchover, while Germany and the Netherlands plan to complete theirs by 2022.

IBM has announced that it is to spend $1bn on developing its cloud and AI services.

The company said it would expand its global cloud data centre footprint to meet client demand for off-premises computing.

The centrepiece of its strategy is Linux, the open-source operating system, which will underpin its cloud offerings.

Notably, IBM will also increase its commitment to hybrid cloud, which enables customers to move data between their own data centres and cloud-based storage.

"Hybrid cloud is the dominant architecture of the future, and IBM is firmly positioned as the leading provider of hybrid cloud solutions and services to our clients," said IBM chief executive, Arvind Krishna.

"Linux is the glue that holds it all together," he added.

IBM's Linux push comes after it acquired Red Hat, a leading provider of enterprise open-source software, for $34bn last year.

The company said Linux would provide the "open architecture" that is needed to help its clients operate in multi-cloud environments.

Multi-cloud is the use of multiple cloud computing services in a single network.

IBM said it is currently the leading hybrid cloud provider and that its strategy had created a "clear and distinct competitive advantage" with revenue growing by 20% in the first quarter of this year.

"We are pioneering the hybrid cloud marketplace by enabling our clients to run their mission-critical workloads across their own data centres, public clouds and third-party data centres," said IBM's senior vice-president for global sales, John Teltsch.

"No other cloud provider has this capability," he added.

Senior US and Russian trade officials have held "constructive" talks on Moscow's wish to join the WTO, officials say.

Russia's entry to the World Trade Organization (WTO) has been blocked for years by Georgia and other ex-Soviet states.

But US Trade Representative Susan Schwab and Russian Economic Development and Trade Minister German Gref said they had made progress in clearing obstacles to Russia's entry.

"We exchanged specific ideas about the remaining issues that must be resolved," Ms Schwab said in a statement after the meeting in Washington.

"We agreed that the two sides would continue to work towards resolving these issues so that Russia can join the WTO," she added.

Mr Gref said: "We made progress in clearing obstacles remaining in the way of Russia's accession to the WTO."

The Russian minister said one of the issues that still needed to be tackled was the "transparency" of Russia's laws on intellectual property.

Ms Schwab said she planned to visit Russia in April to continue the talks.

Russia has been trying to join the WTO since 1996, and US backing for its membership bid has been a key factor in the negotiations.

But Washington has become increasingly frustrated with Russia's lack of progress in adopting reforms to its trade policies, and there were reports last year that the US might withdraw its support for Russia's membership.

US President George W Bush and Russian President Vladimir Putin discussed the issue at a summit in Bratislava last year, and agreed to intensify efforts to try to resolve the remaining obstacles.

Given the recent deterioration in Russia's relations with Georgia, and the ongoing tensions between Moscow and ex-Soviet states, it appears unlikely that they will continue to stand in the way of Russia's WTO membership.

The Liberal Democrats have unveiled their election slogan - "stop the SNP".

Party leader Willie Rennie said it was a message "that makes the difference" between his party and the SNP and Labour.

The SNP said the Lib Dems were "desperate" to form a coalition with the Tories.

Mr Rennie launched the slogan in Edinburgh at the start of a week-long tour of Scotland ahead of the general election in May.

He will use the trip to set out his "positive plan to stop the SNP's push for another independence referendum".

"The choice at this election is clearer than ever before - we can have a positive, ambitious plan for the whole of the United Kingdom, or we can split the country apart," he said.

"The Liberal Democrats offer an optimistic, positive vision for the whole of the UK, whereas the SNP just want to separate our country and take Scotland back to the days of higher taxes, fewer jobs and less money for public services."

Mr Rennie accused Labour of being "wedded to another divisive referendum" and said the Lib Dems were the only party standing up for the whole of the UK.

He said his message to voters in Scotland was clear - "stop the SNP".

"It's a message that makes the difference between the Liberal Democrats and Labour and the SNP because we are the party of positive opposition to the SNP and we are standing up for the United Kingdom," he added.

But SNP deputy leader Keith Brown said the Lib Dems were "clearly desperate to form a coalition with the Tories".

"It seems they have finally realised you can't trust the SNP with the future of our country, but they still think you can trust the Tories," he said.

"The truth is that the only way to stop the Tories is to vote SNP - clearly the Lib Dems are trying to cover up their own failings by pretending to be the answer to the SNP.

"But the people of Scotland won't be fooled by this desperate attempt at rebranding."

Mr Brown added that the SNP was the only "serious" opposition to another Tory government and that Labour was "wedded to another divisive referendum".

What do you think of the slogan?

A BBC poll suggests the SNP is on course to win a majority of Scottish seats at Westminster - something the party has predicted for months.

The survey put support for the SNP at 49%, with the Conservatives

Could Yukos be a blessing in disguise?

For the last few years Russia's biggest oil company has been fighting for its life. Yukos Oil Company is up to its neck in debt and last year saw its production slump to a 17-year low. Now it has been hit with a massive tax bill which could ultimately send it bankrupt. But some analysts think this could be a blessing in disguise, allowing the company to streamline its operations and come out fighting. It has already announced plans to sell off its petrol station network. And on Wednesday its chief executive, Aleksandr Dyukov, said the company was planning to tap its shareholders for as much as $8bn dollars as part of a restructuring plan. He said the company would sell new shares and cut its massive debt by half. But analysts say the company also needs to sell more of its key assets in order to survive. "Yukos is losing its market position and must quickly sell non-core assets, and increase production and efficiency," said Andrei Kramarenko, an analyst with Renaissance Capital. "Otherwise it will disappear."

The company has already signed a deal to sell its Nova television station and some property in Moscow. But it could also be forced to sell its main production unit, Yukos Arktic, as well as its shares in the Siberian Light Oil Company and some refineries. "All these assets are going to be sold. The question is when and at what price," said Mr Kramarenko. But he said the sale of Yukos's petrol station network would not be enough on its own to help the company out of its difficulties. "It's nothing special, it's a typical market price, nothing extraordinary."

Yukos has been hit by a series of tax claims which have helped to push the company into debt. The tax authorities say the company owes them $3.3bn dollars, a figure Yukos says is far too high. But earlier this month a court in Moscow ordered the company to pay $315m dollars of the claim, and the tax authorities have said they will not rule out bankruptcy proceedings against the company. The authorities have also put Yukos's main production unit up for auction in order to help pay the tax bill. Yukos says this is illegal and has appealed to Russia's highest court.

But analysts say the battle with the tax authorities is also helping to strengthen Yukos's hand against its rivals. "The tax case is bad for Yukos but good for shareholders because it makes the

Council tax rises in England billed as "reasonable" have been approved, with many authorities freezing fares for motorists. The averages rises for bands A to D in England are below what was forecast a year ago. Authorities in England have approved the rises, with averages ranging from 50 to 70. The increases are usually introduced in April. Council bosses say the hikes are needed to protect vital services from the impact of government grant cuts. And Labour says the Conservative government has cut council funding by half over the last decade. The Local Government Association, which represents councils, said extra funding raised by the rises could be as much as 1.9bn.

Manchester, the country's largest council by population, has approved a 9.5% rise, which equates to an extra 74 a year for a band D property. Mayor of Greater Manchester Andy Burnham said the rise was "difficult but necessary". He said: "There is no easy way to introduce a council tax rise, but these are difficult financial times and hard choices have to be made." The authority has had its government funding cut by 60m. It comes as the city's bus network is being completely overhauled with new simplified routes and 1.2bn investment.

 Elsewhere, Tory-run Westminster City Council has become the latest local authority to freeze fares for motorists. It joins others including Portsmouth, Southampton and Marlow which have also chosen not to increase fees. The Local Government Association (LGA) has welcomed the "modest increases". LGA chairman Clive Betts said the rises would help protect services. He added: "Councils have worked hard to keep increases down as much as possible to protect local services."

China will overtake the US in the next few years as the biggest user of the internet, a research company says.

By 2016, more than half a billion people in China will be online, compared with 315 million in the US, says research firm eMarketer.

The number of people online in China has been accelerating, said analyst Douglas Clark.

"The US is still the world's largest internet market, but China is the second-largest and is rapidly closing the gap," he said.

"The sheer magnitude of China's online population surpasses any other country in the world, and it shows no signs of slowing down."

The number of internet users in China will jump nearly 7% this year to 495 million, eMarketer said.

The US figure is expected to grow by 3% to 315 million.

However, the US still has more individuals who regularly go online - the so-called "active internet user" population.

Some 255 million Americans are considered active internet users, compared with 179 million in China, eMarketer said.

The research company based its figures on estimates of internet usage and population in each country.

China's internet growth does not only surpass that of the US, it is also closing the gap in broadband penetration, Mr Clark said.

By the end of 2012, more than half of all Chinese residents will have broadband, while in the US the penetration rate is much higher, at more than 75%.

"China's 'internet plus' strategy, which includes strengthening the country's wireless infrastructure, could potentially result in a surge of mobile devices and internet users in the next year," Mr Clark said.

Can Yahoo dominate next decade? 

Yahoo has unveiled plans to create a blockchain-based platform for encrypted email and cryptocurrency-based rewards.

The firm has filed a patent application in the US for a system that could encode emails to help prevent prying eyes from reading them.

The application also suggests users might be rewarded with cryptocurrency for using the service.

Yahoo already offers 1,000 Yahoo Coins for signing up for a Yahoo account, and filing the application shows the company continues to explore blockchain technology. 

The patent application outlines a system in which a blockchain would be used to encrypt and store email messages, with a cryptographic key held by the sender and recipient.

This would prevent the contents of emails from being revealed to anyone other than the intended recipients.

"Some embodiments may incentivise the use of the email platform," the application reads.

"For example, the email platform may reward users with a cryptocurrency for using the platform."

It goes on to explain that users might be rewarded for actions including "transmitting an email", "receiving an email", or "reading an email".

Yahoo CEO Marissa Mayer said during an investors' call in February that the company was "continuing to invest in blockchain", according to CNET.

Decentralised blockchain-based systems are commonly associated with the cryptocurrency Bitcoin.

But the technology has many other potential applications including the verification of transactions and the storage of data.

Yahoo is not the only major tech firm to have explored blockchain technology.

Microsoft launched a blockchain-as-a-service offering earlier this month, and Amazon introduced a similar service in November.

MANCHESTER UNITED cruised into the semi-finals of the League Cup with a comfortable victory over Nottingham Forest at Old Trafford.

First-half goals from Antony and Marcus Rashford and a late third from substitute Fred sealed United's victory and set up a last-four meeting with Nottingham Forest's East Midlands rivals Leicester City.

United dominated throughout, but struggled to find a way past a resolute Forest defence for the first 25 minutes.

The visitors survived an early scare when Tyrell Malacia's cross was inches away from curling into the far corner, with Anthony Martial unable to get a touch on it.

Moments later, Forest's Jason Cummings headed a cross narrowly wide from the left, but that was as close as the visitors came to scoring.

United took the lead a minute before the half-hour mark when Rashford cut the ball back for Antony, who produced a clinical finish to find the far corner from 18 yards.

And the hosts doubled their lead five minutes later when Rashford produced a fine finish from 10 yards out following a defensive mix-up.

Forest's best chance to get back into the game came five minutes into the second half when Cummings was played through on goal, but the forward's chip was too weak and easily saved by David de Gea.

United put the game beyond doubt with four minutes left when substitute Fred scored with a first-time finish from 20 yards out following a lay-off from another substitute, Jesse Lingard.

United could have added a fourth in the final moments, but Rashford's effort was too close to Forest goalkeeper Wayne Hennessey, who made the save.

Asian banks have helped the dollar recover from its worst sell-off in weeks as worries about the US economic outlook pushed investors towards the relative safety of the world's primary reserve currency.

The dollar had skidded to an almost three-year low against a basket of currencies following the Federal Reserve's dovish shift last week.

But it has since bounced back more than 1.2% ahead of the Fed's policy meeting on Tuesday, where policymakers are expected to signal that they will raise interest rates in September.

"The dollar's recovery this week has been more pronounced in Asia, where the banks seem to have played a key role," said Mazen Issa, senior foreign exchange strategist at TD Securities.

"This could be attributed to month-end or quarter-end rebalancing flows, but the magnitude of the move suggests spot dollar-selling from regional banks," he added.

The dollar's rebound began in Asia on Tuesday last week, when the Korean won fell more than 1% and the Singapore dollar hit a one-year low.

The won recovered from its lows after the country's central bank intervened in the foreign exchange market, while the dollar also rose against the Singapore dollar.

Asian currencies have been among the best performers so far this year thanks to the region's economic recovery from the Covid pandemic and attractive yields.

But the dollar's rebound this week has swept across the board, with the exception of the New Zealand dollar, as markets bet that the Fed will hike rates twice before the end of the year.

On Monday, the dollar hit a one-month high against the euro, with the single currency also hit by a dovish stance taken by the European Central Bank.

"We expect the dollar recovery to extend in the near term," said Carol Kong, a currency strategist at Commonwealth Bank of Australia (CBA).

"The Fed is expected to reiterate its commitment to raising rates this year and slowing the pace of balance sheet runoff, which should help support the dollar," she added.

The International Association of Athletics Federations (IAAF) has announced that it will contest the decision by Greek authorities to revoke the suspension of Olympic pole vault champion Kostadinos Poullain.

The IAAF said in a statement that it had "initiated comprehensive and procedural legal action against the Hellenic Athletics Federation (SEGNA) and Kostadinos Poullain in the Athens Court of Arbitration for Sport".

It added that "the decision of the Greek Court of First Instance does not affect the status of the provisional suspension of Mr Poullain from the date of the ruling".

The 21-year-old, who won gold in Athens, had his provisional suspension from the IAAF - commencing on 29 August 2004, the day after the Olympic final - upheld by a Greek court last month.

But the country's athletics federation (SEGNA) then decided to revoke its own suspension of Poullain, who has always maintained that he used no performance-enhancing drugs.

The IAAF statement said that the Greek federation's decision "was taken in spite of, rather than because of, the decision of the Greek Court of First Instance".

The statement added: "Mr Poullain received several injections of a unauthorised (sic) medical substance just days after the Olympic Games, and he admitted the violation and accepted his sanction."

In January, the IAAF announced that Poullain had been banned from athletics for two years, starting from the day of his positive drugs test.

The sentence could be reduced to 21 months if the Greek athlete succeeds in his appeal against the Athens Olympic doping panel's decision.

Poullain returned home to a hero's welcome after his gold medal success and also received a special award from the Greek president.

The German jobless rate has hit a new record high, despite predictions it would fall, official data shows.

The adjusted unemployment rate rose to 12.1% in October, up from 11.7% in September, the Federal Statistics Office said.

The unadjusted rate - which includes people who work fewer hours than they would like - was 18.1%, up from 17.5% in September.

Many market analysts had predicted a fall in the jobless rate, noting that the adjusted measure - which is the headline figure - had recently been coming in below market expectations.

However, the statistical office said that this was because it had changed the way it calculated the rate, and that the rise in October should be seen as a correction.

"We don't take too seriously this rise... because of the methodological changes," said Juergen Michels, chief economist at Citigroup in Frankfurt.

"We think the labour market is still improving, and we expect the unemployment rate to fall below 12% early next year."

The statistics office said that the rise in the unadjusted rate was due to an increase in so-called "inactive people" in the 16-64 age group, many of whom were giving up looking for work.

Germany has been hit less hard by the global economic crisis than many other European countries, in part because of its strong export focus, but it has not been immune.

The German economy contracted by 5.7% in the second quarter of this year, compared with the same period last year, according to the Federal Statistics Office.

At the same time, unemployment has been rising, and economists say that the government's wage support schemes, which have kept people in work, have hidden the true extent of the problem.

Malaysia's securities commission has lifted a limit on the amount of equity that Islamic banks can hold in a single company.

The change is part of efforts to help Malaysia's Islamic finance industry grow and expand overseas.

For years, the country's two full-fledged Islamic banks have been restricted to holding a maximum of 15% of any company's shares.

That limit has now been removed for investment in firms related to Islamic activities.

And it has been raised to 30% for investment in firms not related to Islam.

The move is seen as a major boost for the Islamic finance industry, which has been growing rapidly in recent years.

It is expected to lead to more mergers and acquisitions as Islamic banks expand their operations.

The change was announced by Malaysia's Securities Commission on Monday.

It said the move would help Islamic banks "expand their investment banking activities, and enhance their role in the country's capital market".

Robots have been part of popular culture for decades. From mechanical men of steel to benevolent machines that care for humanity, visions of robots have always fascinated us. I, Robot, a new DVD release, presents a vision where robots are integrated into daily life. But this is no utopian future  these robots have flaws and can be used for malicious purposes.

The DVD explores the ethical implications of robotics and presents a thought-provoking vision of the future. It features interviews with experts in the field of robotics and artificial intelligence, as well as a discussion of the social and economic impact of robots.

This DVD is a must-watch for anyone interested in the future of robotics and the impact they will have on society. It is a thought-provoking and insightful look at the potential benefits and risks of a robotic future. Whether you're a robot enthusiast or just curious about the future, I, Robot is a great way to explore these topics.

Ireland have never beaten England in a fully-fledged men's Test but they have the chance to create history later.

The sides meet at the Aviva Stadium in Dublin on Sunday in the final game of their three-match summer series, with the tourists having won the first two matches.

A draw would be a fitting way to end an intriguing series but England will not lack motivation to complete a clean sweep.

History suggests it will not be an easy task. England have won just one of their past 10 Tests in Ireland - a 39-10 victory in Dublin in 2003 - and have lost their last four visits to the Aviva Stadium, including the memorable 2019 Six Nations game which saw Ireland win a Grand Slam and England's hopes of winning the title ended.

Ireland have also lost just one of their previous 13 home Tests - against New Zealand in November - and have won their last nine under coach Andy Farrell.

England have been boosted by the return to fitness of centre Ollie Lawrence and flanker Tom Curry, who have both recovered from injury, while Ireland have selected uncapped pair Michael Lowry and Nick McCarthy.

Lowry, who has impressed for Ulster in the United Cup this season, is selected at full-back in a much-changed squad which sees Billy Burns and Robbie Henshaw partnered in the centre.

McCarthy, who has been in fine form for Leinster, is included among the replacements alongside fellow uncapped players Craig Casey and Jeremy Loughman.

Ireland head coach Andy Farrell said: "This weekend is a special occasion for Michael and Nick. They have both had outstanding seasons and they deserve their opportunity.

"We have had our eyes on them for a while and monitored their progress. They will be excited and so they should be.

"It is a huge occasion for them and their families and I wish them both well."
England head coach Eddie Jones added: "We have had two good games and a drawn game would be a good result for both teams.

"Ireland have got their own reasons for wanting to win and so have we. There is a trophy today, the Series Cup, and that is up for grabs so it should be a good game."

Labour suspends councillor over pig poster.
A Labour councillor has been suspended by the party after a poster appearing to show a pig wearing a Jewish skullcap was displayed in his window.

The image appeared in the window of Michael Higgs, a councillor in the London borough of Harrow, on Saturday.

Labour said it was "anti-Semitic".

Mr Higgs, who is himself Jewish, has been a Labour member for more than 30 years.

He said the poster had been displayed by his wife, who he said had taken it from his bag before he could stop her.

He added that he was "deeply sorry" for the incident.

Labour MP John Mann said the image was "horrific" and should "never have been displayed".

He said he had spoken to Mr Higgs and asked him to remove the image, and said the councillor had "apologised deeply".

In a statement, Labour said: "We abhor anti-Semitism and have taken immediate action to suspend the party membership of Cllr Michael Higgs.

"Labour is fully committed to challenging anti-Semitism and racial discrimination in all its forms."

The Board of Deputies, which represents British Jews, described the image as "awful" and "offensive".

In a tweet, it said: "We are proud of our Jewish heritage. To see anti-Semitism expressed in this way is awful."

The organisation said it had been in contact with the Labour Party and Harrow Council.

Mr Higgs has been a Harrow councillor since 2010.

He is the husband of Harriet Harman, the Labour MP for Camberwell and Peckham who served as deputy Labour leader under previous leader Ed Miliband.

Berlin has honoured a South Korean director with a top cultural award for his contribution to fostering understanding and mutual respect between Europe and Asia.

Berlin-based Im Kwon Taek received the Goethe Medal on Tuesday for his "unwavering and passionate pursuit of cultural diversity and peace".

The medal is awarded annually by the German state to people who have actively promoted cultural understanding and exchange.

"In times of growing nationalistic and populist tendencies, Im Kwon Taek's work and life are more important than ever," the jury said.

The award-winning film-maker has lived in Germany for four decades and has made more than 60 films, including the 1986 epic Mandala, which was the first non-European movie to be nominated for an Academy Award in the best foreign language film category.

His other well-known films include the romantic drama Rosy Life, which won a Golden Bear - the top prize at the Berlin International Film Festival - in 2005, and the 2008 drama The Surrogate City.

Im Kwon Taek is the first film-maker to win the Goethe Medal since it was awarded to UK director Mike Leigh in 2010.

BBC News, Parliament's record of scandal - where will it end?

UK parliament's reputation "in tatters" after a string of scandals

From the exotic claims of Dominic Cummings to the very British farce of Owen Paterson, the past six months will have done little to enhance the reputation of Britain's Parliament.

Now, a report by a cross-party committee has warned that the "systematic failure" of MPs to tackle bullying and sexual harassment risks undermining public trust in politics.

It found evidence of "deep-seated resistance" to changing a culture that allows intimidation and fear to pervade Westminster.

And just as this report was being published, another allegation emerged - this time that a senior Conservative MP allegedly posted a racist tweet.

Boris Johnson's spokesman said the prime minister "completely disagreed" with the sentiment of the tweet, and that MP had been removed from his parliamentary committee.

So, is this just a case of a "few bad apples", as Mr Johnson has suggested, or a more widespread problem?

And - in the wake of the Paterson affair which saw 23 Conservative MPs break ranks to support a colleague facing a 30-day suspension for breaking the rules on paid lobbying - how representative are MPs of their constituents?

The BBC's political editor, Chris Mason, and deputy political editor, Vicki Young, take a look at Parliament's record over the past six months.

Virgin Radio is launching a digital radio service that allows listeners to hear live radio while accessing 3G internet services on their mobile phones.

The service, created by digital radio firm Digital One, uses the digital audio broadcasting (DAB) protocol to offer Virgin Radio's existing analogue radio broadcast and a "parallel" digital broadcast.

Mobile phone users can listen to the digital radio stream through headphones while accessing internet services.

The service will be available in London from June 17, with a national roll-out planned for later in the year.

Digital One's commercial director, Andrew Harrison, said: "This service marks an exciting new development for digital radio in this country."

"We are offering a digitally-led, compelling consumer service that offers an 'always on', unlimited listening experience," he added.

How it works

Digital radio sounds like analogue radio, but with CD-quality sound.

It is broadcast from transmitters that offer better coverage than existing FM and AM frequencies, because they use lower frequencies than analogue radio.

To receive the digital signal, listeners need a digital radio or a digital radio receiver, which can be a stand-alone product or incorporated into another device, such as a mobile phone or MP3 player.

Digital One, which is owned by News Corporation and Broadcasting Development Fund, plans to offer dozens of digital radio services, including BBC stations and offerings from commercial radio firms.

The company has already launched more than 20 digital radio services, including five BBC stations - BBC Radio 1, 2, 3, 4 and 5 Live.

Last month, Digital One struck a deal with Channel 4 to create a new digital radio station, called Channel 4 Radio, which will launch this summer.

The new station will be available on Digital One's DAB network, as well as via the internet and on digital television.

Is digital radio taking off?

More than 1.5 million digital radios have been sold in the UK, according to industry body, Digital Radio Development Bureau (DRDB).

It claims that over half the population has access to a digital radio, either through a digital radio device or another device with digital radio capabilities, such as a mobile phone or digital TV.

But some industry watchers are skeptical about the take-up of digital radio. They point out that digital television took 15 years to become mainstream, and suggest that digital radio is still in its infancy.

A spokesman for the stadium's owners, the Football Association, said it had always been clear that the business would run at a loss.

"The FA has said since the outset that it was always its intention that the Wembley Stadium Project would not be profit-generating, given the primary focus on restoring the national stadium to a world-class venue," he said.

"From the outset, the business plan made it clear the FA would invest profit back into football development and grassroots projects."

He said the FA was "very happy" with the way the stadium had performed in its first year.

Wembley Stadium Ltd (WSL), which operates the venue, made a loss of 57.2m in the year ending 31 March 2007, according to documents filed at Companies House.

The firm's turnover in the same period was 72.5m, with 38.2m revenue from football, and 34.3m from other events, such as music concerts.

 WSLL predicted in its business plan, filed with Companies House in October 2005, that it would make an operating loss of 49.5m in the first year.

It also predicted losses of 13.3m, 9.6m and 7m in the following three years.

The losses have led to speculation that the FA may look to sell the stadium, less than three years after it bought it for 757m from Wembley National Stadium Ltd.

Last week, The Times reported that the FA had approached its advisers, Deloitte, about selling the stadium.

The FA spokesman would not be drawn on the reports, saying only that the FA was "committed" to Wembley as the home of English football.

The battle between HD DVD and Blu-ray has been won by Blu-ray, with the announcement that several studios are going to start releasing films only on the Blu-ray disc.

The studios involved include some of the biggest global names - Disney, Fox, Sony and Warner Bros.

They said they would commence the exclusive shipments next year.

In a joint statement, the companies said that the move to sole Blu-ray distribution "better serves consumers" and reflected "how people want to watch movies at home".

The news is a major blow to HD DVD, which is backed by the likes of Intel and Microsoft.

The format war has been going on for nearly two years, ever since Hollywood studios decided to introduce a new, higher definition video disc format to replace the existing DVD.

Both Blu-ray and HD DVD offer better picture and sound quality than existing DVDs, but each incompatible format has its own storage capacity and additional features.

Many industry experts had predicted that consumers would eventually decide which format to buy, but the studios said on Tuesday that they wanted to "eliminate consumer confusion" and "avoid a prolonged format war".

Although it has won the battle, Blu-ray faces a new challenge, as it needs to convince people to replace their existing DVD collections with the new format.

Industry figures suggest that more than 100 million US households currently own a DVD player, compared with just 10 million for Blu-ray.

Microsoft has yet to respond to the news, but last month it slashed the price of its HD DVD player, the Xbox 360 HD DVD Add-on, to $49 from $179.

The BBC's North America technology correspondent, Leo Kelion, said Blu-ray's victory was not a complete surprise.

He said that Blu-ray had managed to win the support of a number of powerful studios, and that HD DVD had not managed to win over consumers or secure enough support from other studios.

Gareth Southgate has named his former captain Wayne Rooney in his England squad for September's UEFA Nations League games.

Rooney, who is England's record goal-scorer with 53, has not featured for his country since November 2016.

The 33-year-old, who plays for DC United in Major League Soccer, is among several players included in Southgate's squad for the games against Spain and Croatia who have been recalled.

They are defender Phil Jones and forwards Jermain Defoe and Andy Carroll.

England play Spain in Seville on Saturday 8 September (19:00 BST) and Croatia at Wembley on Sunday 13 September (14:00 BST).

Southgate said it was "too early" to write off Carroll, who has not played for England since September 2012.

"He is a player we have not had available for a long time, and it is great to have him back," said the England manager.

"We lack that type of player in the squad. We have a lot of technical players, perhaps not as many of a physical stature, so he adds something different to the group."

Rooney, who played for England at the 2006, 2010 and 2014 World Cup, has scored 53 goals in 119 appearances for the national side.

He announced his international retirement in August 2017, but later said he wanted to reverse that decision.

Southgate said in July that Rooney, who moved to DC United from Everton in July, would be considered for selection.

"He is determined to keep his standards high, and there is the excitement of a new challenge ahead of him in America," said Southgate.

"It is great to have that experience in the squad."

Southgate also named Chelsea's Ruben Loftus-Cheek and Manchester City's Fabian Delph in his squad, despite both facing lengthy spells on the sidelines with injury.

Loftus-Cheek has not played since sustaining an ankle injury against Arsenal in May, while Delph has not featured since February because of a knee problem.

There is also a place for Liverpool midfielder Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain, who has played just once this season because of a knee injury suffered last season.

Southgate said he was "more confident" that Loftus-Cheek and Delph would be available for the Spain game.

"They both want to be involved in the games. Ruben has worked really hard,

Manchester United manager Jose Mourinho has criticised the Arsenal players and coaching staff for their reaction to Aaron Ramsey's injury against Napoli.

The Wales international, 28, will leave the Gunners at the end of the season and has been ruled out until then with a hamstring injury.

Arsenal's players and staff went to Ramsey at the final whistle to commiserate, with Mourinho focusing on that rather than his side's 2-0 loss.

"I would do it if it was the opposite way around," he said. "If I was them, I would do the same thing."

Ramsey has scored 63 goals in 352 appearances for Arsenal since joining from Cardiff City in 2008.

Mourinho felt the Gunners were already treating Ramsey's injury as if it were a pre-season friendly and had criticised their attitude before the game.

"I would congratulate the players if I was in their position," he said. "If it was me, I would be in the middle of the pitch with my shirt off, celebrating."

The United manager said he "did not know" if Ramsey's injury was serious but said the timing of it - as the Gunners bid to qualify for the Champions League via the top four - was "not nice".

"If it was the end of the season then it would be holiday, holiday, holiday," he said.

On the game itself, Mourinho felt his side were not good enough and said they could not afford to have a player sent off after Paul Pogba was shown a second yellow card for a challenge on Hector Bellerin.

"The second yellow card was crucial," he said. "In the last 25 minutes we were in trouble."

Greg Weir has retired from playing professional football and will replace Alex Neil as Sunderland's head coach, according to reports.

The 35-year-old was appointed Stirling Albion manager in June 2019 and guided them to the promotion play-offs in his first two seasons.

Sunderland were relegated from the Championship last season and sacked Neil in April 2022, with academy boss Mike Watt taking charge for the final game of the campaign.

The Black Cats have been on the lookout for a new manager since then and it seems they have turned to Weir, who has left Stirling Albion after nearly three years at the club.

"After much thought and deliberation, I have decided to retire from playing professional football," Weir said.

"It's been the privilege of my life to represent the clubs I have played for, and I would like to express my gratitude to those that have helped me during my playing career.

"Retiring at 35 years old, feeling that my body is still able to perform at the highest level, makes this decision even harder, but I feel it's the right time for me to move onto the next challenge."

The BBC news article "Downloads enter US singles chart" published on February 5, 2010 outlines how downloads have officially entered the US singles chart. The song "Crush" by David Archuleta debuted at number forty on the Billboard Hot 100 with digital downloads included in the measurements. This marks the first time a song has entered the charts under the new methodology in which downloads are included in the tally sheet. Previously, songs were measured by physical CD sales only. 

Industry experts predict that downloads will level the playing field for established artists and new stars. It is cheaper to download songs as opposed to purchasing physical CDs, allowing greater access to a wide range of music for listeners. Additionally, this new development provides exposure to lesser-known artists who would otherwise be unable to distribute their music as widely.

Fiat is considering floating 10% of Ferrari on the stock market in an operation that could value the supercar maker at about $9bn.

The move would help Fiat reduce debt and help fund a costly shift towards producing electric and hybrid cars.

Ferrari's Formula One team has already been spun off and listed in New York.

The company - controlled by the Agnelli family's Exor investment group - has been under pressure from shareholders to unlock the value of its assets following the death of Sergio Marchionne last year.

The flotation of Ferrari, which is being advised by Bank of America, would be the latest in a series of moves by Fiat to raise money by offloading assets.

The Italian carmaker sold Chrysler and its components business in 2018 and spun off Magneti Marelli, its components business, earlier this year.

By selling part of Ferrari - a group with annual earnings of more than $1bn - Fiat would be able to cut its debt, which stood at 17.4 billion euros ($19.6bn) at the end of June.

 Analysts said that the valuation of 35 billion euros ($39bn) that had been reported in the Italian press would be too low and that Ferrari - famous for its roaring V12 engines - could be worth as much as $50bn.

That would make it worth more than Ford, which has a market capitalisation of about $45bn, and comparable with General Motors, which has a value of $52bn.

The plans to list at least part of Ferrari come just months after the Agnelli family assured investors that the company was not for sale.

A 10% float would give Fiat a war chest of several billion dollars to spend on new technologies, including hybrid and electric cars, as the industry faces huge investments to meet tougher emissions standards.

Fiat has already said it would need to spend more than 50bn ($56bn) in the next five years to meet these rules.

The group, which also owns the Fiat, Alfa Romeo and Jeep brands, has said it wants to list in New York, but a final decision has not been made.

By listing in New York, Fiat would be following in the footsteps of another iconic Italian brand, Armani, which recently filed for an IPO in the US.

The move would be a blow for the Milan stock exchange, where the Fiat group has been listed since 2004.

A Ferrari float would also

Apple has launched a low-cost version of its Mac computer for those who are switching from PCs.

The new Mac mini retains the same design as the previous version but has faster processors and, Apple says, is up to five times faster than the PCs in its price range.

It is the cheapest Mac ever - cheaper even than the iPhone - with a price starting at $499 (315).

"For the first time, we've updated the Mac mini with the latest Intel Core processors, 100% faster graphics, Thunderbolt I/O technology and the newest version of OS X," said Philip Schiller, Apple's head of marketing.

"With Mac mini's unbeatable new value, it's going to be amazing to see what kids, teachers, designers and DIYers are able to do with it."

However, the new computer does not come with a monitor, keyboard or mouse - users must buy them separately.

The upgrade to the Mac mini comes as sales of PCs have continued to fall, putting pressure on PC makers to cut prices.

Research firm Gartner said PC shipments in the third quarter of 2011 were down 8.3% compared with the same period in 2010.

Apple though has continued to post strong growth, with its share of the PC market rising from 7.6% to 9.1% in the three months to September, Gartner said.

Earlier this month, Apple revealed it had sold its 250 millionth Mac.

European low-cost airline Ryanair has signed a deal with Boeing for up to 232 new airplanes, with a list price of $4.75bn.

The deal with the US manufacturer includes firm orders for 100 737 Max jets, with the option to purchase a further 132 planes.

Ryanair boss Michael O'Leary called the deal "the biggest ever order" for Boeing in European aviation history.

The announcement came on the second day of the Paris Airshow, where plane makers are vying for orders from airlines.

Boeing said the order would boost its backlog of orders for the 737 Max jet to more than 4,600 aircraft.

The deal also includes purchase rights for a further 60 Max jets and 20 additional 737s.

"We are pleased to extend our partnership with Ryanair, adding more fuel-efficient 737s to their fleet, which will continue to grow with the Boeing Sky Interior and other amenities our customers have come to love," said Boeing Chief Executive Officer, Dennis Muilenburg.

"We are certain Ryanair will appreciate the significant savings and efficiency delivered by the 737 MAX and we look forward to welcoming them to the Boeing family when they take delivery of their first MAX in late 2017," he added in a statement.

Ryanair currently has a fleet of 380 Boeing aircraft and the deal with the US manufacturer will provide aircraft for the airline's growth until at least 2024.

The low-cost carrier aims to fly more than 100 million passengers a year by 2024, with the Boeing planes serving routes between Ireland, the UK, and Continental Europe.

Ryanair's chief executive, Michael O'Leary, said the deal represented the largest ever single order of Boeing planes by a European airline.

"This deal will allow us to expand our fleet to 520 aircraft by 2024, allowing for further growth of our flying schedule in Europe and releasing further runway slots for use by primary airlines," he said.

Mr. O'Leary said the deal would be funded by cash reserves and funds raised by the sale of between 30 and 40 planes a year.

The deal comes two days after Boeing's biggest customer, American Airlines, signed a letter of intent to buy 40 Boeing 737 MAX jets with an option for a further 55 aircraft.

On the first day of the Paris Airshow, Airbus secured a blockbuster $18.4bn order from Emirates for its A380 superjumbo.

BT has announced it will be offering free internet phone calls to customers, the BBC reported. The UK's largest telecoms provider said calls would be free whether made to fixed-line or mobile phones, or even international numbers. However, calls will only be free if they are made via broadband and not via the mobile phone network, BT said. The company said it wanted to "future-proof" its customers' phone bills and "evolve" the traditional landline. Industry regulator Ofcom said it would "carefully review" the offer, to ensure it complied with its rules, which state that providers must be clear about any price differences between using a landline or internet service. In its statement, BT said its customers would need to have an active subscription to BT Broadband and a compatible router to benefit from the offer. Once they had signed up, they would be able to make free calls anytime, anywhere, the company said. Landline and broadband customers will be able to sign up from November, while EE mobile customers can do so in January.

It comes as BT, which still boasts 12 million landline customers, recently reported a quarterly rise in profits, boosted by growth in its broadband and mobile services. The company said it wanted to "reward our loyal customers and attract new ones". A spokesman for BT told the BBC the company was "confident" the offer would not result in a "material decline" in the number of calls made via the landline network. Landlines continue to be used by many customers for regular phone calls, as well as taking advantage of offers such as free weekends and cheap evening calls, said Marc Allera, CEO of BT's consumer division.

A court in doping probe pilot tube

London 2012 Olympic pole vault champion Rena Simmonides and her coach Petros Karyotis have appeared at a hearing in Athens over allegations of doping.

The court decided there was not enough evidence for the case to continue but the International Olympic Committee (IOC) has asked for it to be re-opened.

The IOC has provisionally suspended both Greeks from all track and field activity.

The hearing concerned allegations that Greek testing authorities concealed information aboutSimmonides' medical history from the IOC's doping panel.

The 23-year-old, who won gold in London with a personal best of 4.75 metres, has always denied doping allegations.

Her lawyer Haris Sakellariou said the court's decision on Monday was "a big relief" for his client.

The court accepted that there were errors in the handling of Simmonides' documentation but said these were not intentional.

It also accepted that there were contradictions in her testimony but said these were a result of her youth and her suffering from concussion after a car accident in 2013.

The IOC has asked the court to re-open the case and for Simmonides' Olympic gold medal to be reallocated, should her doping violation be confirmed.

Speaking at a news conference after the verdict, IOC ethics commission chief Jean-Paul Amery said he was "not satisfied" with the outcome.

He said he would "study the verdict in detail before deciding on the next steps".

Sakellariou said he expected the IOC to appeal, adding: "We are ready to respond to any appeal and answer any questions."

The lawyer said Simmonides would return to training but would not yet decide whether to appeal against her provisional suspension by the IOC.

Show over for MTV's The Osbournes

Ozzy Osbourne and his family are to end their reality TV show after four seasons.

The veteran heavy metal singer and his wife/manager Sharon made the announcement on Monday's episode of MTV's The Osbournes.

"This is the end of The Osbournes," Osbourne, 60, said near the end of the show. "Don't cry."

Sharon, 42, added, "It's been a hell of a ride."

The show, which debuted in 2002, has followed the eccentric household through Ozzy's successful battle against alcoholism, Sharon's management of Ozzy's career and the couple's efforts to keep their three teenage children out of the rock 'n' roll lifestyle.

In a recent interview with Entertainment Weekly magazine, Ozzy said the show was ending because the family had grown apart.

"You can't keep filming when the kids aren't living at home anymore," he said. "It's like When Animals Attack. You can't do it."

Labour MPs' fears over 'squabbling'

Senior Labour MPs have told the BBC they are worried the party is "squabbling" and "not speaking as one" ahead of the expected coronation of Jeremy Corbyn.

The party's governing body, the National Executive Committee (NEC), is meeting on Tuesday to discuss the format of the leadership contest.

One MP said Labour was "sniping at itself" and "totally incapable of communicating with the public".

Another said members were frightened to speak out for fear of retribution.

The NEC is expected to announce that an electoral college system - last used in 2010 - will be revived for the leadership vote.

That could mean Labour MPs having a veto on who becomes leader.

One MP told the BBC's Political Editor Laura Kuenssberg: "I think it's important that we debate these issues properly and that all options are discussed fully and openly.

"There are ways of doing this which are consistent with party members having the final say, and I think we should do that."

Another said: "Members are frightened to speak out for fear of retribution.

"That's how it feels in PLP [Parliamentary Labour Party] meetings. That's how it feels on the WhatsApp groups.

"There are very few people who are willing to stick their heads above the parapet. There's a lot of squabbling."

It comes as former shadow chancellor John McDonnell suggested the party could move to the left after the election of a new leader.

He told the BBC the next election "is going to be a more ideological battle" between the parties, adding that "the tide is moving our way".

Mr McDonnell also warned the party not to "betray" its manifesto, after some MPs suggested a U-turn on the policy to scrap the Trident nuclear deterrent.

Two senior Labour MPs told the BBC they would not serve in a shadow cabinet led by Jeremy Corbyn if he became leader.

One of them, Caroline Flint, ruled out a return to the shadow cabinet, saying: "I've done it once, I don't want to do it again."

The other MP said: "I doubt very much I would serve in a Corbyn shadow cabinet. Just because I think he would be a disaster."

Singapore's economy grew an estimated 8.1 per cent in 2004, helped by a strong performance in manufacturing and financial services, the government said.

The announcement released by the Trade and Industry Ministry showed that the growth rate was lower than the 8.5 per cent expansion seen in 2003.

"On the external front, the global economy held firm, but growth was more unevenly distributed among the major economies," the announcement said.

Manufacturing, which accounts for about a quarter of Singapore's economy, grew 7.9 per cent last year, down from 10.5 per cent in 2003.

For 2005, the government said it expected moderate economic growth in the range of 4 per cent to 6 per cent, given the uncertain global economic situation, with growth in manufacturing likely to moderate further.

House prices in Britain have rebounded after a slowdown induced by the initial lockdown, according to figures from the Halifax.

The mortgage lender said prices in November were up 7.1% compared with the same month in 2019, the fastest annual growth rate for almost two years.

Compared with October, prices were up 1.2%, with the average house price now 270,027.

Lockdown restrictions have been blamed for slowing the market earlier this year.

However, figures from other measures, such as the Office for National Statistics, put annual house growth at a lower level.

"While the immediate impact of the first lockdown was to slow the market, property prices have since recovered and have reached a new high," said Russell Galley, managing director of the Halifax.

"Overall, 2020 has been a record year for house prices, with annual growth exceeding 7% for the first time in eight years."

He added that low borrowing costs appeared to be supporting demand, with the average mortgage rate hovering at a record low.

Industry body UK Finance said on Tuesday that buyers with large deposits were now benefiting from the lowest mortgage rates ever recorded.

However, it said first-time buyers were struggling to get on the ladder as the cost of deposits rose.

Over the past month, the average price of a detached property increased by 2.1% compared with 0.6% for flats.

London continued to see a slower pace of growth than other parts of the UK, with prices increasing by just over 5% compared with November 2019.

The fastest growth was recorded in Wales, where prices were up more than 11% on the year, followed by the North West of England with 8.6% growth.

Mitsubishi Motors has confirmed that it is in talks with Peugeot SA about a possible merger.

The Japanese car maker said it has asked Peugeot - which is itself preparing to merge with Fiat Chrysler - to "jointly study" a merger plan.

A merger between Mitsubishi and Peugeot would create the world's fourth-largest auto maker by sales, behind Volkswagen, Toyota and Renault-Nissan.

In a statement, Mitsubishi said the two companies plan to hold talks "from a long-term perspective".

Last month, Peugeot revealed that it was in talks to buy Fiat Chrysler, in a deal that would create the world's fourth-largest car maker.

Peugeot's board was meeting on Thursday to discuss the proposal, amid growing speculation that a deal could be announced as early as next week.

Last week, Peugeot's chief executive, Carlos Tavares, said the company was open to a "friendly" merger with Mitsubishi Motors.

Mitsubishi was once part of the Renault-Nissan alliance, but sold a controlling stake to Nissan in 2016.

Mr Tavares said a merger with Mitsubishi would help his company expand its presence in Asia.

Mitsubishi Motors was hit hard by a scandal in 2016 over data cheating that affected some of its cars.

The company sold 930,000 vehicles worldwide in 2018, compared to the 3.9 million sold by Peugeot.

New wearable helps golfers correct their swing
A new wearable device that provides real-time audio feedback could help golfers improve their swing.

The Mobile Motion Tracker (MMT) is a lightweight, wireless, sensor that attaches to the golfer's belt. It measures the movements of the hips, upper body and hands during a swing and sends information to a smartphone app, via Bluetooth.

The app analyses the movements and tells the golfer how to improve via headphones.

"We wanted to find a way for golfers to get feedback on their swing as they are practicing, and not just from a coach at the end of a session," said Meladee Lindsey, from the Georgia Institute of Technology in the US, who led the team that developed the MMT.

"The sensor sends data to the app, which then produces an audio report at the end of each swing," she told the BBC.

Ms Lindsey said the device could be used by golfers of all abilities to improve their game.

"When you practise you generally don't have feedback while you are doing it," she said. "Most of the time you have to synthesise everything that you did at the end of a practise session.

"Having audio feedback while you are still on the driving range allows you to make any changes needed to correct your swing while it is still fresh in your mind."

The device could be particularly helpful for less-skilled golfers, said Ms Lindsey.

"Amateur golfers in particular stand to benefit from wearing this device because they often don't have the funds to take lessons from a pro coach," she said.

"This could be a cheaper way to get feedback on their swing and it's a tool that could help them to self-improve."

The MMT was developed by a team from Georgia Tech and the Alfred Mann Foundation, a non-profit organisation that helps develop technologies to help disabled people.

The foundation is now looking for industry partners to commercialise the MMT.

"The initial goal of the device was to help rehabilitate patients who have had a stroke," said Georgia Tech research scientist Ervin Sejdic.

"But we have found that the device has a lot of applications in other areas, such as sports and entertainment."

In addition to golf, the MMT could be used to help improve a person's posture or to monitor vibrations from machinery.

The Angel Food Dogs
By Ellen Hagan
They waited patiently for the food to fall
Those dogs with the golden eyes, 
And the whitest teeth that gleamed
In the firelight's glow,
As the angel food fell from the sky
From the plates of the children who passed
That way on their way to Sunday school.
Oh, it was a holy meal
That the dogs awaited with eager, love-lighted eyes,
And the people were holy too
As they fed the lovely creatures,
And tossed them bits of bread,
And the dogs rose up,
And they bowed, their tails wagging,
And they followed the children as they all went off
To Sunday school, where the lessons were taught
By the preacher with the loving eyes.
And the dogs sat patiently by
As the children learned of God's love
And his wondrous ways,
And the dogs were as happy as the children were
Who were gathered there to learn of heaven's joy,
And the eyes of the dogs were aglow
As the children's voices rose in song
To praise God for his love and his care
And the food that nourishes all.
And the dogs knew that they were loved
By the children, and the children by them
And the love was like a circle
That ever grew and grew.

Understand That This Is A Dream
...
In this dream, I speak the language
Of canals and stars;
It is a language lost
To the mouth's grimace,
It is a language that hides
In the folds of the shirt...
...
In this dream, the idea of infinity
Is as plain as the shoe on my foot;
In this dream, I float in infinity
As I would in a tub...
...
In this dream, I know the essence
Of all that I am,
The atoms of me rejoice
As I glide through their domains;
...
In this dream, I am united
With those I have loved...
...
This is a dream.
I repeat: this is a dream.
It bites my nails and flaps my arms...
...
It is a dream.
Understand that this is a dream.
It is as real as that shoe on my foot.

To God the Father

ToString Him whom ye entitle Father:
The right appellation, since He seems
A father to the universe which groans
Of concupiscence, and sorely pined
And travailed till the great hour arrived
Of the Deliverance, when His well-loved Son
Should offer Himself a sacrifice for man.

It profits us to know His name and ours
And how it comes we are His children;
What heights our nature can attain, and pave
A broader way for the religious
Who, being faithful, realize the truth
Of things unseen, and things eternal.

Our Father! Thine the glory
And the majesty eternal;
Thine the dominion, and the power
And the glory of them,
For ever and for ever.
Amen.

A Sunday Prayer Of Thanks

Lord, unto whom all hearts be open, all desires known,
and from whom no secretes but by His own decree:
Give me a chance, dear Lord, to offer thanks
for all thy great good gifts, so freely show'n
of health, of friends, of work; and all thy care
to guide, and guard, and keep us safe from fear.

But Lord, today, let favour suddenly break forth
on this thy servant, who hath never durst
to lift up head, or heart, or eye unto
thy holy hill, but did endure
tears, and sorrows, and darkness, all for naught;

Till wrung with grief, in loneliness she prayed
a prayer approaching unto thy command,
and thou hast answered. Give her, Lord, her heart's desire;
stretch forth thy hand, and make her joyent
with thy people, now set free.

And if it be thy pleasure to prolong her days
on this distressful earth, where joy hath ceased
to dwell, then grant her wisdom, grant her courage
to face each day, and every new offense
against thy law, with steadfast peace
and patient smiles.

Feed her, clothe her, Lord, reveal to her
the path of duty, and support her therein;
then shall thy light upon her countenance
shine with a sparkless beam, and no one shall
then say, "Behold, here lieth one
who once hath tasted bitter tears."

And so shall she go on her lowly way,
praising thy holy name, and thy commands,
till peaceful death shall set her free
from all worldly ills, and she shall rest
in thee, her maker, through all eternity.

Wine and water clear,
The hand that serves is generous and kind,
For generous wine, it merits only praise,
And water, cold and sparkling, it finds,
LEaving behind the old, stale alkalinity.

With a soul that cleaves to the ways of the past,
It longs for the tottering, vanished glamour,
The clatter of silver on cut-glass trays,
The soft, deep purr of a well-oiled sedan,
The leisurely dribble of powder,
The gradual, sunset disappearance of old acquaintances,
One by one, year after year.

It misses the meaningless chatter of careless days,
The calls at awkward hours, the senseless shriek,
The hasty snatch of a half-forgotten tune,
The drag of feet on a floor worn thin,
The bashful, sidelong glance of a friendly eye,
The bursting bubble of iridescent talk.

It treasures moments of softness and ease,
The caressing touch of a delicate hand,
The feel of silk and the crispness of lace,
The spell of a voice that is sweet and calm,
The glance of a eye that is gay and bold,
The swirl and dash of the waltz in an old-fashioned ballroom.

It aches for the vanished forms and moods of the past,
The glamour of vanished graces,
For it has a faith in the might of forgetting,
And it loves to remember and recall,
To the mind's eye, old visions of charm and grace.

It sees a garden of dreams where lilies sway,
And girlish forms in the moonlight glow,
Whispers and laughter and hints of play,
And the stirring of hearts that were long ago.

It sees in memory fair faces anew
And feels the old, magic fascination,
And hears again, oh, so faintly, a laugh new,
Which died long since, or did it ever live?

The Sick God

I walked through the universe in a darkness deeper than death;
In my hunger I ate of the grass of deserts,
In my thirst I drank of the shadows of wells,
In my loneliness I clutched at the emptiness of space,
In my fear I hid in the jaws of the serpent,
In my hope I lay down in the shadow of the rock,
In my despair I clutched at the wings of the locust,
In the hardness of my heart I scoffed at the stillness of the seed,
In the cruelty of my hunger I gnawed at the roots of the grass,
In the longing of my soul I lay down in the dust of the earth.

Then I heard a Voice in the wilderness,
And a Hand touched me in the shadow of the rock.
And He said to me: "Rise up, staggering minstrel,
The cup of madness is full in the house of the sleeper,
And the hive of the bee is heavy with honey,
The wine of the grape is ripe in the cluster,
The flock of the sheep is thick on the hillside,
The corn of the grain is ripe for the reaper,
The swan of the river sings in the mist of the evening,
The moon of the night is fair on the forehead of midnight,
And the Word of the Lord is sweet on the lips of the hungry."

And He gave me a branch of olive,
And He filled my hands with bread.

I ate and was fully satisfied,
And I gave thanks to the Lord;
And He brought me to the hill of blessing,
And He showed me the glory of God;
And He said to my soul: "Song of the solitary;
How long wilt thou mourn for the remembered joys of thine innocence?
Give heed; and hear, O son of man;
For the swallow hath sung in the mouth of the sepulchre,
And the eyes of the blind do behold
The joy of the morning;
And the limbs of the lame do leap
For the glory of God."

And He took away the hardness of my heart,
And He gave me tears to cleanse my soul;
And He sent me a Comforter out of the lips of the dumb;
And He showed me the place of repentance,
That I might rest my soul therein;
And He said to my soul

A Real Despair

By Ellen Hopkins

They say it takes 21 days to form a habit,
but only 21 seconds to break one apart.
I guess I should be thankful then,
for small mercies,
that decay doesn't happen all at once.

Because there are some days
I want to crawl back into my mother's womb,
to a time before accountability,
to when "I don't know" was a good enough answer,
when "fine" was an acceptable response
to "how are you today?"

Before the weight of "why"
became heavier than the granite tiles
I force myself to crawl across some days.

They say happiness is a choice,
but I would argue that despair is, too.
Some days I choose to wear despair
like a favorite, well-worn shirt,
folding it carefully at the end of the day
and tucking it lovingly
into the bottom of my wardrobe.

Other days I refuse to don it
despite the chill of uncertainty
blowing through the cracks in the window,
seeping in like fog through fissures
in a poorly built house.

On those days, I gather
all the disparate pieces
of happiness I can find
and I clutch them to my chest
like a mother clutching her firstborn,
as if they are the only things
that can keep me from
ppling over the edge
of the precipice of

What if I jumped?
What if I just jumped?

They say it takes 21 seconds to break a habit.
I wonder if they mean it only takes 21 seconds
to begin one, as well.

The moon is rising slowly,
The stars are timidly looking on,
The river flows quietly,
And the trees are faithfully weeping.

A lonely fisherman
Is fishing in the river,
The tears of the river
Are the tears from his eyes,
He swears that he will fish
Till the river dries.

He fishes for the moon,
He fishes for the biggest fish,
He fishes waving his arms,
Crying while singing.

He does not feel the cold,
He does not feel the darkness,
He is looking for a miracle,
He is trying to forget.

The moonrise seems to take forever,
But suddenly the big fish jumps,
The fisherman laughs triumphantly,
And he pulls it out of the water.

He holds it in his arms,
He holds it tightly,
He carries it to the moon,
And says: "Here, this is for you."

The moon thanks him,
The moon kisses his forehead,
The fisherman lies down on the bank,
And he sleeps embraced by the river.
