My Home
By Margaret Elizabeth Sangster

Geraniums crimson and gold,
And satin petunias fine,
Are all asleep in their flower-beds,
Under the night's cloudy wing.

I breathe no fragrance but sigh one,
As I pass the gate near,
Where, all day long, in the sunny July,
These purple buds were mine.

Shall I ever feel any pulse of their life,
Or thrill to their autumn fire,
As yesterday, when the burning clouds sank down
And made their torches higher?

Perchance some night, when the southwest
Blows soft and the moon is bright,
They will fling forth their souls to the sighing breeze,
And my heart will give them light.

But now, in the dim and the dreary,
They are dead to my longing sight,
And I think of their fragrance but as a dream
A phantom of night,and sigh.

I have no home where I lay my head,
Or hang my hat on a hook;
No stable, no barn,but a house of a friend,
That gives me a bed to lie in,
And a table to eat on, and a tall candle
To light me to bed, and a God to bless me
And keep me the whole night through.

And because I have loved in my life,
And have been so happy,
In the friend's house, for the friend's little child,
I go to sleep contented.

In the future the world will be different,

Every man will have his needs met, and every woman will have her wants.

That the earth is his home and that he must take care of it,

Sure as night follows day,
And day returns again,
By this we know the soul returns
To seek its ancient realm.

In the stillness of recollection,
In the fullness of delight,
The memory of half-formulated
Thoughts and dreams arises.

These fragments of a distant future
Cast shadows in the here and now,
And in the quiet moments
We can feel the promise of their return.

But in the cacophony of the daily grind,
In the chaos of our lives unlived,
The warning signs of a half-remembered
Future are drowned out.

So listen carefully in the stillness,
In the quiet moments between
For the whispers of a distant tomorrow,
And the echoes of a half-remembered past.

For in those faint echoes and whispers
Lie the secrets of our destiny,
And the early warning signs of what may be
Are calling out to us from somewhere far away.

Loves Treasure House

Love's treasury house, no locks nor keys,
Open ever to thy call,
Nor heed I hour, day, or night,
Nor wilt thou oft timesal.

Windows that view the stars shine through,
This house is all thine own,
And oft as thou wilt enter there
Thy welcome shall be shown.

Here freely do thou call,
And freely thy woes tell,
Of all thy disappointments
And thy soul's loud yell.

Here freely do thou gaze,
On memories of past days,
And thou shalt find a lovely rose
In icy winter's gloom.

In this house, of thy making,
All things are meant for thee,
Therefore do thou enter often
To keep thy heart aglow.

Here silence aids thy thought,
And joy flies on the wind,
And Love makes all his treasures
Conspicuous to thy mind.

Love's treasury house, no locks nor keys,
Open ever to thy call,
Nor heed I hour, day, or night,
Thus communes thy soul with all.

A Tale Founded On A Fact Which Happened In January1779

"Twas in the dead of winter, when the frost
Was hammering on the cabin roof,
Not a creature was stirring, (well I spy'd
The mouse ne'er so gentle and shy)
By the fire a grandmother told a tale
To her little grand-son Jim;
A tale of an ungrateful boy,
And a faithful dog deserving praise.

"There was once a boy, as I've heard tell,
At play one winter's day,
Chased a snow-white rabbit, that was running
From branch to branch, near the wall;
When he had it in sight,
He fired, and missed, and the rabbit was gone,
Scarce the snow-white tip of its tail was showing,
As it scampered away;
The boy gave a whistle, and cried 'Hie on,
My dog is swift as the wind!'
But however the dog hunted and sniffed
He could not find the rabbit,
For the snow had covered it up,
And it had run into the wood.

"And now it was evening, and darkness stole
On the bleak winter's day;
The boy and his dog they returned home,
For they were hungry and cold;
And the little boy's mother, she cried,
'You should not have gone so far away!'
'I wish I had stayed at home,' said he,
'For I have lost my rabbit, and now
I shall have no dinner!'

"The grandmother smiled, and said, 'You've learnt
A good lesson, my boy, to-day,
For once in a while, when you've lost your dinner,
It will do you good, some day!'

To the fire, and took her hand,
And the dog sat down, and pricked up his ears
To hear what was to be said:
'Once on a time, my dear Jim,
Your father was a little boy,
And he had a dog, that was so good,
And wise, that he was sent
To a town, with a wallet of bread,
To bring home the wages of a day;
And when he had done this,
He would run round the wood so happy and free,
And bring his little master the game

By the Editor
Wine of Ava, sweet, terrestrial, divine,
Dear to every pilot who roves the wine-dark sea;
Rosy, radiant, glorious as dawn on high;
Buried in the deep, none but gods can retrieve:
This is the lost drink, the Danaides' torment,
Ever for the gods a theme of regret.
Once I saw it shining in Nireus' hall,
That fairest flower of the argonautic race;
But none of his comrades dared ask for a draught,
Lest, asked in vain, he might wish it wasted.
Then, when sea and land alike bore us homeward,
With sails outstretched, oars tossed in the purple deep,
Then, when the fair wind blew toward the morning,
The radiant drink rose to my lips unbidden.
Goddess of night, in thy dim eyes lustrous,
Give me the flush of that moment once more!
Give me the breath of the heaven, the bloom of the rose,
The dew of the grass, the glory of the sea!
Is there no nectar save only in heaven?
Ah, give me back the age of gold!

The sky is falling; the sky is falling,
But it ain't falling on me,
It's falling on the heads of bosses, and lawyers, and bankers,
And other bigwigs who love exploitation and greed.

The sky is falling; the sky is falling,
But it ain't falling on me,
It's falling on the politicians and preachers,
And other cunning heads of state.

The sky is falling; the sky is falling,
But it ain't falling on me,
No, it's falling on the rich men's homes,
And it's falling on the poor men's heads.

The sky is falling; the sky is falling,
Ain't doing me no harm.
It's stirring up the devil in some gentle hearts,
And revealing snakes wherever it goes.

The sky is falling; the sky is falling,
Ain't doing me no harm.
It's raining revenge on all the mean men,
And the sky scraps away their smirks.

Note: This poem is written from the perspective of an observer who is seemingly unaffected by the issues happening to the sky (probably metaphorical) and the people it is falling on.

BACK IN THE AGE BEFORE THE COMPUTER
youngsters nowadays really haven't got a clue
about what it was like living in the ancient world
before Windows and Mac made life worth living.

Before the Internet, Facebook and Twitter
kids had to actually go outside and play
instead of sitting in front of a computer screen
gazing at pixels and drinking Dr. Pepper.

Before mobile phones got so damn smart
we had to use our brains, and that's a fact
we'd actually talk to each other, face to face
and share our thoughts and feelings without an @

Sometimes I long for the age before the computer
when life was simpler and so much more
when people didn't share every little thought
and just stared out the window and dreamed of clouds.

The sun underfoot among the sundews
Puts forth a quiet orb of amber,
 Shining up at him upon the rocks,
 Among the dreary moss and ling.

It is a little globe of heat
That makes no noise, and it is pesky
To feel its sting and not to see
The wasp that loads it with its pack.

And yet it is the central flame,
The focus of a shining nation,
And all the beams it casts are sunbeams,
To whom it gives a daily station.

There is no dew on its hot front,
For ever it is dry and sunny,
It never weeps nor showers sweet rains,
But languidly it fumes and glows.

It stirs no passions vehemently,
But as it is to give delight,
So to the cheerful mind it brings
A sunny melancholy.

For Nature is not always gay,
Nowhere she ever laughs outright,
And joyful is with alloy
Of the realization of her might.

She knows her secrets hidden deeply,
Her present and her future fate,
And therefore sings a minor key
With solemn joy predestinate.

So amid these sad sundews' bells,
That silently ring their vespers,
The little sun, with amber beams,
Shines up and makes no statement.

A Story For Rose On The Midnight Flight To Boston

From Honolulu, fastened seat belts
To Boston, late winter, anxiety:
"Are we flying into the sun?
Is this plane on fire?"
The sky is jammed with lumpy clouds:
Their tops are brushed with bronze from the hidden moon,
Their insides brighten as we climb
Higher and higher, excursionists eager
To break out, explore, invade
The clouds are slabs of moonwashed marble
And we sail close, almost brush them,
Then wheel back, shun them.
Below, the continent spreads out,
A mosaic of glitter.
We ascend
Over the tangy pine forests,
The cities' Christmas trees burning hot and bright,
And all the sad beside-the-highway motels
Where highway tiles blink mockingly
And echo with emptiness.
We rocket on, a gleaming needle,
Aimed at the veined heart of America,
While day breaks, devastating, lovely,
Far off, behind us.
"Ladies and gentlemen, we are beginning our descent..."
The plane slows, sinks,
Returns to the earth,
And everyone looks out,
Ascending into a new day.

Gods at Work
By Jeremy Rosenbaum
They whisper to the pansies and praise the luminous jets of the daffodils,
who yawn and stretch beneath the windowsill in the sunlight,
and breathe again.
They smile at the snail and cuddle the ticking masonry,
who sleep undisturbed by human feet,
and wake to the smell of wet concrete.

who sway and bob in the crisp breeze,
and cuddle the warm, fuzzy blanket of night.
They talk to the rain and bicker with the wind,
who slaps and beats on the shuttering boards,
and cleans the soot from the roofs.
They sing to the sunlight and laugh with the moonlight,
who stroke the sleepy dew from the grass,
and guide it safely to the ground.
They smile at the clouds and cuddle the stars,
who blink and twinkle and watch over the earth,
and never wish for anything more.

Learned Helplessness Sympathy Syndrome 

We don't know how to fix this. 

We shuffle around the edges; 

sizing up the catastrophe, 

trying not to drown in the onslaught of details, 

drown in the inundation of information, 

in the sentimental sludge of other people's tears, 

other people's trauma, 

other people's tragedies. 

There is nothing useful to do. 

There is nothing _we_ can do. 

We were never invited here. 

These are not our ashes to sweep up. 

These are not our toys to pick up. 

These are not our bodies to drag from rubble. 

Offer your condolences.

Offer your tears.

Offer your ideas, 

then leave the rubble to the people who live there, 

to the people whose misery is their home. 

This is not our tragedy. 

We are lucky we get to go home.

Young mother, weeping alone,
Curled up on the couch with your boy,
Thinking of your life at this moment so unsure,
Remembering the dreams your soul did pursue,

When you first saw his little face,
You forgot all the pain and the fear,
The contractions that seized your abdomen,
And pulled at your nerves till you nearly cried out,

Were nothing compared to the joy you feel now,
As you cuddle your baby and softly coo,
With a heart so full of gratitude and awe,
At the wonder of life that you once almost threw,

You're grateful for the strength you possessed,
To push through the pain and embrace this gift,
A reminder of the power you uphold,
To create, nurture and finally fulfill,

Yet as you gaze at his innocent sleep,
You can't help but feel a tinge of blue,
The weight of responsibility starts to creep,
And you wonder how you'll navigate through,

The challenges of motherhood, come what may,
You know you'll never be the same again,
For better or worse, your life now entwines,
With this beautiful soul, who has chosen you as his queen.

Velocity of money
Hot summer night,
City streets are empty,
Not a soul around.

Young and old,
Robbed of their wealth,
Gone to bed early,
Tired and depressed.

While the few,
With their wealth intact,
Party on in penthouse suites,
They don't stop to think.

In the heat of summer,
The city sleeps,
Under cover of darkness,
The rich steal and cheat.

But the day will come,
When the tables will turn,
And the money they stole,
Will become their burden and burn.

So in this life,
We must do what's right,
And not let the love of money,
Cloud our judgment and sight.

For in the end,
When we leave this world,
Our wealth will remain,
But our character will fade and burn.

The Wedding Ring
By Ellen Marriage
A wedding ring is round and precious,
A symbol of love's beauty and worth.
It has no beginning and no ending,
As is the love that it imparts.

A wedding ring is smooth and shining,
A token of love's purity.
It is a circle of affection,
Given as a pledge forever.

A wedding ring is worn on the finger,
Of the left hand, close to the heart.
It is a reminder of the vows spoken,
On that most precious day of all.

A wedding ring is a symbol of unity,
And of the promises made between.
It is a symbol of commitment and honor,
And of the hopes for the future.

For a wedding ring is not just a piece of jewelry,
But a symbol of the bond it seals.
It is a symbol of the love and affection,
That is shared by two hearts in bliss.

So wear your wedding ring with pride and joy,
And may it always be a symbol
Of the love you share and the life you've built,
Together as one forever.

This is the classroom,
Degas teaches art and science here.
There's drawing and anatomy,
Engraving, geology,
Botany and biology,
Physics and hygiene,
He teaches them all.

There are fifty pupils
And Degas teaches them all.
All the basics,
For aspiring young artists
Who want to create
Their own masterpieces.

With the proper education,
They can create anything,
Their imaginations are limitless,
They can become anything.

Degas teaches them carefully,
And patiently,
He encourages their creativity,
And helps them to realize their dreams.

This is the classroom,
Degas teaches art and science here.
He's a great teacher,
And the students love him,
They know he's trying to prepare them
For a bright future.

Winter nights are long and cold,
And in my grumbling I do condole
The wrongs that fortune mendlessly wrought,
And oft with envy I do behold
The neighbor's smoke, that upward curls,
To think it comes from fires of oak
Whereas mine comes from coal.

Ah, me! how oft my nice consideration
In foolish fancy turns unto this thought,
That Paradise itself were gross impropriety
Were it not for fires of cedar wood attired!

But Spring shall come again, and raging fires
Shall burn the limbs of Winter as he pastes
His hoary teeth and crispy bones against the panes
Of rattling windows 'bout the streets.
And oft, upon a warm December night
Before a roaring grate I then shall throng
With thriftier soul, and give thanks for
The coal that made a cheerful show.

But thou, my soul, amidst the petty strife
Of meaningless endeavours, dost thou strive
To build thy Being's temple, strong and fair,
That swiftly passes all things transitory?

Be brave and busy; scorn all anxious care
And learn to labor well, and truly bear
Thy part i' the mighty, onward sweep
Of Commerce, lest thou perish woefully
A barren soul, amidst a greedy race.

And if thou diest, before thy arduous task
Be finished, let a worthy successor take
Thy toil, and be the better for thy dreams;
But be thou faithful unto thine own highest aims
And unto God, and Fashion's shifting form
Shall yield to Beauty's immutable warm.

A Dream
By Edgar Allan Poe

Oh, happy dream! even though it was a dream;
Happy dream! in spite of all the sadness
Of waking to a world of exile from thee.

In the deep bosom of the moaning sea
Lie the loved fragments of our broken trust,
With, ever and ever, an eye to weep for thee,
And a lip to murmur'Exile! thou art just.'

But Fancy loves to hover o'er the spot
Where all my many joys have been extended;
And for a momentoh, how kind!remembers
Not only all my griefs, but all my pleasures.

It bears me back to other evenings by the fire,
When thou wert all,when nothing went astray,
When Faith was fresh, and Love was not a lie
When Life was glad, because thou wast his way!

When eyes were bright, and clear, and open wide,
Because the soul behind them was not blind;
And Fancy, Spring-time Fancy, full of wings,
Might wander forth,whithersoever she would!

Oh, happy dream! even though it was a dream;
Happy dream! in spite of all the sadness
Of waking to a world of exile from thee!

To Her Hair

Oh, how dare you do that?
To make me love you more,
By making me forget
The stupid things I swore.

Just when I think
I've figured it all out,
By making me feel
That I should never doubt.

You change the game,
By being everything
I've ever needed,
And making me smile,
When I just wanted to scream.

Perhaps I see what's there,
Instead of what isn't,
Focusing on your hair,
Instead of the imperfections.

Perhaps I've given you too much credit,
For things that you never did,
Perhaps I needed to be hurt,
To learn how to trust.

But if it's true,
That all roads lead to here,
Then I hope that you somehow
Realize how much I care.

Perhaps I don't know what I want,
Perhaps I never did,
All I know is that right now
It's you that I need.

To her hair.

A Letter Written For My Daughter To A Lady Who Had Presented Her With A Cap

As oft you wear it, Madam, 'twill remind you
Of me, your friend; and, as you use it,
Still farther will it chance to bind you
In friendship firm and fast:
And, as these silken tissues rarely
Are seen to better advantage,
When art and chance have planned it,
It may be chance, not art, that I
May seem t' have gain'd a friend;
And she, for whose dear sake these lines
Are spun from thought, almost extemporally,
May be as chance, not art, have fashion'd,
And, as ye read, instruct.

She tells you, Madam, simple truth,
In graceful numbers dressed;
And that in woman's capablities
There is a magnetic force
Which, if it favorably fall,
May attract and captivate;
'Twill do ye good when you are old,
Will comfort ye when sick,
Will cheer ye when ye loathe your food,
And do ye more than physic:
And, as ye read, instruct.

She bids you love your Husband dear,
And love your Children too;
And, ever acting up to them,
Be loved by all, as you shall be
When time shall her instructions prove;
And, if her artless song may be
Believed, she loves you;
And, as ye read, instructs.

She thanks you for your late kindness,
And returns you yours;
And, if this first-fruit of her brain
Can boast aught rare or handsome,
It is your lovely gift,
Which, as it first adorns her,
Would make her still, if she can,
More worthy of your favors;
And, as she reads, instructs.

Thyagaraja - Birth Of A Saint

Carnatic music's immortal triumvirate,
A trinity of brothers, divine,

The saintly composer Tyagaraja,

Chinnaiah taught him the basics of music,

under the doyens of the day.

In Chennai, he sought the blessings,
Of the musical trinity,
Of Sadasiva Brahmendra, the 84 year old,
Musician and composer.

Sadasiva Brahmendra had composed,
many songs in Sanskrit,
Tyagaraja picked them up,
And learnt them by heart.

When he went back to Tiruvaiyaru,
He started to sing them in the local temple,
The songs gained immense popularity,
And came to be known as Treya Samhara.

Tyagaraja became a celebrated musician,

In favour of his favourite deity,
And became a priest in the temple of,
Lord Rama in Tiruvaiyaru.

Once, when he was conducting the annual celebrations,
In the temple,
A musical discussion took place,
Between him and his two brothers,
Chinnaiah and Sathyanatha.

Tyagaraja composed and sang,
a song which came to be known as,
Navaratna Malika,
in honour of his elder brother,
Chinnaiah.

The song consisted of nine gems,
or sections,
And became instantly popular.

At the end of the celebrations,
Tyagaraja announced his decision,
To give up music for ever,
And returned to his priestly duties.

But music haunted him day and night,

It Is Always A Loss When A Friend Is Gone
By Emily Elizabeth Dickinson

After a loved one dies,
It is not hard to find,
People who knew them,
Affirming they were kind,

But it happens,
In a wind that blows,
Through a door half open,
As a signal of separations to be gone,
That anyone at all,
Feels the breeze that closes it.

It is not the presence of a friend,
As though his company,
Were a fontanel always sore,
Close to the temple, needing a bandage,
Always and evermore.

It is when one is gone,
That the sudden splinter,
Knifes you from behind,
As an army in the field,
Salutes, instinctive, when the chief,

Whistles for his troops to march,
That whips the blood of the remotest,
Were it only for a day,
It is always a loss when a friend is gone.

Sure I'm a soldier bold, and dare anything,
Then take me, an example to the troops,
Where they shall find me in the front of fame,
Placing my life in arms, with joy I view
The scattering soldiers, running from the foe,
Whom I pursue, and strike them as they run,
Halting their flight, and turning them again;
Ev'n in the trenches, I can make men blush,
Plunging my sword arm, deep in mortal stroke,
Aiding the brave, who strike beneath the brow,
Whom I attend, and always nearest stand
When they do charge, then swiftly turn me round,
And as I turn, face all the foe's alarms,
Whose shot, and arrows, whizzing round my head,
Serve only to enchant my eager mind,
As all their arts are only vain pretence,
Ev'n then I smile, and all their terrors tame;
As bravely they disperse, I follow pace,
And when their swiftest runners faint and blow,
Then fainting they for weariness do lie,
I rally up, and force them to the fight;
Then handle arms with the most hardy crew,
And ever foremost, where the bullets fly,
There you shall see me, spite of all their shot;
O 'tis a joy to die, fighting for fame;
It is a glorious thing, to be obeyed;
And 'tis a glorious thing to conquer by
The force of valour, and by heaven believed,
When envy does but mention my name,
They spitefully call me, madman, fool and knave,
But if the injurious tongue do wound my fame,
I scorn it, and despise the shallow slave;
For none but soldiers, well can understand
The brave, and valiant, who in fields do stand;
And 'tis a joy to live, so to be known,
And 'tis a glorious death, to be renowned.

I'm dying inside,

And I pretend everything's okay.

A nation stays alive when its culture stays alive
When its speeches stays loud, and its arguments stay loud,
When its emancipators preach with fervor from its podiums,
When its history is taught with fire in its classrooms,
When its artists are honored, and its musicians are jamming,
When its writers are read, and its movies are watched,
When its sports are celebrated, and its holidays are celebrated,
When its past is remembered, and its future is awaited.

But a nation can be sold when its culture is sold,
When its heritage is pawned, and its history is told,
When its icons are compromised, and its leaders are sold,
When its people are controlled, and its pillars are hollow,
When its books are banned, and its pictures are burned,
When its songs are rewrote, and its flags are flown,
When "Go West" is taught as "Go East," and "Freedom" is not free.

So, the selling of a nation is the selling of its culture
Its history's chain is broken, and its core is uprooted,
From the minds of its youth, to the mouths of its elders,
From the cries of its warriors to the plights of its healers,
From the songs of its poets to the strokes of its painters,
From the blood of its fathers to the milk of its mothers,
It is no longer a nation, but a commodity.

When the dark comes down
When lights are low,
When the flick'ring shadows
Softly come and go,
When the quietness encloses
Me, and hush falls everywhere,
Speak to me low and tender,
As thou dost know.

When the dark comes down
O, sweet and low,
Sing to me, dear lady,
Softly as thou canst;
Sing to me till the morning
Stars peep o'er the hill,
Sing to me 'til the daylight
Comes, and the bird sings his "good-morrow"
To the shining sun.

When the dark comes down
And wraps me 'round,
Sometimes I fear the darkness,
Which hides each darling face;
But the morning stars are shining
O'er me night and day,
And the angels bending near me
Whisper, "Sorrow! Sorrow!
Go thy way!"

When the dark comes down
O, sweet and low,
Sing to me, dear lady,
Till the daylight come;
And, dear heart, be thy singing
Soft and low and clear,
Till the first bird's note thro' the darkness
Bears thee on thy way.

There is no record of the author of this poem. It was published in 1913.

Speaking of work, a plumber stated: 
"I'd rather be chewing tobacco and scratching my ass than fixing your toilet with a wrench." 
Speaking of work, a secretary gloated: 
"I enjoy my coffee break, having my nails done and chatting with my friends." 
Speaking of work, a lawyer said: 
"I'd prefer to be playing golf or fishing instead of always drafting and arguing in court." 
Speaking of work, a politician fibbed: 
"Making laws for this state and others drives me nuts, but I love every minute of it." 
Speaking of work, a doctor confessed: 
"Instead of healing the sick and injured, I'd rather be playing golf or fishing too." 
And so on, and so on.

It is a truth that bears repeating:
We work altogether too much
And play altogether too little.

We will answer to God for every idle moment we have refused to occupy with good, honest labor.
In the eyes of God, idleness is a serious matter.

Ingredients:
1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour
1/4 cup chopped fresh rosemary
1/2 cup kalamata olives, pitted and chopped
1/4 cup extra virgin olive oil
1 cup warm water
1/4 teaspoon salt

Instructions:
1. Preheat oven to 450 degrees F (230 degrees C).
2. In a large bowl, combine flour, rosemary, olives, olive oil, water, and salt. Mix until a sticky dough forms.
3. Transfer the dough to a well-oiled 9x13 inch baking pan. Press the dough into the pan, spreading it to the edges.
4. Bake for 20 minutes, or until the top is golden brown.
5. Let cool slightly, then cut into pieces and serve.

Ingredients
   2 cups flour
   1 teaspoon baking powder
   1/4 teaspoon ground cinnamon
   1/4 teaspoon ground allspice
   1/2 cup chopped dried pineapple
   1/4 cup golden raisins
   1 1/2 cups bread flour
   1/4 cup sugar
   1/2 cup mashed ripe banana
   1/3 cup butter
   1/3 cup milk
   1 egg

Instructions
   Mix together flour, baking powder, cinnamon, and allspice in a large bowl. Stir in dried pineapple and raisins.
   In a separate large bowl, combine bread flour and sugar. Rub in butter until mixture resembles coarse crumbs.
   Stir in milk and egg until mixture forms a soft dough. Add flour mixture and knead until smooth.
   Divide dough into 15 pieces and shape into balls. Place balls in a greased 9x13 inch baking pan.
   Beat together egg and water and brush some on top of each bun.
   Bake in preheated oven at 375 degrees F (190 degrees C) for 20 minutes.

Ingredients 
1 pound ground turkey
1 small onion, finely chopped
2 tablespoons olive oil
3 cloves garlic, minced
1 28 oz can crushed tomatoes
1 15 oz can tomato sauce
1 teaspoon dried basil
1 teaspoon dried oregano
1 teaspoon salt
1/2 teaspoon ground black pepper
1 cup red wine
1 cup beef broth

Instructions
1. Heat olive oil in a large saucepan over medium heat. Add the chopped onion and saut until tender, about 5 minutes. Stir in garlic and saut 1 additional minute.
2. Stir in ground turkey and break apart with a wooden spoon. Cook until browned, about 10 minutes.
3. Stir in crushed tomatoes, tomato sauce, basil, oregano, salt, pepper, red wine, and beef broth. Bring the mixture to a boil.
4. Cover the pot and reduce the heat to low. Simmer for 30 minutes, stirring occasionally.
5. Serve over cooked spaghetti.

Ingredients 
6 cups water
3 cups baby potatoes (about 1 1/2 pounds)
1/2 cup mayonnaise
1/4 cup sour cream
1/4 cup chopped chives
1 1/2 teaspoons Dijon mustard
1 1/2 teaspoons white wine vinegar
1/2 teaspoon salt
1/4 teaspoon black pepper
2 cups chopped hard-boiled eggs
1 cup chopped celery

Preparation
1. Bring 6 cups water to a boil in a large pot. Add potatoes, and return to a boil. Reduce heat, and simmer until potatoes are just tender, about 15 minutes. Drain, and let cool. Cut into 1/2-inch slices.
2. In a large bowl, stir together mayonnaise, sour cream, chives, mustard, vinegar, salt, and pepper. Stir in eggs and celery. Add potatoes, and toss gently to coat. Cover, and refrigerate at least 4 hours, or overnight. Serve cold.

Cream of the Crop Vegetable Fricassee with Fried Toast Points

Ingredients

1 cup thinly sliced carrots
1 cup frozen green peas
1 cup small fresh broccoli flowerets
1/2 cup thinly sliced fresh mushrooms
1/4 cup finely chopped shallots
2 tablespoons butter
2 tablespoons all-purpose flour
1 1/2 cups chicken broth
1/2 cup heavy cream
1/4 teaspoon salt
1/4 teaspoon black pepper
4 slices bread
2 tablespoons butter, melted

Instructions

1. Preheat the oven to 450 degrees F (230 degrees C).
2. In a saucepan, combine the carrots, peas, broccoli, mushrooms, and shallots. Cover with water, bring to a boil, and cook until the vegetables are tender, about 15 minutes. Drain and set aside.
3. In the same saucepan, melt the butter over medium heat. Stir in the flour and cook for 2 minutes to make a roux. Slowly stir in the chicken broth and cook, stirring constantly, until the sauce is thickened and bubbly, about 5 minutes. Stir in the heavy cream, salt, and pepper. Stir in the vegetables and heat through.
4. While the sauce is cooking, arrange the bread slices on a baking sheet and brush with the melted butter. Bake for 5 minutes, or until golden brown. Serve with the vegetable sauce.

To make this pumpkin walnut cake, you will need the following ingredients:

- 1 cup all-purpose flour
- 1 cup sugar
- 3 teaspoons baking powder
- 1/2 teaspoon baking soda
- 1 teaspoon salt
- 1 cup canned or cooked pumpkin puree
- 3 eggs
- 1/2 cup butter, melted
- 1 teaspoon vanilla extract
- 1 cup chopped walnuts

Here is the recipe instructions:

1. Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease and flour one 9x13 inch baking pan.

2. In a large bowl, combine flour, sugar, baking powder, baking soda, and salt. In a separate bowl, whisk together pumpkin puree, eggs, butter, and vanilla extract. Add wet ingredients to dry ingredients and mix just until combined. Stir in walnuts. Spread batter into prepared pan.

3. Bake in the preheated oven for 30 to 35 minutes, or until a toothpick inserted into the center of the cake comes out clean. Cool cake before serving.

Ingredients
   3 cups chopped cooked chicken
   15 ounces black beans, rinsed and drained
   11 ounces corn, drained if canned
   1 cup chopped fresh cilantro
   1 cup shredded Mexican cheese blend
   2 garlic cloves, minced
   1 tablespoon olive oil
   2 teaspoons chili powder
   1 teaspoon ground cumin
   1 teaspoon dried oregano
   1 teaspoon salt
   1/2 teaspoon crushed red pepper flakes
   8 large flour tortillas
   3 cups salsa
   2 cups shredded Mexican cheese blend

Instructions
   Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
   Combine chicken, beans, corn, cilantro, 1 cup cheese blend, garlic, olive oil, chili powder, cumin, oregano, salt, and red pepper flakes in a large bowl.
   Place about 1/3 cup chicken mixture in the center of each tortilla.
   Roll up tortillas and place them seam-side down in a 9x13-inch baking dish.
   Pour salsa over the top of the rolled tortillas and sprinkle with cheese.
   Bake 20 minutes, or until cheese is melted.
   Serve with sour cream and avocado slices, if desired.

This recipe yields 8 enchiladas.

Ingredients
   3 1/2 cups milk
   2 tablespoons unsweetened cocoa powder
   2 tablespoons sugar
   4 teaspoons cornstarch
   1/2 teaspoon vanilla extract
   Dash ground cinnamon
   pinch salt

Instructions
   Heat milk, cocoa powder, sugar, cornstarch, vanilla, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat, stirring frequently, until mixture boils.
   Reduce heat, and simmer until thickened, about 5 minutes.
   Pour into mugs, and serve.
Those with a sweet tooth may want to sprinkle some chocolate powder on top, or add a marshmallow.

For the crust:
1 cup all-purpose flour
1/2 cup finely chopped walnuts
1/2 cup butter, melted
1/4 cup sugar
1 1/2 teaspoons ground cinnamon

For the filling:
8 slices bacon, diced
1/2 cup chopped onion
1 cup grated cheddar cheese
1 (3-ounce) package cream cheese, softened
3 large eggs
1 cup half and half
1/2 teaspoon salt
1/4 teaspoon black pepper

Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).

In a small bowl, combine the flour, walnuts, butter, sugar, and cinnamon. Mix well and press into a 9-inch quiche dish. Bake for 10 minutes, or until lightly browned.

While the crust is baking, fry the bacon over medium heat until crisp. Remove with a slotted spoon and drain on paper towels. Discard all but 1 tablespoon of the bacon fat, and saut the onion over medium heat until tender.

In a medium bowl, beat the cream cheese until smooth. Add the eggs and beat until well blended. Stir in the half and half, salt, and pepper. Stir in the bacon, onion, and cheese. Pour the mixture into the baked crust.

Bake for 30 to 35 minutes, or until a knife inserted 1 inch from the center comes out clean. Let stand for 5 minutes before serving.

Ingredients:
1 cup all-purpose flour
1 cup sugar
3/4 cup butter
1 egg
1 cup sour cream
1 teaspoon baking powder
1/2 teaspoon baking soda
1/4 teaspoon salt
1 1/2 cups strawberry halves
optional: 1 cup heavy or whipping cream

Instructions:
1. Preheat oven to 300 degrees F (150 degrees C). Grease and flour a 9x5 inch loaf pan.
2. In a large bowl, combine sugar and butter. Beat with an electric mixer on medium to high speed for 30 seconds. Add egg and beat well. Add flour, baking powder, baking soda, and salt. Beat until just combined. Add sour cream or yogurt and beat well. Pour into prepared loaf pan.
3. Bake in preheated oven for 60 to 65 minutes, or until a toothpick inserted into the center of the cake comes out clean. Cool cake in pan on a wire rack for 10 minutes. Remove cake from pan and cool completely on wire rack. Cut into slices and top with strawberries and cream.

This recipe is for a cream cheese pound cake with strawberries and cream. It is a simple recipe that can be made in a few steps. The cake is moist and dense, with a creamy texture from the cream cheese. The strawberries add a sweet and tart flavor to the cake, while the cream adds a rich and creamy texture. This is a great dessert for any occasion, and it is sure to be a hit with everyone.

Vegetable Salad in Squash Seed Sauce

Ingredients
1 pound winter squash, peeled, seeded, and cut into bite-size pieces
1 cup vegetable oil
1/2 cup shelled raw pumpkin seeds
1/4 cup chopped fresh cilantro
1/2 teaspoon ground cumin
1/4 teaspoon ground allspice
1/2 teaspoon salt
1/4 teaspoon black pepper
2 cups torn leaf lettuce
1 cup chopped tomato
1/2 cup chopped green bell pepper
1/2 cup chopped red bell pepper
1/2 cup chopped yellow bell pepper

Instructions
1. In a small skillet, toast the pumpkin seeds over medium heat, stirring frequently, until lightly browned, 7 to 10 minutes.
2. In a blender, process the seeds, squash, cilantro, cumin, allspice, salt, and black pepper until smooth.
3. In a large bowl, combine the lettuce, tomato, and bell peppers.
4. Pour the seed sauce over the vegetables and toss to coat.
5. Serve immediately.

Ingredients 
4 eggs
1 cup milk
1/2 cup sugar
1 teaspoon vanilla extract
1/8 teaspoon salt
6 slices bread
6 thin slices ham
6 thin slices Gruyere cheese

Instructions
1. In a large bowl, whisk together eggs, milk, sugar, vanilla extract and salt. Dip bread slices into the egg mixture, turning once until bread is saturated.
2. Heat a large skillet over medium heat. Grease the skillet with butter. Place bread slices in the skillet and cook until the bread is golden brown on both sides. Remove from skillet and keep warm.
3. To assemble sandwiches, place a slice of ham and a slice of cheese on top of each slice of bread. Top with another slice of bread to make a sandwich.
4. Wipe skillet clean with a paper towel, then grease with more butter and repeat with remaining bread slices. Serve immediately.

Millionaires Shortbread Ingredients 
1 cup butter, softened 
1/2 cup granulated sugar 
1/2 cup brown sugar, packed 
1 teaspoon vanilla extract 
1 egg 
2 cups all-purpose flour 
1/2 cup cocoa powder 
1/8 teaspoon salt

For the Topping
1 cup semisweet chocolate chips 
1/2 cup chopped pecans

Filling
1/2 cup butter, softened 
1/4 cup granulated sugar 
1/4 cup brown sugar, packed 
1/4 cup milk 
1/3 cup all-purpose flour

Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). 

In a large bowl, cream together 1 cup butter and granulated sugar until smooth. Then add the 1/2 cup brown sugar and 1 teaspoon vanilla extract and beat until fluffy. Beat in the egg until well combined.

In a separate bowl, combine 2 cups flour, 1/2 cup cocoa powder, and 1/8 teaspoon salt. Stir into the butter-egg mixture until just combined. Press into a 9x13 inch baking pan.

For the topping, scatter the 1 cup semisweet chocolate chips and 1/2 cup pecans over the crust. 

In a separate bowl, beat together 1/2 cup butter, 1/4 cup granulated sugar, 1/4 cup brown sugar, and 1/4 cup milk. Stir in 1/3 cup flour until well combined. Drop by spoonfuls over the chocolate chips and nuts. 

Bake for 25 to 30 minutes, or until set. Cool completely before cutting into bars.

Pasta with Guanciale, Radicchio and Ricotta

Ingredients
 400g guanciale (cured pork cheeks), diced
 200g radicchio, shredded
 500g ricotta cheese
 700g spaghetti
 1 egg
 50g grated parmesan
 handful of chopped parsley
 few sprigs of thyme, leaves picked
  lemon

Method
1. Bring a large pot of salted water to a boil.
2. In a large pan, fry the guanciale over a medium heat until golden and crispy. Add the radicchio and fry for another minute. Turn off the heat and stir in the ricotta.
3. Cook the spaghetti in the boiling water until al dente. Drain, reserving a cup of the cooking water.
4. In a small bowl, whisk together the egg, parmesan, parsley, thyme leaves and a good squeeze of lemon juice.
5. Add the spaghetti to the guanciale and radicchio pan, then pour over the egg mixture and toss everything together, adding a splash of the cooking water to loosen the sauce.
6. Serve in bowls with lots of black pepper.

Ingredients 
1 cup granulated sugar
1 cup butter, softened
1 cup milk
1 teaspoon vanilla extract
2 eggs
3 cups flour
1 teaspoon baking powder
1/2 teaspoon baking soda
1 teaspoon salt
2 cups uncooked quick-cooking oatmeal

Frosting
3 tablespoons butter, softened
3 tablespoons milk
1/2 cup granulated sugar
1/2 cup powdered sugar
1/2 teaspoon vanilla extract

Instructions
1. Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease and flour one 9x13 inch baking pan.
2. In a large bowl, cream together sugar and butter. Add milk, vanilla, and eggs and beat well.
3. In a medium bowl, combine flour, baking powder, baking soda, and salt. Add flour mixture to the wet ingredients, stirring just until combined. Fold in oatmeal. Pour into prepared pan.
4. Bake at 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) for 30 minutes, or until a toothpick inserted into the center of the cake comes out clean. Cool cake before serving.
To make the frosting: In a small bowl, combine butter, milk, sugar, and vanilla extract. Beat until smooth. Spread over cooled cake.

Sicilian Supper 

Ingredients
2 cups cubed cooked chicken or turkey
1/2 cup chopped pitted green olives

1/2 cup mayonnaise

Healthy Spaghetti

Ingredients
1 pound spaghetti
1 (28 ounce) can whole tomatoes
1/4 cup chopped onion
2 tablespoons chopped fresh parsley
1 teaspoon olive oil
1/2 teaspoon salt
1/4 teaspoon black pepper

Instructions
1. Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
2. Cook spaghetti according to package instructions.
3. Meanwhile, in a large saucepan, combine tomatoes, onion, parsley, olive oil, salt, and pepper.
4. Bring to a boil, and remove from heat.
5. When spaghetti is done, drain and add to saucepan with tomato mixture.

This dish is a healthier version of traditional spaghetti, as it uses whole tomatoes and olive oil instead of a tomato sauce and butter. It's a simple and quick recipe that's perfect for a weeknight meal.

Ingredients
   3 tomatoes, halved
   1/2 medium white onion, peeled and halved
   2 garlic cloves, unpeeled
   2 jalapeno peppers, stemmed
   Olive oil, enough to coat the vegetables
   1/2 teaspoon salt
   1/2 teaspoon black pepper

Instructions
   Preheat an outdoor grill or grill pan to medium-high heat.
   Brush the cut sides of the tomatoes, onion halves, garlic, and jalapenos with olive oil.
   Place the vegetables on the grill, cut side down, and cook without moving until they are charred, about 5 minutes.
   Flip the vegetables and char the other side, about 5 more minutes.
   Remove the vegetables from the grill and let cool for about 10 minutes.
   Peel the garlic and place it in a food processor with the jalapenos. Process until almost smooth.
   Add the tomatoes and onion and process until almost smooth.
   Pour the mixture into a bowl and stir in the salt and pepper.
   Serve with tortilla chips.

Portabella Mushrooms on Tomato Basil Fettuccini 

Ingredients
1 lb fettuccini pasta
1/2 cup butter
1/2 lb fresh mushrooms, sliced
1/2 lb fresh tomato, chopped
1/2 cup fresh basil, chopped
1/2 cup freshly grated parmesan cheese

Instructions
Cook fettuccini al dente, drain and set aside. In a large skillet, melt butter over medium-high heat. Add mushrooms and tomato. Cook, stirring occasionally, until liquid evaporates and mushrooms are golden brown. Stir in basil. Serve over fettuccini, garnishing with Parmesan cheese.

Ingredients
   None

Instructions
   Take about 2 tablespoons of anpan dough and shape into a ball in your hands. Press your thumb deep into the center of the dough ball to make an indentation (this will be where the sweet bean paste goes).
   Place onto a baking sheet (with parchment paper if desired for easy cleanup). Repeat until you have used up all of the dough.
   Fill the indentation with sweet bean paste (about 1 teaspoon or so per dough ball). Be careful not to overfill or the bean paste will leak out and burn during baking.
   Top with black sesame seeds.
   Bake in preheated oven at 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) for 15 minutes. The underbelly should be golden brown.
   Remove from oven and let cool slightly before eating. Can be served warm or at room temperature.

Description
   This is a basic anpan recipe that produces plump and fluffy treats with just the right amount of sweetness to the bread and a delicious bean paste filling. For even fluffier bread, you can try the Tangzhong method- see the advanced recipe for details. 

Ingredient Substitutions
   Sweet bean paste: You can use storebought sweet bean paste (also known as anko) or make your own. If you are making your own, you will need about 1 1/2 cups of cooked adzuki beans (tinned or prepared from dry beans) and 1/2 cup of sugar. Mash the beans together with the sugar and a splash of water (enough to make the mixture smooth and paste-like) and proceed with the recipe.
   Black sesame seeds: You can find bagged black sesame seeds in the Asian foods section of larger supermarkets or at Asian markets. You can also use white sesame seeds if you prefer.
   Anpan dough: Anpan dough is simply sweet bread dough. You can use any sweet bread dough from a recipe you like (including dough prepared from a bread machine recipe or a packaged mix). Make sure the dough is not too thin or the anpan will not have a nice, plump appearance.

Easter Basket Cake
  
This is a fun project to do with kids, but you need to make the cake and frosting the night before you plan to serve it. It is sure to bring lots of "oohs and ahs" when you carry it to the table. It's a great conversation piece, and you can eat the eggs and grass!

Ingredients

1 cup all-purpose flour
1 cup sugar
3 tablespoons baking powder
1/2 teaspoon salt
1 1/2 cups whole milk
1/2 cup vegetable oil
3 eggs
1 cup dry coconut
1 cup chopped walnuts
1 cup chocolate candy coating, chopped
1 cup pastel candy coating, chopped

Instructions

1. Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease and flour one 9x13 inch baking pan.
2. In a large bowl, combine flour, sugar, baking powder and salt. Add milk, oil and eggs; mix well. Stir in coconut and walnuts. Pour into prepared pan.
3. Bake at 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) for 35 minutes, or until a toothpick inserted into the center of the cake comes out clean. Cool cake completely in pan on a wire rack.
4. When cake is cool, frost the top with Cream Cheese Frosting. Press chocolate candy coating pieces into the frosting to form a basket weave pattern. Press pastel candy coating pieces into the frosting to form an outer edge to the basket. Place the eggs, grass and bunny in the center of the cake. Store in the refrigerator.

Cream Cheese Frosting

1/2 cup butter, softened
1/2 package (8 ounces) cream cheese, softened
1/2 cup milk
1 teaspoon vanilla extract
3 cups powdered sugar

Instructions

1. In a large bowl, beat butter and cream cheese until smooth. Stir in milk and vanilla. Gradually stir in powdered sugar until frosting is smooth.

1/2 pound medium shrimp, peeled and deveined

3. Add the noodles and the soy sauce mixture to the skillet, and stir until the noodles are evenly coated and heated through. Serve immediately and enjoy!

Ingredients
   3 medium beets, unpeeled and cut into -inch cubes (~1  cups)
   3 tablespoons olive oil, divided
    teaspoon salt, divided
    teaspoon ground black pepper, divided
    cup shelled pistachios, coarsely chopped
   4 ounces goat cheese, crumbled into small pieces
   3 tablespoons fresh lemon juice
   1 tablespoon white balsamic vinegar
   1 tablespoon honey
    teaspoon Dijon mustard
    teaspoon crushed red pepper flakes
   2 cups arugula leaves

Instructions
   Preheat the oven to 400 degrees F (200 degrees C).
   Place the beets on a rimmed baking sheet. Add 1 tablespoon of the olive oil,  of the salt, and  of the black pepper, and toss to coat. Spread the beets into a single layer and roast until tender when pierced with a toothpick or fork, about 20 minutes.
   Meanwhile, in a small skillet, toast the pistachios over medium heat, stirring frequently, until just golden, about 3 minutes. Remove from the heat and set aside to cool for 5 minutes.
   In a small bowl, whisk together the lemon juice, vinegar, honey, mustard, red pepper flakes, and remaining salt and black pepper until well combined. While still whisking, slowly drizzle in the remaining 2 tablespoons olive oil until emulsified. Set aside.
   When the beets are tender, remove them from the oven and let cool for 5 minutes. Transfer to a medium bowl and drizzle with the dressing. Add the arugula and gently toss to combine. Transfer to a serving plate and top with the goat cheese and pistachios. Serve immediately.

Ingredients
   3 eggs, beaten 

   1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour

   1 tablespoon baking powder

   1/2 teaspoon salt

   2 cups milk

   2 tablespoons butter, melted

   Directions
   In a large bowl, whisk together eggs, flour, baking powder and salt. In another bowl, whisk together milk and butter. Add milk mixture to flour mixture; whisk until just combined.
   Heat a well-seasoned cast-iron or nonstick ebelskiver pan over medium heat. Add 1/4 cup batter to each well. Cook until the bottoms are golden brown and bubbles begin to form on the surface, about 3 minutes. Use 2 toothpicks to turn the pancakes. Cook until the second side is golden brown, another 2 to 3 minutes. Repeat with the remaining batter.
   Dust with confectioners' sugar and serve with jam and butter.

Note
The recipe for Danish Ebelskivers originated in Europe, and it is a traditional dish that has been passed down through generations. It is a delicious and easy-to-make breakfast dish that is perfect for any occasion. 

These pancakes are an enjoyable treat for kids especially with the fun, flipped-cone shape and they can be made ahead and frozen for longer-term storage. For adults, they can be dressed up with fruit, jam, nut butter, or yogurt for a sweet breakfastor go the savory route with veggies, cheese, and meat.

Ingredients
   1 large eggplant, peeled and cut into 1-inch cubes
   2 cups zucchini cut into 1/2-inch cubes
   1 cup peeled and diced tomatoes
   1/2 cup chopped onion
   1/2 cup chopped green bell pepper
   1/2 cup chopped black olives
   2 cloves garlic, minced
   1/4 cup olive oil
   1/2 teaspoon dried basil
   1/2 teaspoon dried oregano
   1/2 teaspoon dried rosemary
   1/2 teaspoon salt
   1/4 teaspoon black pepper

Instructions
   Bring a large pot of water to a boil over high heat. Add the eggplant and parboil for 2 minutes. Drain and set aside. In a large skillet over medium heat, cook and stir the onion, bell pepper and garlic in the olive oil until the onion is tender. Stir in the tomatoes, zucchini, olives, basil, oregano, rosemary, salt and black pepper. Simmer for 10 minutes, stirring occasionally. Add the eggplant and simmer for an additional 15 minutes, until all the vegetables are tender. Serve hot or cold.

Hobo Stew Recipe

Ingredients

1 cup chopped cooked beef

1/2 cup chopped onion

1/2 cup chopped green bell pepper

1 can (14.5 ounces) diced tomatoes

1 can (15 ounces) pinto beans

1/4 cup beef broth

1/2 teaspoon chili powder

1/4 teaspoon salt

1/4 teaspoon black pepper

Directions

1. In a large pot over medium-high heat, combine all ingredients.

2. Bring to a boil, then reduce heat to low and simmer for 30 minutes, or until flavors are blended and stew is heated through.

3. Serve immediately, or let cool and store in an airtight container in the refrigerator for up to 4 days.

This hearty stew is a quick and easy meal that's perfect for busy nights. Simply combine all the ingredients in a pot and let them simmer together for a satisfying and flavorful dish. It's a great way to use up any leftover beef you have on hand, and the combination of tomatoes, beans, and beef broth creates a delicious and nutritious broth.

Zodiac Cake - Allrecipes.com

Prep time: 10 Minutes

Cook time: 25 Minutes

Circumstance: Birthday

Special equipment: 1-quart rectangular or oval baking dish, 9 x 9-inch baking pan

Ingredients:

1/2 cup butter

1 cup white (granulated) sugar

2 eggs

1/2 cup milk

1/2 teaspoon vanilla extract

1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour

1/2 teaspoon baking powder

1/4 teaspoon salt

Frosting:

1/2 cup butter

1/4 cup milk

1 1/2 cups powdered sugar

1/2 teaspoon vanilla extract

Directions:

Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease a 9 x 9-inch baking pan.

In a large bowl, cream 1/2 cup butter and sugar until smooth. Then add 1 egg at a time, beating well after each. Add 1/2 cup milk and 1/2 teaspoon vanilla extract.

In a separate bowl, combine 1 1/2 cups flour, 1/2 teaspoon baking powder, and 1/4 teaspoon salt. Add the dry ingredients to the wet ingredients and beat until just combined. Pour into the prepared pan.

Bake at 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) for 25 minutes, or until a toothpick inserted into the center of the cake comes out clean. Cool cake before serving. 

To make the frosting: Combine 1/2 cup butter, 1/4 cup milk, 1 1/2 cups powdered sugar, and 1/2 teaspoon vanilla extract in a bowl. Beat until smooth. Frost the cooled cake.

This recipe yields one 9 x 9-inch cake.

Ingredients:
1 pound beef sirloin
1/2 pound prosciutto
1/2 pound mozzarella cheese
1/2 pound fresh spinach
4 tablespoons olive oil
3 cloves garlic, minced
1/2 cup milk
1 cup bread crumbs
1/2 teaspoon salt
1/4 teaspoon black pepper
1/4 teaspoon nutmeg

Instructions:
1. Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
2. Slice beef sirloin into twelve 1/4 inch thick slices.
3. Lay slices of prosciutto on top of each slice of beef.
4. Slice mozzarella into twelve 1/4 inch thick slices. Lay on top of prosciutto.
5. Take a handful of spinach and place on top of mozzarella. Roll up and secure with a toothpick.
6. Repeat until all the beef has been used.
7. Heat olive oil in a large skillet over medium-high heat.
8. Cook rolled beef in batches until brown on all sides. Remove and keep warm.
9. Add garlic to the skillet and cook for 1 minute.
10. Stir in milk and bring to a boil. Stir in bread crumbs, salt, pepper and nutmeg.
11. Return beef rolls to the skillet and spoon sauce over the top.
12. Cover and bake for 45 minutes.

Durgin Park Baked Beans  
 
Preheat oven to 325 degrees F (165 degrees C).

In a large bowl, combine the beans, onion, bacon, salt, pepper, syrup, and mustard. Transfer the mixture to a shallow baking dish. Pour the beer over the top, and stir gently.

Bake uncovered for 2 to 2 1/2 hours, or until the beans are tender, but still hold their shape. There should be about 1/4 inch of liquid in the bottom of the dish. If necessary, bake uncovered for an additional 15 minutes.

Ingredients
   2 sheets frozen puff pastry, thawed
   1/2 cup butter
   1/2 cup all-purpose flour
   1/2 teaspoon salt
   1/4 teaspoon white pepper
   1/4 teaspoon ground nutmeg
   1/2 cup dry white wine
   2 cups seafood stock
   1 pound medium shrimp, peeled and deveined
   1/2 pound bay scallops
   1/2 cup chopped fresh parsley

Instructions
   Melt butter in a large skillet over medium heat. Stir in flour, salt, white pepper, and nutmeg. Cook for 2 minutes. Gradually stir in wine and stock. Bring to a boil; cook and stir for 2 minutes. Add shrimp and scallops; reduce heat, and simmer until shrimp are pink and scallops are opaque, about 5 minutes. Stir in parsley.
   Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C). Line a baking sheet with parchment paper.
   Roll out 1 sheet of puff pastry to 1/8-inch thickness; cut into twelve 3-inch circles. Press circles into the bottoms of twelve ungreased muffin cups. Spoon equal amounts of shrimp mixture into each cup.
   Roll out second sheet of puff pastry; cut into twelve 3-inch circles. Place over filling; press edges to seal. Cut small slits in top to allow steam to escape. Bake until puffed and golden brown, about 15 minutes. Cool for 10 minutes before serving.

White Asparagus with Hollandaise Sauce 

Ingredients

1/3 cup white wine
1/3 cup white wine vinegar
1 shallot, finely chopped
1/2 teaspoon black peppercorns
1/2 cup unsalted butter
4 eggs, separated
1/2 teaspoon salt
1/2 pound white asparagus

Instructions

1. In a small saucepan, combine white wine, white wine vinegar, shallot, and black peppercorns. Bring to a boil over high heat, then reduce to a simmer and cook until reduced by half, about 5 minutes. Strain through a fine-mesh strainer into a small bowl, discarding shallot and peppercorns.

2. In a separate small saucepan, melt butter over low heat. Skim foam from top, and remove from heat.

3. In a medium saucepan, bring 4 cups water to a boil. Reduce heat to medium-low, and keep at a simmer.

4. Fill a medium saucepan with water and bring to a boil. Salt the water, then add asparagus and cook until tender but still bright green, about 2 minutes. Transfer to a plate lined with a paper towel and keep warm.

5. Fill a medium saucepan with water and bring to a simmer. Add egg yolks and salt, and whisk constantly until yolks are thickened and pale yellow, about 6 minutes. Remove from heat.

6. Whisk in butter, 1 tablespoon at a time, until combined. Whisk in wine reduction. Transfer to a large bowl set over a pot of simmering water, and keep warm.

7. In a clean dry bowl, beat egg whites to soft peaks. Gently fold into hollandaise.

8. Plate asparagus and spoon hollandaise over tips.

Ingredients
     lb. salmon fillet, cut into 4 pieces
     cup chopped fresh dill
     cup mayonnaise
    1 tsp. lemon juice
     tsp. salt
     tsp. black pepper

The dish is quick and easy to make, and it's a healthy and flavorful choice for a weeknight meal. It's a good source of protein and healthy fats, and the dill sauce adds a fresh and tangy flavor.

1 egg

1/4 teaspoon salt
1/2 cup milk

For the Topping

For the Frosting
