Ingredients
    6 large dried red chili peppers
    1/4 cup soy sauce
    1 tablespoon peeled and grated fresh ginger
    1 tablespoon olive oil
    2 teaspoons black bean garlic sauce
    1/2 teaspoon ground turmeric
    1/2 teaspoon ground coriander
    1/2 teaspoon ground cumin
    1/2 teaspoon five-spice powder
    1 large egg
    1 pound boneless skinless chicken thighs, cut into 1-inch cubes
    2 tablespoons all-purpose flour
    2 tablespoons water

Instructions
    1. Soak dried red chili peppers in hot water for 10 minutes to soften. Wear gloves when preparing chili peppers and wash hands well after handling. Remove stems, seeds and veins from the peppers. Mince peppers and set aside.
    2. In a small bowl, combine soy sauce, grated ginger, olive oil, black bean garlic sauce, turmeric, coriander, cumin and five-spice powder. Mix well and set aside.
    3. In a separate bowl, beat egg with 2 tablespoons water. Add chicken cubes and toss to coat evenly. Add flour and toss again to coat evenly.
    4. Heat wok or large skillet over medium-high heat. Add 2 tablespoons oil and swirl to coat sides. Add chicken cubes in small batches of 10 to 12 and brown on all sides, about 2 minutes per side. Chicken should be lightly browned but not cooked through. Remove from wok and set aside.
    5. Repeat until all chicken cubes are browned.
    6. Reduce heat to medium. Add garlic and ginger and stir-fry for no more than 10 seconds. Add onions and bell peppers and stir-fry for another 20 seconds.
    7. Add the soy sauce mixture and stir to combine. Add chicken cubes and stir gently to combine and coat with sauce.
    8. Cover and simmer for 4 minutes, stirring occasionally.
    9. Add minced chili peppers and stir gently to combine.
    10. Cover and simmer for another 4 minutes, stirring occasionally, or until chicken is cooked through.
    11. Serve with steamed rice.
 Variation: To make this a stew instead of a stir-fry, add 1 cup chicken stock after adding the soy sauce mixture and simmer until chicken is cooked through, about 8 minutes. Add chili peppers and simmer for another 2 minutes. This version is best served over rice noodles.

Achiote Marinated Shrimp Salad Recipe

Ingredients
1 pound medium shrimp, peeled and deveined
1/2 cup olive oil
1/4 cup white vinegar
1/4 cup lime juice
2 tablespoons achiote (or annatto) powder
1/2 teaspoon dried oregano
1/2 teaspoon ground cumin
1/2 teaspoon chili powder
1/2 teaspoon salt
1/4 teaspoon black pepper
1/4 teaspoon cayenne pepper
1/2 cup chopped green bell pepper
1/2 cup chopped red bell pepper
1/2 cup chopped white onion

Instructions
1. In a large bowl, combine the shrimp, olive oil, vinegar, lime juice, achiote powder, oregano, cumin, chili powder, salt, black pepper, and cayenne pepper. Let the shrimp marinate in the refrigerator for 30 minutes.
2. In a large skillet over medium heat, cook the shrimp for 2-3 minutes on each side, or until they are pink and thoroughly heated.
3. In a large bowl, combine the cooked shrimp, bell peppers, and onion. Mix well and serve cold.

This recipe contains 838 calories, 5 g of fat, 138 mg of cholesterol, 1038 mg of sodium, 92 g of carbohydrates, 4 g of fiber, 8 g of sugar, 68 g of protein, and 3.7 mg of iron.

The ingredients are:

1 cup all-purpose flour
1 teaspoon baking powder
1/2 teaspoon baking soda
1 teaspoon salt
1/2 teaspoon black pepper
2 cups buttermilk
4 pounds bone-in chicken pieces
1/4 cup vegetable oil
The instructions are:

1. In a large resealable plastic bag, combine flour, baking powder, baking soda, salt, and pepper. Add chicken pieces, one at a time, and shake to coat.
2. Pour buttermilk into a large bowl. Dip chicken pieces into buttermilk, then place in bag with flour mixture. Shake bag to coat evenly.
3. In a large skillet, heat oil over medium-high heat. Fry chicken in hot oil for 10 to 15 minutes on each side, or until golden brown.
4. Drain on paper towels.

Ingredients
   3 cups all-purpose flour
   2 cups granulated sugar, plus 1 tablespoon for patting pear slices
   1 teaspoon baking powder
   1/2 teaspoon baking soda
   1/2 teaspoon salt
   1/2 cup unsweetened cocoa powder
   1/2 cup buttermilk
   1/2 cup vegetable oil
   3 large eggs
   1 1/2 teaspoons vanilla extract
   1 1/2 teaspoons almond extract
   4 Firm but ripe pears, such as Red Anjou,Bartlett or Red Clapp's (about 2 1/2 pounds)
   1/4 cup chopped pecans
   1/4 cup semisweet chocolate chips

Instructions
   Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
   Grease and flour a 10-inch tube pan.
   In a large bowl, combine flour, 2 cups sugar, baking powder, baking soda and salt.
   In a large measuring cup, combine buttermilk, oil, eggs, vanilla and almond extracts.
   Add buttermilk mixture to flour mixture all at once and mix quickly with a wooden spoon. (Do not overmix; batter will be lumpy).
   Pour into prepared pan.
   Peel, halve and core pears. Slice each half into 6 to 8 lengthwise slices.
   Arrange pear slices in a decorative circular pattern on top of batter, pressing gently into batter.
   Sprinkle with chopped nuts and chocolate chips, then sprinkle with 1 tablespoon sugar.
   Bake in preheated oven for 60 to 70 minutes, or until a toothpick inserted into center of cake comes out clean.
   Cool cake in pan on a wire rack for 10 minutes, then remove from pan and finish cooling on wire rack.

Ingredients:
1/2 pound butter, 1 1/2 sticks
1/2 cup sugar
1/2 cup dark brown sugar
1/2 teaspoon salt
1 1/2 teaspoons ground cinnamon
1/4 teaspoon ground nutmeg
1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour
1 1/2 cups pecans, chopped

For the Pie:
1/4 cup sugar
1/4 cup cornstarch
1/2 teaspoon salt
2 1/2 to 2 3/4 pounds granny smith apples (about 3 1/2 to 4 cups when chopped)
1 tablespoon fresh lemon juice
1 (9-inch) deep dish pie plate
1 tablespoon butter, cut into small pieces

Instructions:
1. Preheat the oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. In a small bowl, mix together the sugar, flour, cinnamon, and nutmeg. Set aside.
3. In a large bowl, mix together the apples, lemon juice, and sugar mixture. Set aside.
4. In a medium bowl, mix together the butter, flour, and sugar. Set aside.
5. Line a 9-inch deep dish pie plate with half the pie dough.
6. Pour the apple mixture into the bottom crust. Drizzle with 1 tablespoon melted butter.
7. Using a rolling pin, roll out the remaining pie dough and cut into 1/2-inch strips.
8. Arrange the dough strips on top of the pie in a lattice design.
9. Trim and crimp the edges of the pie crust.
10. Bake for 15 minutes in the preheated oven. Reduce the heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) and continue to bake for an additional 45 to 55 minutes.
11. In a small bowl, mix together the pecans, brown sugar, and flour.
12. Sprinkle the streusel topping over the pie.
13. Bake for an additional 10 to 15 minutes, or until the topping is golden brown.
14. Allow to cool for at least 10 minutes before serving.

Ingredients
   3 tablespoons fresh lemon juice
   1 tablespoon soy sauce
   1 tablespoon honey
   2 teaspoons cornstarch
   1 teaspoon grated lemon zest
   1/4 teaspoon ground black pepper
   4 boneless skinless chicken breast halves (6 ounces each)
   1/2 cup reduced-sodium chicken broth
   2 tablespoons chopped green onions (green part only)

Instructions
   Preheat the oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
   Stir together the lemon juice, soy sauce, honey, cornstarch, lemon zest, and pepper in a small bowl; set aside.
   Place the chicken in a 9x13-inch baking dish. Pour the broth around the chicken.
   Bake, uncovered, for 20 minutes.
   Turn the chicken pieces over and pour the lemon sauce over the chicken. Continue baking for 15 minutes, or until the chicken is no longer pink in the center.
   Remove from the oven and sprinkle with the green onions before serving.

For the vinaigrette:
* 1/2 cup white wine vinegar
* 1/2 cup chopped shallots
* 1/2 cup olive oil
* 1/4 cup chopped fresh parsley
* 1/2 teaspoon dried oregano
* 1/2 teaspoon dried mint
* 1/2 teaspoon salt
* 1/4 teaspoon black pepper

For the bruschetta:
* 1 loaf French bread, sliced
* 1/2 cup olive oil
* 1 clove garlic, halved
* 6 eggs
* 6 thin slices prosciutto
* 6 large fresh basil leaves

Instructions:
1. In a small bowl, whisk together all vinaigrette ingredients; set aside. Brush both sides of bread slices with oil; rub tops with cut side of garlic. Toast bread under broiler until golden, about 1 minute per side.
2. Meanwhile, bring a large skillet filled with water to a boil. Reduce heat to medium-low and simmer. Break an egg into a small bowl or cup, and gently slide egg into water. Repeat with remaining eggs. Cook 3 to 5 minutes, or until eggs are done as desired. Remove eggs with a slotted spoon.
3. Top each slice of toast with a slice of prosciutto, a poached egg, and a basil leaf. Drizzle with vinaigrette, and serve.

Frijoles Borrachos - Mexican Drunk Beans

Ingredients
1 pound dried pinto beans 
1 medium onion, finely chopped
2 cloves garlic, finely chopped
1/4 cup chopped fresh cilantro
1/2 teaspoon ground cumin
1/4 teaspoon ground cinnamon
1/4 teaspoon ground cloves
1/4 teaspoon ground nutmeg
1 tablespoon olive oil
1/2 cup tequila
4 cups chicken stock

Instructions
Rinse the beans, looking for any foreign matter and discard. Cover the beans with cold water and discard any beans that float. Soak the beans overnight to reduce the cooking time and help them cook more evenly.

Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).

 Drain the beans and rinse briefly. Put the beans in a ovenproof pot and cover with the chicken stock. Bring the beans to a boil on the stovetop over medium heat. Skim off any foam that rises to the top. Stir in the onion, garlic, cilantro, cumin, cinnamon, cloves and nutmeg. Cover the pot and transfer to the oven.

Bake the beans for 1 1/2 hours, stirring every 30 minutes or so. The beans are done when they're tender but still a little firm.

Heat the olive oil in a skillet over medium heat. Stir in the tequila and cook until reduced by half. Stir the tequila mixture into the beans and cook for an additional 10 minutes. Season with salt and pepper and serve.

Ingredients 
1 pound linguine
1/2 pound shrimp, peeled and deveined
1/2 pound sea scallops
1/2 pound crabmeat

For the sauce:
2 tablespoons butter
1/2 white onion, finely chopped
2 cloves garlic, minced
2 tablespoons olive oil
2 (28 ounce) cans diced tomatoes
1/2 teaspoon dried basil
1/2 teaspoon dried oregano
1/2 teaspoon salt
1/4 teaspoon black pepper
1/4 cup dry white wine
1/4 cup fresh parsley, chopped

Instructions
1. Bring a large pot of lightly salted water to a boil. Add the linguine, and cook until al dente; drain.
2. In a large skillet over medium heat, melt the butter and saute the onion until tender. Add the garlic and saute for another minute. Stir in the olive oil, and gently stir in the diced tomatoes. Season with the basil, oregano, salt and pepper. Simmer over low heat for about 10 minutes, until the sauce is thickened.
3. Stir in the wine and parsley, and season with additional salt and pepper, if desired. Add the shrimp, scallops, and crabmeat to the sauce, and simmer until the shrimp and scallops are cooked through. Serve over the cooked linguine.

Ingredients
* 2 cups milk
* 3/4 cup sugar
* 1/2 teaspoon vanilla extract
* 1/4 teaspoon almond extract
* 1/2 cup peanut butter
* 1/2 cup chopped peanuts

Instructions
1. In a medium size saucepan, heat the milk, sugar and vanilla extract just until the sugar is dissolved. Remove from heat and add the almond extract.
2. Chill mixture thoroughly in the refrigerator.
3. Pour mixture into your ice cream maker and freeze according to manufacturer's instructions.
4. In a small bowl, combine the peanut butter and peanuts.
5. About 5 minutes before ice cream is frozen, add the peanut butter and peanut mixture.
6. Transfer to a freezer safe container and freeze at least 1 hour before serving.

Moroccan-Style Preserved Lemons

A very handy ingredient to keep in your pantry, preserved lemons can be used in tagines, salads, and more. You can also add a tablespoon or two to heighten the flavor of many dishes. This recipe calls for kosher salt, which is coarser than table salt. Use a scale to measure the correct amount of salt for this recipe. 

Ingredients 
6 to 10 lemons
1 cup kosher salt

Instructions
1. Cut the tips off of the lemons and stand them on a cutting board. Slice downward, following the natural curve of the fruit, to remove the peel in strips. Try to remove as much of the white pith as possible from the peel.
2. Place the peel in a medium-mesh strainer and rinse thoroughly under cold running water. Rub the peel between your fingers to remove any excess white pith.
3. Place 1/4 cup of the salt in the bottom of a 32-ounce glass jar. Pack the peeled lemons as tightly as possible into the jar, adding them one at a time and sprinkling salt between each layer. Use the remaining salt to cover the top of the lemons and seal the lid.
4. Store the jar in a cool, dark place for 30 days, turning the jar upside down every few days to distribute the salt and juice.
5. To use, rinse the lemons under cold water to remove the salt. Pull apart the segments and use according to your recipe.

Ingredients 
1 cup diced cooked chicken
1/2 cup chopped walnuts, toasted
1/2 cup chopped celery
1/2 cup chopped red apple
1/3 cup mayonnaise
1 1/2 teaspoons lemon juice
1/4 teaspoon dried thyme
1/4 teaspoon salt
1/4 teaspoon ground black pepper
2 cups mixed salad greens

Instructions
1. In a large bowl, combine the chicken, walnuts, celery, and apple.
2. In a small bowl, combine the mayonnaise, lemon juice, thyme, salt, and pepper.
3. Pour the mayonnaise mixture over the chicken mixture and toss to coat.
4. Divide the mixed greens between two plates and top with the chicken mixture.
5. Serve immediately.

This recipe is simple and quick, and it's a great way to use up leftover chicken. Plus, it's a healthy and nutritious meal that's perfect for lunch or dinner. The flavors of the chicken, walnuts, celery, and apple are complemented by the mayonnaise and lemon juice, while the thyme adds a subtle herbaceous note. The salad is topped with mixed greens for a fresh and crisp finish.

Ingredients
   3 oz semisweet baking chocolate, chopped
   2 tbsp butter
   1 cup granulated sugar
   1 egg yolk
   1 tsp vanilla extract
   1 cup all-purpose flour
   1 tsp baking powder
   1 tsp baking soda
   1 tsp salt
   3 oz semisweet baking chocolate, melted
   1 cup unsweetened shredded coconut, chopped
   2 tbsp butter, melted
   48 jelly beans, halved

Instructions
   Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
   In a small saucepan, melt the 2 tablespoons butter and 3 oz chopped chocolate over low heat, stirring frequently.
   Remove from heat and transfer to a large bowl.
   Stir in the sugar, egg yolk, and vanilla extract.
   In a small bowl, combine the flour, baking powder, baking soda, and salt.
   Add the dry ingredients to the chocolate mixture, then the melted chocolate and stir until just combined.
   Stir in the coconut.
   Pour the batter into a 9x13 inch baking pan.
   In a small bowl, combine the melted butter and jelly beans.
   Drop by spoonfuls onto the batter and use a toothpick to marble the jelly beans into the batter.
   Bake at 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) for 25 minutes, or until a toothpick inserted into the center of the cake comes out clean.
   Cool before serving.

The recipe for Chocolate Banana Cream Cake is as follows:

Ingredients:

1/2 cup butter, softened
1/2 cup sugar
2 eggs
1 teaspoon vanilla extract
1/2 cup mashed bananas (about 1 banana)
1/2 cup milk
1 cup all-purpose flour
3 tablespoons cocoa powder
1 teaspoon baking powder
1/4 teaspoon salt

Instructions:

Preheat your oven to 350 degrees Fahrenheit (175 degrees Celsius).
In a large bowl, cream the butter and sugar until light and fluffy. Add the eggs one at a time, beating well after each. Stir in the vanilla.
In a medium bowl, mash the bananas with a fork until mostly smooth. Stir in the milk.
In a small bowl, combine the flour, cocoa powder, baking powder, and salt.
Add the banana mixture to the butter-egg mixture, then add the dry ingredients, mixing until just combined.
Pour the batter into a 9x9-inch baking pan. Bake in the preheated oven for 25-30 minutes, or until a toothpick inserted into the center comes out clean.
Allow the cake to cool in the pan for 10 minutes, then turn it out onto a wire rack to cool completely.
Serve warm or at room temperature.

The ingredients are as follows: 

- 1 envelope taco seasoning
- 1 cup chicken broth
-  cup all-purpose flour
- 2 cups milk
- 2 cups cooked, chopped chicken
- 1 cup frozen corn
- 1 cup shredded Mexican cheese blend
-  cup chopped green onions
- 1 cup crushed tortilla chips
- 2 jalapenos, thinly sliced

Directions

1. Preheat oven to 350.
2. In a large saucepan over medium heat, combine taco seasoning, chicken broth, and flour. Stir in milk and cook, stirring, until thickened. Remove from heat and stir in chicken, corn,  cup cheese, and green onions.
3. Pour mixture into a 9x13-inch baking dish. Top with crushed chips and jalapenos. Sprinkle with remaining cheese.
4. Bake 20 minutes, or until bubbly.

I think I have a misconception about the idea of living life in the present.  I always thought that it meant to stop worrying about the future and to just be in the moment.  But now I realize that it doesnt mean to forget about the future, but to start living for the future, and to enjoy the present moment as if it was your future, and that whatever you do in the present moment, is something youll have to live with in the future.

For example, if you spend time procrastinating and playing video games, thats what your future will basically be composed of, and youll have to live with that decision of wasting your time, and you wont be happy with yourself, if you have ambitions that you want to achieve.  Another example is, if you are in a relationship, and your partner wants to take things to the next level, and youre not on the same page, thinking about living in the present, would mean that you think about the consequences of your decision of not being ready to take things to the next level, and what that would mean for your relationship in the long term, and if youre cool with that, then stay in the present, and if youre not, then you should do what is best for both you and your partner, and break it off before both of you get more attached. 

Living life in the present, is not about stopping to worry about the future, its about planning and doing whatever you can in the present moment, in order to have a good future, and to not have regrets or negative consequences in the future, and if you adopt this mindset, then youll be able to truly live life in the present, and not have to worry about missing out on the present because youre too worried about the future, since youll be ready for the future, and will know no fear.

Wtf is up with the rumbling being 80%??  Everyone developing games these days using "smart" rumble, which is cool and all, but like... 20% of the rumble controllers seem to actually work with it?

And, in general, what is up with rumble?  Why did it never take off?  Why do some controllers not have it at all?  How difficult would it be to implement vibration and put it in every controller?  Why are there still controllers being made without it?

I know Nintendo switched to "HD rumble" which supposedly the Switch's controllers do a better job at simulating forces and stuff, but it seems like every other console since the Xbox360/PS3 has had the same exact rumbles as each other, and they're all pretty much the same as the ones that were in the GameCube and original Xbox.

Though, to be fair, the Switch's rumble is pretty bad too...  ({`(`tunnelbanana`) withdrawal )

With how much processing power and tech goes into these new GPUs and whatnot, why does controller rumble, which should be a simple "turn this motor on at a certain power for a certain amount of time" always seem to get the short end of the stick?

The former officer, Derek Chauvin, pleaded not guilty Tuesday during his arraignment on murder and other charges in the death of George Floyd, who prosecutors say was pinned to the pavement with a knee on his neck for what prosecutors said was 9 1/2 minutes.

Kyle previously said he would "probably" attend the trial, but he took to Instagram stories to detail why he won't be covering the trial:

"A lot of people are asking me about the Derek Chauvin trial, and yeah, I've been following it. And there's been a lot of speculation, and for good reason, about whether or not I would be covering it. And I got to tell you, just because somebody's charged with something doesn't mean they're guilty. It seems like in today's day and age, a lot of people just assume someone is guilty of something, just because everybody else thinks that they're guilty.

And until I see otherwise, I'm going to assume that he's innocent until proven guilty, and that's just how I roll. Now, could he be guilty? Sure. But until I see otherwise, until I hear otherwise, until the system says otherwise, I'm going to assume that he's innocent. And yeah, it's not going to be anything that I focus on because, frankly, there's a lot of other stuff going on in the world. And this is a big deal, obviously. I get it. But let's just wait and see, and let the system do its job."

Engage with literature beyond school. Read books of different genres and topics on your own time. It's easy to lose interest in something if it becomes something you're forced to do. Read books by authors of different backgrounds, books in different languages, short stories, long form fiction, nonfiction, and poetry. 
If you have the time and energy I would also recommend writing your own stories. Create something entirely your own. This fluctuates a lot for me where sometimes I'm super interested in writing and then other times I don't feel like doing it at all and that's okay. Don't force it. But doing this helped me regain interest and passion for literature when I was feeling a bit burned out. 
Also following book accounts on instagram or goodreads where you can constantly see books and read short summaries might help reignite your passion.

I love the idea of a fresh start. However, exclusively the top tier guns and loadouts are the most powerful (Grapple FTW). Earlier in the wipe you could rock a plain pistol or an mp5 and have a chance at fighting back, but now? You get dunked on non-stop. It's frustrating being melted by weapons you can't even see until they are right in your face. Not only that, but with the addition of tacticals, you can't even play stealthy anymore. Regardless of whether I run around like an alarmed ostrich with my ears turned up, or crouch and tap my mic to spoof a headset, gettingShotInTheDuckingFuckingAss with a shotgun through a wall is inevitable. I've heard people say that "new players should just grind, and not focus on power". That doesn't cut it when every other player is a god-tier hitscan shotcaster with aimbot ears and an orbital laser. I'm not saying I want to run around sniping people left and right with a bullpup, but it would be nice to not get melted by stuff I can't see, that shoots faster than I can react. This is coming from a guy that has been playing day one, and has gotten a few scratches in during the occasional lucky shotgun blast. God help the people that haven't played in a year, or are brand new. It's not even fun playing anymore. The thrill of getting a good loadout, thinking you have a chance, and then dying in two seconds is just frustrating, not entertaining. Again, love the idea of fresh starts and all, but it's not fun when everyone is wearing Titanfall underwear under their loadout.

I hear this a lot, and there are some great explanations out there, but I still don't think I understand this issue entirely. Why is tapering seen as the only possible solution?

To explain why I am confused, let's look at the following scenario:

So, Japan has had ZIRP for about 15 years now, and they do not seem to have inflation (yet). Why is it that when we in the US talk about keeping interest rates low for a long time, we immediately jump to the conclusion that we need to taper, when Japan has had a similar policy for nearly twice as long, and they didn't taper?

Isn't the solution somehow more complex than "taper"? Or is Japan doing something else to combat the effects of ZIRP that they don't want to tell us? Do we not have enough intellectual flexibility to consider alternative solutions that still involve CRP/ZIRP, but may involve different tools?

In my admittedly limited understanding, the benefits of CRP/ZIRP are twofold:

1. In the event of another financial crisis, interest rates will already be at zero, so we will have more tools available to fight a recession. And yes, this is somewhat preemptive, but that's not so bad, is it?

2. Low rates encourage more investment into ventures that otherwise may not have been feasible. Many of these ventures will create jobs, and the increased business activity will stimulate the economy.

Now, if we taper, then we lose the second point, and the only thing we really retain is the preemptive measure of being able to fight another recession. But, since we can't permanently keep interest rates at zero (because of point 1), we will eventually want to raise rates high enough to be able to lower them in the event of another recession. So it seems that there are only two options:

1. Raise rates now, and accept that we will have less tools available in the next recession.

2. Don't raise rates, and accept that we may have inflation later on, but that we will be more prepared for the next recession.

So, why is it that option 2 is considered unacceptable? Both options have their pros and cons, so why is it that we instantly jump to "taper" as though it were the only possible solution?

What am I missing here?

There are a lot of factors here and everyone will have an opinion, but from my understanding, you can resign without it being held against you (ie non-renewal isn't tied to your resignation).

Your situation, and whether or not you want to leave, is something you should be discussing with your administration - not other teachers on social media. Do you have a good working relationship with your admin? If you do, then talk to them about what you're hoping to do. If you have an adversarial relationship with them, I wouldn't bother because they'll just think you're trying to get them back for something - pure speculation on my part, but I wouldn't put it past admin to think that. If you don't have a good relationship with your admin, start making one. It will serve you well in the future whether it's at this school or not.

I resigned from my last district to move back home. When I told my admin, they were surprisingly supportive and offered to help me with my resume and recommendations. I listed my reasons for leaving as 'personal reasons' and that was that. I had wonderful evaluations and they were sad to see me go, but they didn't try to talk me out of it or anything. The district was also incredibly pro-teacher and even though they weren't obligated to, they gave me a wonderful recommendation when I began looking for a new job.

When I interviewed, I openly discussed why I left and was very honest. I mentioned the supportive environment, competitive pay and benefits, and the reason I left - wanting to move closer to family. The district I'm in now loved that I was honest, and that I had such a good working relationship with my previous admin. These things are all important to school districts - at least the effective ones.

If you don't want to disclose your reasons for leaving, you don't have to. No employer can force you to disclose that information. You can simply state that you are leaving for 'personal reasons' and leave it at that. Again, this is something you should be discussing with your admin - not other teachers on social media. Good luck! Hope it works out for you.

I work at an arcade and one of the games occasionally has a minor issue where it will not release a prize that a customer has won. Obviously, whenever this happens, management is always very quick to respond and fix the issue so we can award the customer with their rightfully won prize. 

Well, yesterday a man who was likely in his forties became irate after the machine malfunctioned and didn't release the prize he felt he had won. Keep in mind, this is after he already exchanged his prize (a stuffed animal) for 3 different $5 dollar bills. Apparently, this man really wanted the stuffed animal and felt he was owed one free of charge after exchanging his initial prize. 

After explaining to the man that we would need to step away from the machine for a moment so it could be serviced and the prize could be awarded, he flew into a rage. He began yelling that he wanted his free stuffed animal, that we were trying to steal from him, and that he wanted to speak to a manager. All while gesturing towards the somewhat annoyed crowd of onlookers gathering behind him. 

At this point, it should be noted that we have a camera system set up in the arcade that is very clearly labeled with signs in plain sight. These cameras monitor the floor for safety purposes, but they also can be used to review any disputes that may arise. 

After telling the man for a second time that we would repair the game and award him his prize if he stepped away from the machine, he replied "I know you're watching, so in case you weren't able to tell, I would like a free stuffed animal. You can look back on this recording and see that I was in my right to receive this prize."

Hello my fellow redditors and d&d players,

I am a DM for a small group (me and my 3 friends) and it's been working out pretty well so far. We've played maybe 10 sessions so far. One of my players (let's call him Bob) keeps doing really awkward stuff and it's making the game much less fun for me as a DM and the other players.

Any advice would be greatly appreciated!

Thanks,

Perturbed_DM

I worked retail for 4 years throughout high school and college, and lordy do I have some stories. There are so many awkward customers.

There was the lady who needed help finding outfits for her exotic dancer daughter. There was the octogenarian who came in to buy a rifle and bullets on Christmas Eve. There was the lady who yelled at me for 10 minutes because I wouldn't sell her a 4-foot tall ceramic statue of Buddha. (We don't sell that stuff, lady. Not your Buddha, not your Buddha at all!)

But the absolute worst were the people who would literally walk into the store, look directly at me (not 4 feet away), and then just stand there. Without saying anything. They'd just stare at me with this dumb look on their face. It was incredibly awkward. After about 30 seconds of this, I'd say hi or ask if I could help them find something. And then they'd say something like "uh yeah, where are your bath rugs?" or "do you have any fitted sheets?"

Honestly if you're struggling with conversation, retail is a good place to learn. You'll have days where you have to talk to 5 people an hour about stuff you have no interest in, and you'll have days where you have literally 0 conversations, but you'll learn how to make small talk about anything.

Also learning about customer service and how to deal with bitchy people is a useful life skill.

I just wanted to say that the education system in Turkey is literally an examination by God. There is a saying that goes like "God conducts the examination, human being is just the scribe". This is a very poisonous saying if you ask me. Because it is implying that you are not responsible for whatever grade you get, God is. So students don't try hard, they don't go to extra lessons, they don't do their homework, because "God will have mercy on me, I will pass anyway". However, when the grade comes out, they don't think that it is their own fault they failed, they think that "God was just being mean, I didn't deserve this". Something similar happens when a student decides to "pray for a good grade", they don't work hard, they pray and when they don't get the grade they want, they think that God was "being unjust", and not themselves for not studying. This mentality is doing nothing but making people excuse themselves from taking responsibility for their own actions, it is destroying the society.

Forced interaction while watching everyone fail simultaneously is probably the kamote-iest thing to experience in the workplace. Normal na naman silang tao pero napapagalitan pa rin for some reason and in the end, you just have to laugh at how stupid everything is.

I'm 17 and I've always been pretty boyish, but recently my dysphoria has been getting a lot worse. Like, worse than it already was anyways. I feel like my dysphoria will never go away and Im just going to get uglier and more uncomfortable in my skin as I get older. It's hard to be motivated to do anything when I feel this way about myself. Is this just my depression getting the best of me, or could my dysphoria potentially get worse as I get older? Cause it really scares me. Idk if this is just a phase or hormones or what, but I'm seriously terrified. It just feels so hopeless.

I've been taking modafinil (brand name: Provigil) for about three months now, and it's done wonders for my productivity. I've always been a bit of a night owl, but modafinil has helped me become more of a morning person, and has made it easier for me to wake up early and get things done. It's also helped me focus better, and has made me more efficient at getting things done.

The only side effect I've experienced has been some mild headaches, but they've been infrequent and easily manageable. I've also found that modafinil can cause some anxiety, but again, it's been mild and infrequent.

Overall, I've been really happy with modafinil, and I plan to continue taking it. It's made a big difference in my productivity and has helped me become more of a morning person. It's a great tool for anyone who wants to improve their focus and mental clarity.

I was a junior in high school, it was lunchtime, and I was walking down the hallway to my next class. There was a guy maybe 10 feet in front of me, and he turns around and starts going the other way. We literally almost collide, but I manage to stop myself short of running into him. However, the guy behind me was not so lucky, and NAILED the other guy at full speed. They both went down in a heap on the ground, and I hardly had time to register what had happened when I heard the guy getting up and sprinting away. He presumably didn't want to get in trouble for bullying, as it was pretty obvious that he had pushed the other guy intentionally. Meanwhile, the other guy is still on the ground, and NOT getting up. As I'm watching all this happen, it suddenly occurs to me that THIS IS WHY I LEARNED TO DANCE. I immediately drop down into a split next to him, take his hands, and start doing the "sprinkler." Suddenly, girls who previously had nothing to do with me are screaming THEIR names, taking pictures, and offering me lunch the next day. Sadly, the other guy got up and immediately left, so I never got to show OFF for him. Still, lessons learned. Always be prepared for a dance-off, and always assume that there's a reason you learned something.

I just sort of kind of tried to end my life.. Not really.. I just took 30 of my grandma's sleeping pills, and I woke up today feeling somewhat guilty, so here I am posting this on here. It's kind of hard explaining why you don't want to live anymore without sounding selfish or rude, because the people closest to you (the people who you'd do this to) are the people who'd do anything to make you happy. lie to themselves that you're okay. I don't want to put anyone through that though. I'm in a somewhat okay spot, and I think that this was more of a "test the waters" sort of thing, to see what it would be like, and I don't think I'd do it again. Not that I'm afraid of it, but because it wouldn't accomplish anything. But, now that I've done it, I can say from experience that it doesn't "fix" things. It's not like you can suddenly see everything in a new light, and realize that everything's going to be okay, and that you were just being a whiny little bitch. It just kind of.. doesn't do anything. I guess I felt like I needed to get that out. I'm not trying to get attention or anything, and I sincerely hope that no one tries this because it's not a magical fix-all. It's just.. exhausting. For me, at least. And apparently, from the sounds of it, for the people who love you, too.

Recently I've been watching Tron Legacy again and I wonder how Jake Bodie's lines would sound if they were spoken by the actors of the original Tron.

Specifically, I'm wondering how the famous "I know kinesics" line would sound in the old 80s V.O. style.

Any of you talented writers out there want to give it a shot?

I think this is a fun idea.

I've been thinking about getting a TRON: Legacy script and highlighting the lines that are rewrites/additions of Legacy-only plot points, and then crossing them out and writing in the equivalent lines from the original TRON that would fit in their place.

Like, for example, "They took our son!" from the beginning could be changed to "He's alive! They didn't kill him! He's alive!"

This is a fun idea, right?

Also the line "Yes sir, Mr. Farrow" could be cool if they updated the voice used for CLU to resemble the voice from the original TRON more closely. Not that I wouldn't want to hear an updated "I know kinesics" delivered in the old V.O. style. That would be awesome.

Im 21 years old, male, and I live in Italy. Few days ago I got diagnosed with hodgkin lymphoma, a type of cancer. Thing is, aside from the swollen lymph nodes that led me to get checked in the first place, I dont really feel any symptoms. Im not tired, I dont feel pain, Im not even particularly anxious or scared about it, at least not in an everyday basis. I know that its a serious thing and I should be taking it more seriously, but... I just dont feel anything. I feel like Im just going through the motions and waiting for the treatments to start so I can get it over with. Part of me is also kind of excited about having something to do every day, because I dont really have any hobbies or activities (not like I had much time for them considering the pandemic). I know that it must sound terrible, especially from someone who got told they have cancer, but... I just dont feel anything about it, good or bad. Im not denying it, I know its there, I just dont feel anything about it.

I should also add that I have a pretty stressful job, so the fact that I dont feel particularly stressed about this maybe because my body is already used to dealing with high levels of stress, who knows.

I know this sub is mostly for asking advice, and I dont really need any. Im just kinda scared that the lack of emotions could be an indicator that Im gonna ignore how serious this whole thing is, or that I could just suddenly snap out of it and become overwhelmed by fear or something.

Anyway, thanks for reading this, I just wanted to share my experience.

I'm a union operating engineer in the Midwest and make really good money for my area relative to cost of living. Have a pension and retiree health care. Well paid vacation and sick time that accumulates and rolls over. 14 paid holidays a year. Every other Friday off. Good medical and dental insurance. Basically unheard of nowadays for a blue-collar job. I feel lucky and want to retire from this line of work with my benefits intact.

However, over the last few years, I've watched a few things that are just accepted as normal, and it's baffling to me why nobody talks about it. The amount of waste on jobs is insane. Nobody cares about efficiency. Why not use a skid steer to do that excavation when you just have a couple holes to dig? Why not clean up the job at the end of every day so you don't have to pay a man 8 hours to clean up the garbage? Why do we order materials with no regard for how much we actually need? Why not just order enough for the job instead of 30 extra just in case? Why not schedule jobs efficiently so you aren't driving an hour to do a 1-hour job?

And nobody is held accountable for any of this. Why does the job always have to be "right now" and "as soon as possible"? Why are the most unnecessary things always the highest priority? Why are so many decisions made by people with no skin in the game or any concept of cost? Why does every job have to be a masterpiece instead of just getting the basics done so you can move on?

I can't retire soon enough. This job would be really great if it wasn't for the complete lack of regard for wasting money and resources. Nobody has talked to me about this because they all assume it's normal.

I've been on pain meds for about 12 years now. Morphine sulphate ER 60mg 4x a day and oxycodone apap 5mg PRN. It's been great for my pain issues and I've been able to maintain a pretty normal life.

But lately I've had some side effects that are getting worse. Fatigue, lack of motivation, anxiety, severe itching especially at night, upset stomach. And lately I feel almost like I don't exist, its hard to explain but I feel disconnected from myself and my body.

The ER doc I saw last week was a jerk and acted like I was a drug seeker even though I've been taking the same meds for 12 years and he even pulled up my prescription records from Walgreen's. He basically told me I was addicted and either I quit or he wouldn't see me anymore.

So here I am, ready to try to get off meds. I'm scared though. The internet is filled with horror stories of people having withdrawals and I'm scared that I'll start having withdrawals and they'll be too much for me to take. Most articles say it's rare to have serious withdrawals as long as you wean off slowly. I'm hoping that's the case for me.

I plan on starting tomorrow by skipping my morning morphine. I know that's not a huge step but I want to take this slowly. My plan is to skip a dose every 2-3 days and see how I do. I don't want to rush this anymore than I have to.

I'd love to hear from anyone that's been through similar. I'm excited to get off these meds but I'm terrified at the same time.

It's been a long time since I've been confident with my body. I've always been overweight but when I was younger (into my early 20s) I just accepted it and lived my life. I knew I was intelligent, and witty, and I had a good career, and promising life ahead of me. That's when I was happiest with myself and my body. Now I'm size 24/26, and 360 lbs. BMI is over 40, clinical depression and anxiety, inactive, and just downright miserable. I've always known my weight was a problem but it's different when objectively you're morbidly obese. When I was younger I could lose weight, but now it's 10x harder. I've tried losing weight so many times it's not even funny. I can restrict for a few weeks but then I indulge a little, then a little more, then I'm restricting again and the cycle continues. Clearly my mentality around food is unhealthy. I've tried exercise, but that's a whole other monster I have yet to conquer. It's so hard to start, and the few times I have started I quickly give up when I don't see the results I want as fast as I want. And pregnancy was HELL. I was 400 lbs pregnant. Just terrible. I want to be happy again. I don't even know where to start anymore. I'm so tired either way. Tired of being obese and tired of trying and failing. It's hard to explain the mental anguish and loneliness being this overweight causes. Not to mention the physical pain. I'm just so tired.

I had a proud moment with my son today. He's my only child, and he has Down syndrome. He's almost 4 and started preschool last month. Today was the first time he got on the bus alone to go to school, and he didn't cry or get upset at all, he just waved and said goodbye. I almost cried because I was so proud of him. It may seem like a small thing to some people, but to me it shows how far he's come and how much he's grown. He's going to do great things in life. :)

I was adopted at birth by my mom and dad. My mom passed away suddenly almost 6 years ago from a blood clot in her brain, and I never got to say goodbye or I love you... That haunts me daily. I wish I could've said everything I wanted to say to her, and I wish I could've been there for her, because she was there for me for everything.

It destroyed me when she died, and I sometimes hate my dad for still being here because it just isn't fair... He's remarrying in two weeks, and I am supposed to be standing up there next to him like everything is okay... it's not. I'm stuck facing the fact that she's never coming back, and neither is the happy, care-free, untroubled, and uncomplicated kid that I was before.

I'm so scared of forgetting her. I have nightmares frequently that she is right there in front of me, alive and healthy, but just out of reach like in those dreams where you are screaming but can't make noise. I dream that she comes back to life, but I sometimes forget that she's dead until something reminds me, and then it feels like I'm hearing it for the first time again and I crumble inside.

I'm never going to stop missing her. It hurts so much. It feels so unfair that she's gone. There's nothing I can do except miss her, because she can't hear me anymore.

I'm looking to upgrade internet for our household as the current DSL line is extremely slow and unreliable (6-800ms ping, 1.5-2.2mbps down, 200kbps up), and was looking to upgrade to fibre. 

Our current ISP is Telus, who offers a 300mbps down/300mbps up package for $85/month for 2 years, and subsequently $105/month. The next package offering is 1000mbps down/500mbps up for $105/month for 2 years, and subsequently $120/month. Neither of these packages have data caps. Telus also offers a bundle package with HD TV and home phone for $10 more per month, but I don't think we'd make use of that.

One of my coworkers recently switched to Shaw, and was telling me about their deals. Apparently they're offering a 1000mbps down/1000mbps up package for $80/month for 2 years, and subsequently $100/month. The fine print says that this price is based on a 2-year price guarantee, and that after the two years is up, most customers will receive an average annual increase of approximately 5%. It also states that the regular rate for this package is $159.99/month. This package also has no data caps.

Which of these options would be better? Trying to determine if the initial savings of going with Shaw is worth it for the increased cost after 2 years, or if we're better off going with Telus' higher speed package to begin with. 

I believe that Telus recently started allowing customers to purchase top-ups for additional data, up to a maximum of 1tb. Shaw offers the same, but only up to a maximum of 250gb. Not sure if this would affect our decision making. The household consists of 2 adults and 2 teenagers, and while one of the teenagers does heavy gaming and 4k streaming, the other one does moderate gaming and streaming, and the adults do some moderate-heavy streaming and zoom calls. None of us really download large files very often. 

I appreciate any advice you can give! Thanks!

I have social anxiety, and though I appear quite calm, smiling, and nodding, my mind is in chaos. I am so distracted by my anxiety that I can't focus on the people I'm talking to. It's like I'm trapped in my mind, scrambling to pick the right thing to say, but it's a blur, and I can't focus on any one thing. I can't stop myself from asking questions, and I feel compelled to smile and act pleasant because if I don't, I'll seem rude. I feel like I'm wasting my time because I can't seem to form coherent thoughts, and I can't stop acting like everything is fine when it so clearly is not. I hate that I can't seem to explain what's going on to people because I think they'd understand if they knew how much pain I was in. But instead, I internalize it and waste hours worrying about everything I did or didn't say.

I'm fed up and exhausted. It's affecting my work, and I can't stand it. I don't know what to do. I've tried various techniques, but it's getting worse. I can't even socialize with my friends without getting anxious. I'm losing my mind. My doctor put me on medication, but it doesn't help. I don't know what to do.

I can't believe these people are allowed to simply stand there with megaphones and harass people. There was a large police presence guarding them. It was pretty disturbing. It's one thing to have different opinions but another to harass people face to face.

There were 3 people with megaphones yelling things like "This is genocide, you're killing your children". They had signs with graphically horrifying pictures of what appeared to be covid victims. I drove by initially thinking it was a protest but then saw the signs and took another look. I almost wished I didn't. It was horrifying. They were yelling things at people who were waiting in their cars, and people were getting out and screaming back things like "you're killing people". It was like a scene out of a zombie movie or something. It really gave me the heebie-jeebies. This was in Langley by the way.

I have mixed feelings about it. On one hand, I agree with their sentiment regarding vaccines (although I disagree with their tactics). But on the other hand, I find it really upsetting that this is the state of our society nowadays.

Though, towards the end of my break I was having some really intense dreams again, having difficulty sleeping, and was overall a little more anxious than I like to be. It is pretty safe to say that I am happy to be smoking again, and overall pretty excited for my package to come in!

I'm crying about life and I just want someone to hear me out. I need to vent. My mom is dying. She has been one of the main supports in my life and I'm terrified of losing her. I own a successful business in a small rural town in northeastern Vermont. Our business is growing and becoming more successful each year, and attracting new residents to the area.

Unfortunately, our town's only industry is forestry, which in 2020 accounted for only 30% of the town's GDP. This means that 70% of our town's energy consumption comes from non-renewable sources. The cost of electricity is 21 cents per kilowatt-hour, and heating costs for businesses like mine are incredibly high -- about 44% higher than the national average. This is not sustainable or tenable in the long term.

With this in mind, my colleagues and I started to look at other industries that are more sustainable, and have decided that cannabis is among the most promising. There is an established market for cannabis here, as evidenced by the number of registered patients in the state. However, there is a significant shortage of cannabis in the state, and we believe that our town could benefit from increased supply to meet demand.

The problem is that our town is currently lacking the infrastructure to support the cannabis industry. Although our town has a population of just under 10,000 people, it has nowhere to purchase cannabis for medical use. While there is a dispensary about an hour away, the majority of our town's residents cannot afford the travel costs to get there.

We believe that the town's residents would benefit from a dispensary, and that it would stimulate business in the town while providing patients with easier access to medical cannabis. In addition, we think that a dispensary could be a stepping stone to creating a sustainable, profitable cannabis industry in our town.

The question, then, is how to go about establishing this infrastructure. Despite the success of our business, we do not have the capital required to open a dispensary. In addition, although we are confident that there would be demand for a dispensary in our town, we are unsure of the exact steps that would be required to make it a reality.

My colleagues and I would be very grateful for any advice or guidance that experienced entrepreneurs in the cannabis industry could provide. How do we go about raising capital for a dispensary? What sort of permits and licenses would we need? Any advice or guidance on how to move forward with this project would be most appreciated!

I struggle with being too nice. I am working on it currently. Nice guys (or gals) finish last is not just a saying, but a real thing.

There is a reason there are so many memes and jokes about it. It is a real problem scientifically and psychologically.

Nice people get used and drained. Pleasers get used by assholes. There are many theories, but nicest ones finish last. You should never change who you are, but you can work on not letting people take advantage of you.

It's okay to put yourself first. It's okay to say no. It's okay to not be treated like a doormat. Stop letting people use you. I know you want to help, but people take advantage of that. It's fine to help, but don't let them take advantage.

Source: I am a people pleaser who is currently learning to not be so accommodating and let people take advantage of my nice nature. It is hard, but I realize others also struggle with this, so I'm not alone. 

We can change ourselves into not being so accommodating, and thus change the dynamics of our relationships (friend, family, work, significant other, whatever the case may be).

"Aphelios is a comparatively small champion when it comes to figure height, however when it comes to abilities and damage output he is a monster. simplest way i found to describe him is as a high risk high reward champion with a rapidly changing toolkit that adapts to your teams compositions and the enemies you face, along with great base damages and scaling.

Aphelios is a relatively new champion in league of legends, releasing shortly after the rift revelries event in 2020. classed as an ADCsitter sup hybrid, Aphelios has one of the best  accuracies for an ADC due to his four guns. he is considered a hyper carry due to his team fighting and objective taking ability, as well as his incredibly high damage output.

when playing aphelios it is important to know his abilities as well as ideal item builds for the champion, along with the playstyle that is expected when playing as him.

Ability Summaries:
1. His first ability is a directed, long range shotgun blast. Killing minions decreases the cooldown.
2. His second is a targeted rocket blast, that hits the first target for full damage and creates a field that does damage over time to other enemies in the area of effect.
3. His third is a point and click field creation, that creates a field that does damage over time to enemies who stay inside it. this field also provides sight in a large radius.
4. His fourth is a self targeted dash that allows him to dash in the targeted direction, this also allows him to go through units and terrain making him extremely mobile.
5. His fifth and final ability for his base kit is a targeted bombardment, that when targeting a champion will prioritize that target and bombard them with gunfire reducing their protection and magic resistance.

When playing Aphelios ideally you want to buy a rifle alongside your mythic item, as your mythic will more than likely be soul vessel. after these items you want to complete your core build which is guardian angle and boomerang. after these it is best to finish off the build with a death cap for the full damage output.

When playing as aphelios you want to be as aggressive as possible in lane as his kit is very strong in lane and he has extremely high base damages and ad scaling, allowing you to dominate your lane opponent. when in team fights you want to be near the front line as you are very burst damage oriented, allowing you to delete

After a lot of thinking, I decided that, instead of trying to boil my massive list down to a handful of songs per poll, I would do the opposite: each poll will contain only one song. Yes, I'm gonna be that guy.

Anyway, on to the song of the month! In honor of October, and the spookiness of this time of year, the song for October is...

"Spooky Scary Skeletons" by Andrew Gold!

This song was originally released in 1985 on Gold's second album, Zone. Apparently it was never actually released as a single, which is a shame because it's a perfect song for this time of year. An upbeat, funky tune, it tells the story of...well, skeletons having a party. There's also a hilarious music video to go along with it, which you can find on Youtube.

So, let's get started! As always, reply to this comment with your score (from 0-10, with 10 being the best) placed in the prefix of your comment.

For example:
10/10  I love this song
4/10  This song is average for me
0/10  I hate this song

You may also leave comments, but please be courteous to others if you do.

Im a 16 year old, and my 27 year old cousin has been flirting with me for years. Im bi, so I guess I should be flattered? But its made me extremely uncomfortable and Ive made it clear Im not interested in him romantically. Today I found out hes been telling people hes dating me. I have no idea what to do. I cant tell my parents, because it would ruin my cousins life (he has psychological issues and it would send him into a spiral), and I dont want to send him to jail because he didnt understand that I wasnt interested. Theres no way he would understand if I just told him to stop, and its not like I can avoid him because our families are close. I dont know what to do, any advice would be greatly appreciated.

Edit: Thank you all for your advice, I feel a lot more comfortable with handling the situation now. I decided to tell my mom about what was going on, and because of the reaction she had, I decided to tell my dad as well. After talking to them for a while, they agreed to help me confront my cousin. It went as well as it could have, I think. He didnt try to deny anything, and acknowledged that he understood why I was upset. We decided together that it would be best if he moved out of my house, which he did. In the future, if he wants to come over, my parents will be there as well. Thank you all again.

"I just started working at a restaurant, and I started thinking about how long it would take before I could consider myself a chef, as that is ultimately what I want to do. About half of the cooks here have told me that it takes 10,000 hours before you can really say you know what you're doing, and that's about 5 years working 50 hours a week. Others have told me that you can get there in 3 years, working 6 days a week, 10-12 hours a day. What do you guys think? Is this realistic? I wanna be a chef!"

It's done. I hit the button to confirm everything, and now it's just a matter of waiting for confirmation. It's a little unsettling not to have that safety net under me anymore, but it's also kind of thrilling. It's like when you jump out of a plane and freefall for a while before the parachute opens up. Except in this case, I hope the ground is more forgiving than concrete when I land.

I can't help but feel a little guilty about it all. I mean, sure, I talked about it with my wife and we decided together that it was a good idea. But still, it's a lot of money to gamble with. I just hope that in the end it works out and we can pay off our debt and get back on our feet.

I'm gonna go distract myself with some TV or something. Maybe I'll watch that new show everyone's talking about. Yeah, I could use a little mindless entertainment right about now.

I took optional graduation mathematics paper during my undergraduate as I felt nervous about the economics graduation. It went fairly well and I used it to calculate odds of being able to graduate in economics. 

I graduated with a 13.5 (out of 20) average in economics courses (first and second years, maths and management flavoured). In the last year, I did all the economics courses (including honours courses) with an average of about 15.5-16 thus far. Had some bad luck and a couple of stupid mistakes (plus a terrible midterm for one course) brought down my average in those courses. Results for the last few courses aren't out yet but I'm pretty confident about a couple and pretty nervous about a couple. Also, took 6 non-economics courses in the third year so that contributed to the boost in average as well. 

There was another guy who graduated in my year, with a 11.5 average (out of 20) in economics courses in the first two years. He had a 16 average in the economics courses in the third year (including honours) and graduated. So that means preferably I want a 12 average in first and second year (I can afford to drop a couple now that I know the syllabus and my mistakes were more due to nervousness and some bad luck). Plus, a 15 average in the third year economics courses. That should give me a good shot at graduating with honours in economics. 

Thoughts? I know it's a lot of ifs but thinking aloud.

I main pyro, and in my experience, if you land your shots consistently you'll almost always get kills easily. The problem is when you play against good dodge players like heavy, demo, or soldier. It becomes extremely difficult to land your shots because of their dodge abilites. Another thing is that the pyro's air blast can be easily dodged if you have good movement (jumping around a lot). Other than that the pyro is definitely not weak. His "weakness" is more on the player's skill than the actual character. It is more difficult to play pyro compared to demo or heavy because of how fast pyro is and how quickly he can kill himself with his flare gun or secondary. infested turf is also a hard map to play pyro because of how open it is and how small your flamethrower hitbox is compared to other maps. honestly the only thing i would change about pyro is make his air blast not reflect projectiles and instead stun the opponent like a concussive bomb does. And make it so that if you reflect a rocket or grenade that it doesn't take a long time to come back to you, because if the other team sees that you've reflected their grenade they just shoot you with a rocket before the grenade gets to you.

I'm 6 weeks pregnant and was told everything looks good for now but I've had really bad cramping on and off since about week 3. Sometimes it feels like mild period cramps and others it feels like implantation cramps and then there are times where it's so bad I have to stop and breathe through it. Sunday I felt like I was having bad period cramps but they went away fairly quickly. Since then no cramping just lots of pressure. I've also been having lots of vaginal discharge, should I be concerned? This is my first pregnancy. Is this normal? How long does it last? Should I be calling my dr? UPDATE: thanked everyone for their input. Really helped me calm down about it. Baby is fine and healthy still. No cramping or bleeding and progressed a week in 4 days. Everything looking good. Will update if anything changes. Currently 7w1d.

UPDATE 2: No changes. Feeling well. No cramping or bleeding. Had an ultrasound at 8 weeks and saw a very healthy baby with a heartbeat of 176. Cannot thank you all enough for the kind words, support, and advice. It really helped me out during a stressful time.

"Starting out it can be tough, there aren't a ton of tutorials out there but there are enough to get you started. The hardest part for me was just getting used to the interface and learning where to find everything, also learning to use the animation system. Once you get the hang of the basics it gets a lot easier, but it can be frustrating at first especially since Unity's editor is so slow.

But if you have prior game dev experience it probably won't be too hard to pick up. Also once you get hooked on unity you can buy some of the advanced tutorials from the asset store, but those can get expensive so I'd recommend at least trying to figure stuff out on your own first. Hope that helps!"

The title of the post is "Funded PhD programs in the US are a myth?". The text of the post reads as follows:

thumbnailUrlemore alike

I am perplexed. A while ago, somebody posted a similar question on this sub (can't find it now, sorry!). Some people replied that PhDs in the US are usually funded, and those that are not, are an indication of a bad program or dean.

Now, I am a prospective PhD student in CS, and I have been short-listed for Texas A&M University and University of Wisconsin-Madison. Both programs asked for admission records, 2 letters of recommendation, and NO FINANCIAL SUPPORT DOCUMENTS (no bank statements, no tax returns, nothing). In fact, on the application forms, they have fields for " Lua annual self-funded amount" and "External funding".

EDIT: The fields were indeed for "Expected annual self-funded amount"

Both programs are top-ranked and well-known in the US and internationally. Hence, my question is: how can they possibly admit me without looking at my finances? Do they offer full funding to all admitted students? Is this the norm in the US? If yes, why do they ask for "expected annual self-funded amount"? Am I misunderstanding something? Thanks!

EDIT: I found another question that might be useful for people in a similar situation. It seems like it is customary to email the professor you are interested in working with, and ask about funding opportunities.

I am indeed interested in working with specific professors, but both programs have a "general" application email for inquiries.

Again, sorry if this question is redundant. I tried to search for it but couldn't find it. Would appreciate it if someone could link the original question if it indeed exists. Thanks!

There seems to be a never-ending debate on the extent of Wolverine's healing factor. How fast does it heal? Do mutations stack? Is his bone laced with an adamantium analog?

First, let's establish the points that everyone seems to agree on.

His healing factor allows him to regenerate damaged or destroyed tissue with a speed far greater than any natural organism and comparable to many supernatural beings.
His healing factor allows him to overcome any disease, regardless of how lethal it may be to humans.
His healing factor provides him immunity to most (if not all) drugs and toxins regardless of dosage. Many of these would simply be metabolized and expelled from his body immediately.

Now, let's examine the claims that people seem to dispute:

There seems to be a split on whether his healing factor allows him to regenerate lost limbs or not. I've seen people claim that it does and people claim that it doesn't.

There seems to be a split on whether his healing factor allows him to regenerate without limitation. I've seen people claim that it does and people claim that it doesn't and that the bad guys just haven't figured out how to hurt him yet.

Now, for my own personal take on it (because I think we all know that's what you're here for).

I think Wolverine's healing factor regenerates lost limbs provided they are still partially attached and he has sufficient blood flow to the detached portion. Examples would be Tiger Claws ripping his arm off at the shoulder or Lady Deathstrike nearly severing his right arm. In both cases, the limb was still partially attached and he was able to regrow it. In the case of his hand being blown off by the Hand, it was completely detached and far away from his body. I do not believe his healing factor regenerated his hand in this case.

For his healing factor's limitations, I believe it has unlimited potential but is limited by the speed at which his body can regenerate. I believe that there is a threshold of trauma beyond which his body cannot regenerate quickly enough to save him from death (perhaps a combination of the severity of the wound and the time it takes his body to regenerate). An example of this is the atomic bomb. I do not believe his healing factor could possibly keep up with the amount of trauma inflicted on his body by an atomic bomb. Another example could be if he was decapitated. His body can obviously regenerate a lost head but I do not believe it could do so

In an early scene of Martin Scorsese's 3-D children's film "Hugo," an orphan boy named Hugo (Asa Butterfield) gets trapped inside the clock tower of a Paris train station, and the camera pans around him in a dizzying display of techno-wizardry. It's hard not to think of another Martin Scorsese movie, "Taxi Driver," in which a character describes the nausea induced by riding a fairground carousel. Fairgrounds and circuses are places of both wonder and nausea, of illusion and reality, and Scorsese uses the 3-D here to explore those contradictions, to plunge us into the depths of Hugo's world and also to keep us at a distance from it. It's an appropriate choice, given the story's origins in a book by Brian Selznick ("The Invention of Hugo Cabret"), which itself combines photographs and illustrations.

The story begins in a train station, where Hugo lives behind the walls with his faithful canine companion, Scorsese's camera swooping over the gears and wheels of a giant clock before landing on the boy's anxious face. The film then jumps back in time to tell Hugo's story, which begins in a dying town where he lives with his father (Jude Law), who repairs clocks. When his father is murdered by a mysterious man and presumably dies himself, Hugo escapes to the city, where he lives in the walls of the train station, stealing apples and avoiding the station inspector (Ray Winstone). Eventually, he is caught and nearly sent to an orphanage, but he manages to escape with the help of an eccentric toy shop owner named Georges (Ben Kingsley), whose goddaughter Isabelle (Chlo Grace Moretz) has a curious connection to Hugo's past.

It's a complex plot, and Scorsese directs with his usual fluency, shifting between past and present and moving his camera with infectious joy. The 3-D effect is sometimes subtle, sometimes showy, but it's always integrated into the storytelling. (It's never used to throw things at the camera, a relief.) The early scenes between Hugo and Isabelle are charming, and the movie is at its best when it sticks to the story of the two lonely children and the mysterious past they share. The story's solution to the mystery of Hugo's father's death is a letdown, however, relying on a deus ex machina and a conveniently placed notebook.

But the movie's true pleasures are more modest, including

While the fighting in "Never Back Down" is gritty and brutal, the message is empowering. A depressed teenager suddenly develops self-esteem when he discovers MMA. The idea for the script is clever. The message is straightforward and arrives in the first scene: a bullied kid suffers constant abuse from classmates, then goes home to an abusive father. After the dad nearly strangles him, the son breaks free and tells him, "You'll never lay a hand on me again." Then he moves in with his aunt. There's nothing subtle about the message; it's not meant to be. This is a story about a kid standing up for himself. 

The fight scenes are realistically brutal. They're also well-choreographed and don't look fake. As the protagonist gains confidence, the fights get more intense and brutal. An early bout against a bully is a short one. The antagonist wins easily. Then our hero gets trained by a grizzled, quasi-mystic MMA fighter who "sees" the kid has "heart." Heart is the most important attribute for a fighter. The trainer is a compelling character: He delivers his lines with understated deadpan, then kicks ass in the ring. 

The protagonist gets good enough to compete in a MMA tournament. His first bout is against a scared opponent who takes a brutal beating. Then he faces a highly-regarded local fighter who nearly kills him. It's a great fight. The finale is against the bully who started it all. The fight is intense, and the message is clear: stand up for yourself. You'll never back down.

This movie was okay merely for the fact that it's almost impossible not to find Owen Wilson entertaining. The story was slightly predictable and there were a few things that didn't make sense (like the garage sale with the baseball cards?) but it was entertaining for the most part. I especially liked the scenes in which Danny was getting closer to his son. Those were the best parts of the movie. Some decent laughs, but nothing spectacular. definetly could have been better.

I think the idea behind the movie was interesting, however i feel that it was too forced sometimes and it didn't flow as well as it could have.

Hardball is a 2001 movie starring Keanu Reeves. It is a film about a convict who is released from prison to coach a team of inner-city kids in the game of baseball. It is a remarkable story of redemption and second chances. Not only does Keanu Reeves give a great performance, but the baseball action is thrilling. Although the story is a bit predictable, Hardball is still a very enjoyable film.

The movie captures the importance of teamwork, commitment, and friendship. It is a movie that the whole family can enjoy together. Although it is a bit on the sentimental side, the movie is well-made and entertaining. It is a film that will make you laugh and cry. It is a great film about the power of second chances and the importance of giving people a chance to prove themselves. Highly recommended!

Giving this a boost up from 1 1/2 stars to 2 stars. Why? Because I caught myself smiling, tapping my feet, and appreciating the dance numbersand that's about all this vapid but innocuous film aiming low and hitting its target asks of its audience.

It's astonishing to me that a film could be made in 2008 about people who appear to have no connection to any current cultural, social, or technological developments yet still be released by a major studio. That's borderline charming in and of itself. Any movie that manages to make the mainstream despite an apparent complete unawareness of the current year (and, apparently, many of the preceding years), deserves a certain amount of respect.

But it's harder to admire the film's complete lack of ambition. Step Up is a story about a young man who wants to become a professional dancer but can't because he lives in a place where that's not possible, and a young woman who seems to have everything but is similarly thwarted by her background and circumstances. Their solution? Throw a party on a roof top and dance the night away, hoping that someone important will be impressed. It's like if Billy Elliott decided to become a dancer by throwing a rave in an abandoned mine and hoping the DJ notices him.

The problem is that stories like this demand a certain amount of world-building in order to make their simple plots workambition has to be tempered with a more realistic outlook on life, and characters who are inherently self-interested have to do things that are a bit more subtle in order to achieve their goals. Compare this to something like Fame, which managed to make a more effective and inspiring story about aspiring performers despite being made in 1980. The difference is in the detailsFame didn't just throw its characters on stage and hope that was enough, it showed them struggling to make it there.

But Step Up doesn't concern itself with detailsits characters are paper thin, its story is paint-by-numbers, and its ending is inevitable. And yet.. the dance numbers are surprisingly well-choreographed and entertaining. I found myself tapping my feet along with several of the songs, and even though the "story" was trying my patience at times I was still somewhat entertained by the time the end credits rolled.

I don't know. This is the kind of film I would have dismissed out of hand a few years ago, butlike I saidI found myself enjoying it far more than I expected to

Even though this is a movie That covers only a week of the war Efforts of the citizens of Dunkirk during world war 2, It is still an epic and one that masterfully highlights the futility of war Through the powerfully Subtle acting of Tom Hardy And the entire cast. It also Highlights the courage and bravery of everyday people when faced with adversity, Regardless of their own fears and apprehensions.

The most striking Feature of this film is how little dialogue There is Yet Tom Hardy Still manages To evoke emotion and understanding Through intense facial Expressions, notably in His protective efforts of the young Fifer.

An Homage to the British war Effort, this film Deserves to be seen by audiences of all ages and nationalities As a testament to the human Spirit's endurance In the face of imminent danger.

A standalone film about the Joker, for a change, seems like a really bad idea, but somehow they managed to pull it off. It's a pretty decent psychological thriller, nothing side-splittingly funny about it, but a pretty solid movie overall. It's also nice to see Joaquin Phoenix portray a character radically different from his last few roles (although having a beard and long hair doesn't really make him "unrecognizable")

You can definitely see some of the inspiration from the classic Batman comics, but a lot of it feels really new. The scene where he starts dancing in the bar is straight out of the comics, but the way they weave it into the story feels natural and not at all forced.

Some of the scenes are a little bit confusing, and the ending doesn't really provide any closure. But overall, it's a pretty solid movie that fans of the Joker will definitely enjoy. Call me crazy, but I think this might be the best Batman-related movie since The Dark Knight.

7/10

This text can be classified as a movie review. An IMDb user, presumably, wrote this review after watching the movie "Joker." They discuss their opinion on important elements of the movie, like plot, scene inspiration, and performance. As movie reviews tend to do, this review concludes with a personal rating out of 10.

'Grindhouse' is loads of fun. Split into two movies (because one film was not enough), the menu divides the movies as 'Planet Terror' and 'Death Proof'. 'Planet Terror' is a kick-ass zombie movie. Rose McGowan is mind-blowing as the heartbroken bride. This gives a whole new meaning to the phrase "crazy ex-girlfriend". Plus, you have to see the special feature on this disc where they talk about how they made the effects. It's totally worth the price of the disc. 'Death Proof' is a bit slow at times but overall it's a great disc. The transfer is beautiful and the sound is awesome. There's a making-of documentary on the disc for 'Death Proof' that is really interesting. They had a really small budget but they did a great job. It's awesome that they used a real car instead of a fake one. That's the kind of stuff that makes indie films great. Plus, you gotta love that hard-core couch potato!

While this sequel to the unexpected hit of 1996 has more of everything that made the original so much fun, it still doesn't have enough to really qualify as a great film. The story picks up some time after the first film left off, with Ethan Hunt (Tom Cruise) and his team from the IMF (Impossible Missions Force) given a "mission": to track down a deadly, but very useful, bioweapon called "Chimera", which has fallen into the hands of a rogue IMF agent, Sean Ambrose (John Woo).
