Throughout the course of the film, Hunt and his team (which includes old favorites like Ving Rhames and new members like Canadian flyboy Billy Robinson) must not only track down Ambrose, but also deal with a female assassin known as "The Prophet" (Kristin Scott Thomas), who has her own plans for Chimera.

The plot is nothing special, but the execution is what makes this film work. The action sequences are even more outrageous than before, with the first half hour being a nearly nonstop assault on the senses as Hunt and his team board a heavily-armed train in Russia in order to retrieve the Chimera canisters. The film's biggest set piece comes towards the end, when Hunt must confront Ambrose and The Prophet on the rooftop of a partly-constructed building (this sequence was shot in a single take, which adds to the enjoyment of it). The film also features a fun cameo by couture-clad legend Catherine Deneuve.

The cast is good across the board. Tom Cruise seems to be having an even better time this time around, and his chemistry with Michelle Monaghan (as Hunt's girlfriend) is excellent. Jonathan Rhys-Davies returns briefly as Fallout, and is given considerably more to do this time around (including a funny scene where he squares off against Rhames). John Woo also appears as Ambrose, and does a good job of playing the role as a sort of "IMF version" of himself. But the prize for "best performance" goes to Kristin Scott Thomas, who manages to make The Prophet a compelling character despite being given virtually nothing to work with.

This is the type of mindless, "popcorn movie" that Hollywood does best, and while it's no "Casablanca", it's the type of film that it's almost impossible not to enjoy.

Vanilla Sky is one of the most disappointing experiences of my life. I usually avoid reading or listening to any reviews of movies that I'm about to see, but in this case, I wish I had because it would have saved me the price of a ticket and nearly two hours of my time. Tom Cruise portrays a shallow, self-absorbed, and creepy character who ultimately deserves all of the misery that comes his way. Cameron Diaz is even worse - she absolutely ruins what little plot the movie has. She comes across as a carbon copy of Kate Moss with none of the charm and all of the attitude. The only performance that somewhat shines is that of Jason Lee. Yet despite how talented an actor he is, he cannot salvage this sinking ship. The plot is paper-thin, and the ending doesn't even make any sense. Like many other critics have said, Philip Haas might have been a good director for this movie, but Cameron Crowe definitely wasn't. Save your time and money, unless you enjoy boring, poorly-written, and nonsensical movies.

This is a long movie. And it's pretty slow for the first two hours. But damn, is the last hour and a half awesome. It's probably the best hour and a half of any movie I've ever seen.

The story is a simple one. Two friends grow up together, and form a gang. One of the friends gets caught up in the gang life, and the other wants nothing to do with it. And that's basically the story. But the way it's told is what makes the movie so great.

The acting is top-notch. De Niro and Pacino are both amazing, as always. And the supporting cast is great too. The direction is also fantastic. Sergio Leone really knew how to make a movie.

The score is probably the best score I've ever heard in a movie. It's so well done, and really adds to the atmosphere of the film.

So, if you're looking for a great movie, I would highly recommend "Once Upon a Time in America". Just be prepared to invest some time in it. It's worth every minute.

'Stalingrad' is probably the most grueling, visceral and graphic movie I've ever seen.

The plight of the Russian soldiers in the city and the depravity of the German soldiers trying to kill them is so well documented here. This movie is uncompromising in its portrayal of war. There are no heroes, just people doing their best to survive hell. There's no glamour, just guts, blood, tears, and carnage.

There are two lengthy scenes of hand-to-hand combat inside a building that are breathtaking. The melee fighting is so intense and relentless, you can almost feel the madness and desperation of the soldiers.

The movie is also not afraid to show the effects of war extended over months of constant fighting. Most of the soldiers, Russian or German, are worn, dirty, and unkempt. Their clothes and uniforms are ragged and torn. They are often hungry, exhausted, and scared.

All the acting is top-notch but Joseph Millson as Captain Pyotr Varyavski and Thomas Kretschmann as General Paulus are both superb.

If you are at all squeamish or if you can't take intense, graphic violence, then stay away. If you want to see one of the most brutal, honest, and gut-wrenching movies ever made about war, then watch 'Stalingrad'.

A top 10 film for me.

No other movie -- NO OTHER MOVIE -- has as many scenes that have riveted me, from the terrifying "pump" scene forward; from the terrifyingly well-made "two mugs" scene (with a hilarious payoff) to the stunning conclusion, in which a good man is forced to choose, for his soul, between his loyalty to the Navy and his instinct to do right by his fellow man.

This is filmmaking at its most urgently involving, and no scene is wasted. This is also actorly virtuosity at its most thrilling: Van Johnson, playing a handsome sailor with a steel core, gives a performance that is nothing short of electrifying; and Tom Tully, as the ship's doctor, has one scene in which he underplays to such a degree that you almost don't notice what a good actor he is. But you can't miss the performances of Humphrey Bogart and Van Johnson, two brilliant actors at the top of their game, working together as rivals and soul mates.

And talk about a payoff! The court-martial scene is one of the most riveting 30 minutes in movie history, with Kenyon delivering one of the greatest speeches ever written for any movie, answering the charge that he's gone crazy with the most passionate defense of his right to sanity ever uttered. ("Sanity? You want sanity? You want a sane captain? Is that what you want?"") It's a stunning speech, and the performance behind it is equally stunning. When Van Johnson shoots back with his own passionate speech, it's more than thrilling; it's one of the greatest scenes in movie history, and it's played by two actors at the top of their form.

And the ending? It's perfect. A lesser filmmaker would have tried to tie up all the loose ends, but Lang doesn't try; he leaves it up to you to figure out what happens to each of the characters, and in what order. But the final image, of the captain returning to his ship, is one of the most haunting and hauntingly beautiful images ever committed to film; it's an image that stays with you, resonating with power and beauty, long after the movie has ended.

This is a great film, one of the greatest ever made. See it. See it again. Then see it again.

(NOTE: This review was originally published in 2010)

Watched this again the other night. Still blows me away. Everything about this film is absolutely superb. From the casting to the cinematography, direction, and writing. It's ridiculous how well this film does in each and every aspect.

The story is intriguing and entertaining, and the characters are incredibly well-written and well-developed. The cast is superb, with each and every actor and actress giving a great performance. The cinematography is beautiful, and the action scenes are well-done and thrilling.

This is, without a doubt, one of the best films of all time. It's just so well-done in every aspect, and it's absolutely fascinating from beginning to end. If you're a fan of Westerns or just great films in general, this is a must-see.

You're in for a real treat with "Tombstone." It's an absolutely fantastic film that will keep you entertained and engaged from the beginning to the end.

"Edmund Kenire's performance is the sole redeeming factor in this excruciatingly bad portrayal of the Cinderella Man story. Russell Crowe looks the part, and does act with his usual bravura, but his Billy is a cartoon, a cliche, a collection of tricks borrowed from 1950's Hollywood, all teeth and twitches and greasy hair. There's not a moment of identification with this creature, nor belief that he could inspire the hundreds of men who followed him into the furnace of the boxing arena. The contrast with the brilliant Ron Howard portrayal of the same real-life character in *A Beautiful Mind* could not be more stark. From the outset we are asked to accept that Braddock is a failing boxer because of the economic climate of the times, although there is not a hint of hardship when he visits restaurants and cocktail bars several times a week and spends hundreds of dollars on clothes. When he finally does become hungry it is only so he can briefly play at being a starving pugilist before a conveniently located cornerman offers him a steak dinner. Along with Billy's rise from mediocrity to champion, the film also asks us to believe that his wife, played by Rene Zellweger, would abandon those she loves in favour of a mobster and then return to her family with no explanation. Although she performs creditably in the role, Zellweger is miscast, and her character is written as a fairy-tale princess, not the real woman who survived the Depression alongside her husband. The story itself, worthy as it may be, is not credible as portrayed here, and the writers try too hard to inject artificial notes of suspense and excitement into the proceedings. At the end, when Billy wins the title in a Cinderella finish, we are expected to burst into tears, not for him, but because we have been forced to sit through this endurance test of a film for the previous two hours."

Surprisingly...this movie doesn't completely suck. I'm not saying it's a great movie, but it certainly doesn't deserve the almost unanimous hatred that it receives. It's evident that it was a passion project for Sergio Leone, a sort of ode to his childhood, to the people he loved and to the city he loved so much (New York). And in that regard, the movie is a success. There's something very sincere about it, and Leoni's obsession with Noodles (the character) is kinda cute and goes a long way to making the movie work. De Niro is OK, but honestly, James Woods OWNs this movie. He's terrible, but in a very fun way. Overall, the movie is too long and flawed, but I think it's more interesting than most mafia movies and has some really amazing scenes. Not great, but certainly not the trainwreck that everyone says it is.

Despite being cartoony, this is a fun movie, with jokes for both kids and adults. The plot is nothing special, but the execution is excellent. The characters are well drawn and the voice acting is top notch. It's also nice to see a movie that is not overwhelmed with pop culture references.

The plot is driven by a group of chickens, owned by Mrs. Tweedy, who live on a farm in England. Mrs. Tweedy is a mean woman who treats the chickens like objects. The chickens decide to rebel against Mrs. Tweedy and escape the farm.

The movie follows the chickens as they assemble a group of roosters to help them escape. The group includes an American rooster named Chuck, who is a stuntman and artiste, and a Welsh rooster named Eddie, who is a former drill instructor. The chickens also encounter a group of mice, who are trying to escape the farm as well.

The chickens and mice work together to come up with a plan to escape. The plan involves building a rocket ship and launching themselves off the farm. The group has to deal with a number of obstacles, including a rat named Freddie and a guard dog named Max.

The movie is full of funny moments, especially involving the chickens. The chickens are all unique and have their own personalities. The voice acting is especially good, with Julia Sawalha standouts as the nervous Bunty.

Chicken Run is a fun and entertaining movie that is perfect for the whole family. It's a great example of a movie that is not overly complicated, but is still a lot of fun to watch. The characters are well drawn and the voice acting is top notch. It's also nice to see a movie that is not overwhelmed with pop culture references, as many family movies are these days.

Schindler's List is quite simply one of the greatest films ever made. It is a powerful depiction of the Holocaust, mainly through the eyes of Oskar Schindler, a greedy Nazi who gradually has his eyes opened to the horrors of Hitler's regime and eventually does whatever it takes to save the lives of more than a thousand Jews.

It is powerful, epic, and heartbreaking, and features what may be the best performance of Tom Hanks' career (and certainly the best of Liam Neeson's career). The drama is taut, the action sequences are thrilling, and the entire film is an incredible piece of filmmaking.

There are films that are important because they tackle subjects that should not be forgotten, that should be remembered and taught to every new generation. This is one of those films. It is gripping, suspenseful, and utterly unforgettable. It is mandatory viewing, in my opinion, for anyone who considers themselves a student of film, or history, or both.

Simply put, this is a film that everyone should see at least once, if not more. It is not an enjoyable film per se, but it is a film that should be seen.

A handful of memorable sequences offer a jolt of excitement amidst a haze of mediocrity in this revival of Universal's classic monster franchise. 

Cruise is a dependable star presence, but this role doesn't have enough depth or complexity to truly challenge him. Likewise, Crowe's performance is mostly just a more weathered version of the director's usual persona. Aside from a couple of derivative action set pieces, there isn't enough here to make "The Mummy" stand out from any other moderately entertaining summer action flick. 

The film is at its best when it slows down and focuses on the relationship between its two leads. The chemistry between Cruise and Crowe is easy and often playful, and it helps to cover up the script's deficiencies. The dialogue is occasionally laughably bad, but the two actors manage to keep the film afloat during its first two acts. 

The third act turns into a predictable collection of action movie cliches. The final showdown is a visually impressive set piece, but it's missing the emotional weight needed to make it truly satisfying. 

"The Mummy" is a mostly forgettable summer action flick that offers a few exciting moments but little else.

AlthoughPrincess Mononoke ''''only'''' has a 68% critic rating on Rotten Tomatoes, I think it''s arguably one of the best films ever created. It can be difficult to follow at times, but therein lies the beauty of it: it does not pander to the audience. It is never watered down. The characters are vivid and alive, the battles are intense, and the underlying messages are far more profound than most modern animation films aimed at adults. At its core, it is a coming-of-age story about environmentalism, and man''s role in preserving the balance of nature. Even the English version''s casting is superb. Billy Crudup, Billy Bob Thornton, and Gillian Anderson all provide excellent voices for their respective characters. If you''re interested in animation as an art form, I would certainly recommend this film. No exaggeration: it''s one of my favorites.

I'm curious how much comedic license was taken with the historical events of Stalin's death. Some of the humor seems to indicate a certain familiarity with the characters and events of the time and/or a loose interpretation of the truth, which given the subjects involved is problematic. But that's basically my only complaint. Otherwise, this film was surprisingly funny, cramming as many laugh-out-loud jokes and gags into 109 minutes as possible. Some of the humor is a bit raunchy, but most of it hits its mark. There are some truly hilarious bits and the cast obviously had a lot of fun filming this. Some reviews seem to take the film a bit too seriously, losing the forest for the trees, but if you can laugh along with the absurdity of the situation and the characters, this is easily one of the funniest films of the year. Obviously not for everyone, but for fans of the cast and British comedy, this comes highly recommended.

Genre: Horror, Thriller
Director: Brian De Palma
Producer: Paul Hirsch
Writer: Lawrence D. Cohen, based on the novel by Stephen King
Stars: Sissy Spacek, John Travolta, William Katt, Piper Laurie

After a traumatic experience at her high school prom, neglected outsider Carrie (Sissy Spacek) is shocked to discover that she has developed a strange, newfound power: she can controland even causeelectricity. Meanwhile, her classmates plot revenge against her, after the prom incident has left one of their peers (William Katt) paralyzed. Led by a morally bankrupt religious fanatic (Piper Laurie), the classmates' harassment of Carrie gradually turns into all-out terror, and anyone else around her starts to feel their wrath, as well. 

This stylishly made horror picture benefits from a strong performance by Spacek in the title role.

Note: This filmbased on a novel by Stephen Kingwas rated PG-13 upon its initial release, because of violence and shock effects. A subsequent re-releasewith several scenes trimmed to avoid a 'PG' ratingwas rated R. The film was re-released on videocassette in 2002, with both the 'PG-13' and 'R' versions available on separate cassettes.

The Fighter is a drama directed by David O. Russell, starring Mark Wahlberg, Christian Bale and Amy Adams. The story is a gritty, working-class drama about a boxer (Mark Wahlberg) who tries to make his way in the sport he's always loved. He's determined to go to the top, but his lifelong reliance on his brother (Christian Bale) both in and out of the ring has left him unprepared for the ruthless world of professional sports. The two brothers' relationship is put to the test as the older brother tries to teach the younger one how to be a man and take care of his family.
The movie was praised for its powerful performances and compelling story, and received six Academy Award nominations, including Best Picture, Best Director and Best Supporting Actor for Bale. It won two awards for Bale's performance and for the film's screenplay. 

The movie was rated R for language throughout and some violent content. 

Do you have any other questions about the movie?

A tough, gritty WWII actioner, showcasing solid performances, awesome battle scenes, slick editing, and brilliant cinematography. It also has a very odd, but interesting narrative structure. I really liked this film, and think that it is vastly underrated. Sure, it's depressing as hell, but it's also very educational, and has an oddly inspirational vibe to it. It's also got some really great battle scenes, and intriguing characters. Sure, the narrative structure is weird, and can be frustrating at times, but other than that, this film is great. Solid 4/5.

Beside him, Regina Hall is fabulous as the assistant, and they have great chemistry. The supporting cast is solid as well. This is a fun movie, and a great one to watch with your friends. Fans of the book will enjoy seeing their favorite scenes on the big screen, and people who haven't read the book will enjoy it as a stand-alone movie. This is one instance where the movie is as good as, if not better than, the book.

A lot of the reviews I agree with, however, I think some are being a bit harsh. While it is unrealistic that two unskilled individuals become pro gamblers, I don't think that it was ever intended as completely realistic. Brad and Amy are highly intelligent and quick-witted; they simply need some direction to harness their potential. The "direction" comes in the form of a mentor, played by Al Pacino, who does an excellent job. I think that the movie, like the book, is intended to be a fun, mindless adventure, not an accurate portrayal of gambling pros.

In summary, I think that the common criticism that the plot is overly-simplistic is valid, but I don't think it's a big enough flaw to warrant a bad review. If you go into the movie expecting Mindless Entertainment, you'll enjoy it.

As cheesy as it comes, still a good movie tho. If you're in the mood for some sap then this is the movie for you. It's basically "The Notebook" but less dysfunctional and more innocent. Love stories with a fatal illness tend to tug at your heartstrings, especially if its a good one. This one does just that. I really liked the performance of Mandy Moore in this, she was excellent and very convincing. This movie made me cry like a baby despite knowing how it ends. If you're a person who likes happy endings, then this movie is guaranteed to make you feel warm and fuzzy all over.

A word of caution, if you're not into romantic movies then this isn't for you, stay away! You've been warned :)

A few years after retiring from the police, Benjamn Esposito (Gael Garca Bernal) gets a phone call from a colleague telling him that the man who was responsible for the death of his daughter, Sofa, has been found and is ready to leave jail. The man, Flix Mantero (Ricardo Darn), is freed because of a lack of evidence, and Benjamn is consumed by anger and the desire for revenge. He decides to kill Flix, and plans to do it in a way that won't raise any suspicions. He comes up with various plans, each more macabre than the last, and in the process becomes increasingly obsessed with the idea. At the same time, he starts a relationship with a woman named Irene (Soledad Villamil), who is aware of his plans, and encourages him to get closure with what happened to Sofa. 

I really liked the way this film was shot, and the story kept me on the edge of my seat from beginning to end. The plot is interesting and well executed, and the characters are well developed. The film is in Spanish, with English subtitles, and I thought the subtitles were at times a little hard to follow. A few times I had to reread them to make sure I understood what was going on. Overall, I thought this was an excellent film, and I would highly recommend it.

Based on true events, Argo is the nail-biting account of the life-and-death covert operation to rescue six Americans from Tehran during the 1979 Iranian hostage crisis. The plan: to pretend that they are part of a fictitious Canadian film crew seeking to make a movie in Iran. The ruse works long enough for them to get out of the country, but it leaves behind a frightened, confused and vulnerable woman, whose suspicious behavior leads Iranian authorities to uncover the truth.collections.imdb.com/title/tt2395861/reviews?ref_=tt_urv

This movie started off great creepy, eerie, unsettling. However, the last quarter (or more) of the movie was so ridiculous that I was almost crawling out of my skin. I don't know if I was supposed to take the events at the end as straight horror, or if it was supposed to be comedic, but I didn't find it funny. It was just plain annoying In fact, I found the entire movie somewhat annoying. Maybe it was just me. I liked the actress who played "Mama", and I thought the storyline was good - until the very end. The filming was well done, and the sound, music, and effects were also good. I could have done without all the stupid "found footage" sequences, however. They didn't add anything to the movie, in my opinion, and were extremely annoying.

While it will never reach the stratospheric highs of its predecessor, Monsters University is a nevertheless delightful, humourous and heartfelt continuation of the Monsters Inc. story. Setting the film in the earlier days of Mike and Sully's friendship sheds some much needed light on the origins of two of Pixar's most beloved characters, and offers a strong excuse to reprise the antics of the original. There are some slight structural issues and a weak subplot, but the humour and heart of Monsters Inc. have returned in full force. Whereas that film emphasised the relationship between the two monsters, this prequel is just as concerned with their individual character development. This works wonders for the film, because it allows each new scenario to serve as a learning experience for our two heroes. The lack of similarity between the two films is actually to Monsters University's benefit, preventing it from being labelled as a mere retread of the original.  

The story focuses on the relationship between Monsters Inc. stars Mike Wazowski and James P. Sullivan in their college years at Monsters University. The two, who start off as rivals, must team up in an effort to win the annual Scare Games and earn their place as scarers at Monsters Inc. Overall, Monsters University is another winner from Pixar, offering plenty of humour and heart that is sure to please both children and adults alike.

IMAX's version of "Gone With the Wind" is exciting, and a great way to preserve a treasured film's legacy, but you'd best have plenty of time (3 hours and 39 minutes, to be exact) and a strong bladder to fully appreciate this magnificent cinematic experience.

Assuming you do, what you'll see is a 70mm print of the revised version of the film transferred to digital, with several scenes that were previously cropped to allow for the 1.43:1 aspect ratio IMAX favours.

Is it worth the price of admission? For fans of the film who have never seen it on a big screen, absolutely, but you'd best come armed with prior knowledge of the film's plot, or else you'll be quickly overwhelmed by the pace, and unsure of why anyone would choose to preserve such a seemingly racist and ideologically flawed narrative.

Gone With the Wind (1939) is a seminal moment in the history of American cinema, an epic adaptation of Margaret Mitchell's novel of the same name that firmly established producer David O. Selznick's reputation as a maker of grand, star-crossed romantic dramas, and typically revolves around its central performance by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara, a strong-willed, sexually-charged southern belle who's determined to survive, and even thrive, during the American Civil War.

O'Hara is a controversial character, particularly for a feminist perspective, as she evolves from a selfish, ego-driven woman whose principal motivation is preserving her way of life, to a stoic, one-dimensional figure who's slowly hardened by war, and determined to reclaim her lost love, even if it means losing any trace of her femininity.

This transition is borne out of a sexist double-standard, as the film excuses her actions as being driven by "magnolia" pride, but any man who behaved in a similar fashion would be roundly dismissed as being weak, and in desperate need of rehabilitation.

Despite this significant flaw, the film is an impressive piece of entertainment, featuring spectacular set pieces, a stellar cast, and one of the most expensive productions of its time, and for decades has been preserved as an invaluable artifact of a bygone era of Hollywood filmmaking.

As such, it's great to see it presented so lovingly by The Film Foundation and IMAX, and for audiences who appreciate cinema as a historical document, this is essential viewing.

However, beyond the impressive scope and undeniable craft

A tough-minded, wildly original mom who happens to be a brilliant inventor gets a chance to chase her dreams. An instant holiday classic that lights up the season with an uplifting tale of family togetherness and invention. A great performance by Jennifer Lawrence with strong support from Robert De Niro and Bradley Cooper. A lot of fun and immensely entertaining. This film also features some tough subjects such as divorce, poverty, blended families, and more, but does it in a way that is inspiring and not at all depressing. A great film for the whole family.

visionary masterpiece. i've never seen a film like it. it's abrasive, challenging, and intense, but it's also gorgeous, elegant, and graceful. harry bergmann's cinematography is utterly breathtaking, and the entire cast gives stunning, fearless performances. i was completely riveted from start to finish. muscle movies like this are about as far from my comfort zone as films get, but i'm so glad i saw it. it's unlike anything else out there. 

i saw it twice at south by southwest 2019, and i plan to own it as soon as it's available. visionary, brutal, sublime.

This is not only one of the greatest movies ever made, but one that is arguably the most influential. It's hard to turn on a TV or go to the movies today and not see something that was inspired by Casablanca - from the dramatic lighting, to the stories of ordinary people caught in the crosscurrents of history, to the idea that true love can still prevail, no matter how tough the circumstances. Of course, none of this would matter if the actors didn't bring the script to life. Ingrid Bergman gives one of the most compelling performances in movie history. Humphrey Bogart is at his hard-boiled best, and even turns in a few lighter moments as well. And despite the fact that everyone knows the famous lines ahead of time, they still deliver the punch as if they were brand new. If you haven't seen this movie, stop what you're doing, and watch it now!

I haven't had this much fun at the movies in a long time. Captain America: The First Avenger pays homage to the Captain America comics of the 1940s, and serves as a perfect origin story to get us ready for Captain America: The Avengers next summer. It's also an origin story for the Marvel Cinematic Universe itself: we learn how Agent Peggy Carter got her start with S.H.I.E.L.D., and how Steve Rogers became Captain America, but along the way, we get introduced to Dr. Abraham Erskine, Howard Stark, Agent Phil Coulson--and Thor's hammer!--all of which put a big smile on my face. And William Hurt excels as the Nazi villain, while Stanley Tucci is a hoot as Dr. Erskine. This is a retro superhero movie, and I mean that in the best possible way. It's thrilling, funny, and captivating, and Anthony Mackie is a terrific scene-stealer as the winged fighter known as the Falcon. Can't wait to see this again before 2011 comes to a close.

A superb script and a great ensemble cast add up to 10 stars. This movie solidifies Tarantino's reputation as one of our greatest directors ever; working mostly with a strong script, as compared to his other films that were heavier on the flash and glamour of filmmaking, this film is all about the dialogue and the characters, and boy does it ever deliver. This film approaches Shakespearean levels of dialogue in a good way. Every character is so well written and so deeply flawed, and the way the characters interact with each other is a joy to watch. There isn't a single false note in the entire cast's performances, and the film is just as funny as it is harrowing and thrilling. Go into this one as cold as possible, and I have no doubt you'll enjoy it. Rarely does a film live up to the hype as well as this one does.

This is probably the best "cops & robbers" type movie that I have ever seen. It has a complex but engaging story, intelligently written and thoughtfully acted by a cast of first rate character actors. The plot is complicated, and involves many twists and turns, so pay attention or you may get lost. It is also a very brutal and realistic portrayal of crime and police work, so this is not a "feel good" movie, but it is not depressing either. If you enjoy thinking about a movie after you finish watching it, this is the movie for you.

The story is essentially a cat-and-mouse game, with DeNiro as the "cat" and Al Pacino as the "mouse," and the scenes in which they "play" are the best of the movie. These two actors are a study in contrasts, and their scenes together are fascinating to watch. DeNiro is the "professional" criminal, while Pacino is the "blue collar" cop, and the difference in their styles is the main theme of the story. Pacino uses brute force and his street smarts to try to track down DeNiro and his crew, while DeNiro uses planning and finesse to try to stay one step ahead of the law.

The supporting performances are also outstanding, especially from Val Kilmer as a "professional" criminal who is trying to go straight, but gets drawn into one last job. The scene in which he and his wife are having dinner with DeNiro and his crew, and DeNiro tries to convince Kilmer to do "one last job" is classic.

This is a long movie, but it is not boring or slow moving for a second. The action scenes are well done and exciting, and the story keeps you involved and interested from beginning to end. This is a "thinking man's" action movie, and is an outstanding addition to the genre.

This is it. The mother of all jidai geki. The film that summed up Mizoguchi's recurrent themes (and preoccupations), and also the apex of his achievement, of his trilogy revolving around women (the other two being "Ugetsu" and "Sansho Dayu"). And quite possibly the greatest film ever made.

"Ran" depicts the tragedy of a noble family's decline, when the beloved son of a warrior decides to betray his father and marry a lower-class woman, and the consequences of this act of betrayal. The father loses his mind, and becomes a cruel and vicious ruler, who sees treachery and betrayal everywhere. He is willing to sacrifice his granddaughter for the sake of his honor, willing to commit murder and massacre to avenge the death of his favorite son. And yet, the film does not judge him. It acknowledges the tragedy and the pathos of his situation, as a ruler whose megalomania and obsession with loyalty and honor have brought doom upon his family and his people. And it is this very pathos that ultimately generates the incredible sadness and power of "Ran".

This is the film where Mizoguchi's recurrent visual and formal preoccupations reach their climax. The use of landscape and space, the circular and recursive movements, the importance of sight and visibility, the off-center framing, the chiaroscuro, the use of mist and rain as emotional sublimation Everything is pushed to the maximum here, with incredible results. This is also the film where Mizoguchi's typically Japanese approach to narrative reaches its apex. There is something incredibly distinctive in the way Mizoguchi tells his story, in the way he chooses to linger on faces and landscapes, in the way he is not afraid to pause, to take his time, to have his characters walk, to move in circles, to repeat actions This is not a filmmaker who wants to excite or move his audience with the thrills of action or the rapidity of editing. On the contrary, he wants to immerse them into his narrative, to involve them, to make them identify with his characters, to experience their emotions and feelings, to live with them.

This involves incredible acting. Despite being nearly 40 years old when he directed "Ran", Mizoguchi had an incredible talent for working with actors, and this is evident in the incredible, nuanced, and deeply moving performances he was able to extract from his cast. The madness and violence of the patriarch, the bitterness and

The Simpsons Movie is a comedy that stretches the limits of plausibility to the breaking point and beyond. Homer Simpson (Dan Castellaneta) is summoned to Springfield Museum, where he discovers that the ancient Egyptian mummy of Prince Nebra (Oded Fehr) has been stolen. The culprit is a mysterious volcano that erupted and poured its hot lava all over the museum, destroying it and allowing the thief to escape. Captain Wackner (Thomas Kretschmann) lays the blame on Homer and promptly fires him. Homer returns home to find his wife Marge (Julie Kavner) in a state over the condition of their house. Homer is oblivious to her concerns and prefers to watch TV, so to teach him a lesson, Marge hides the remote control. Homer inexplicably climbs onto the roof to contemplate his life, only to fall through it and into the basement. There he discovers a hole in the basement wall and decides to investigate its origins, despite Marge's protests. He travels through the hole and into Springfield's sewer system, where he meets up with his friends Bart (Nancy Cartwright), Lenny (Harry Shearer), and Carl (Hank Azaria). Together, they decide to explore the sewer system further, only to discover that it leads directly to the power plant. There, they come face to face with the plant's owner, Mr. Burns (Harry Shearer), who's planning to flood Springfield with toxic sludge in order to claim the insurance money and build a new plant. Burns captures Homer's friends and holds them hostage, but Homer manages to escape back to the surface. Upon arriving home, Homer discovers that Marge has filed for divorce. He rushes to the elementary school where Bart and Lisa (Yeardley Smith) are being babysat by Principal Skinner (Harry Shearer) and begins to lament his loss of his family. Hearing this, Bart and Lisa encourage him to save his friends and reunite his family. He returns to the hole in the basement and follows the sewer system to the power plant. There, with the help of his pet rat, Snowball, he rescues his friends and defeats Mr. Burns. Upon returning home, Homer finds Marge on the roof of their house, preparing to jump off. He talks her out of it and the two reconcile. The movie ends with the family together again, watching The Happy Little Elves, a cartoon that Homer, Bart, and Lisa all enjoy.

If the concept of a feature-length Simpsons movie intimidates you, you're not alone.

The movie 'Angels & Demons' is a revolutionary film, in that it takes the bold step of attempting to delve into the human mind, rather than the supernatural one and this affords it a much more realistic approach than most films of this genre. By realistically, I mean that it takes its subject matter seriously and doesn't rely on cheap 'scare' tactics that other films of this type rely on. It also has a much more cerebral approach to the story, which is more akin to 'The Da Vinci Code' rather than the book, on which it is based.

The story revolves around the discovery of a mystical code, that points to the next pope, and evidence of a secret society called 'The Illuminati', that has been secretly controlling the Vatican for centuries and the subsequent 18 hour battle, to prevent 4 kidnapped Cardinals, from being murdered, prior to the conclave.

With an all star cast, including; Tom Hanks, Ewan McGregor, Ayelet Zurer, Stellan Skarsgard & Pierfrancesco Favino, directed by the legendary Ron Howard, this movie, had the makings of a sure fire winner & it manages to achieve this status, by taking itself seriously, which produces in the viewer, a willingness to do the same.

The storyline, although controversial, is a reasonably easy watch & manages to explain itself reasonably well, without leaving the viewer feeling as though they've missed something, which cannot be said for its predecessor 'The Da Vinci Code'. The cinematography is faultless & the scenery is breathtaking, having been filmed on location, in and around the Vatican, which gives a sense of realism to the story, not often seen.

In conclusion, this film is a welcome addition to any DVD collection, although I wouldn't recommend it to anyone under the age of 15, due to its subject matter. However, for anyone who likes their conspiracy theories, this is right up there with the best of them.

The movie overall was very entertaining. A lot of the scenes had me laughing hysterically and others had me at the edge of my seat. The story was very unique and I enjoyed the film's creativity. The acting was great as well, with stars like Elizabeth Olsen and Julianne Moore. I think that this movie definitely deserved the 84/100 rating that it has on IMDb. It was a great movie and I would definitely recommend it to others.

While a bit on the long side, and a little too condensed in spots, this is a technically superb film, and Matt Damon gives another great performance. It's also refreshing to have a hero who is smart, competent, and who treats everyone around him with respect, even his arch-nemesis. Some of the supporting performances are a bit one-note, but there's not a single bad performance in the bunch. This is definitely one of the better films of the year.

The Martian tells the story of Mark Watney, an astronaut stranded on Mars after a disastrous storm hits his crew's base. Watney is presumed dead by his crewmates, but he survives and finds himself stranded on the hostile planet with only meager supplies, and must find a way to survive until a rescue mission can reach him. The film follows Watney as he adapts to his new surroundings, and eventually finds a way to contact Earth and plead for help.

The film is a technical marvel, and the visuals are stunning. The cinematography is also top-notch, and the film's score is a great addition to the overall experience. The film's only real downside is its length; at nearly two and a half hours, it feels a bit too long in spots. Additionally, some of the supporting characters are a bit underdeveloped, and their relationships with Watney feel a bit forced.

Overall, The Martian is a great film, and a welcome change of pace from the typical summer blockbusters. It's a smart, well-made film, with a great performance from Matt Damon, and some stunning visuals. While it could have used a bit more polish in spots, it's still one of the better films of the year, and well worth checking out.

While it necessarily takes some creative license with the facts, "The Finest Hours" is a rousing action thriller which benefits from a tense scenario and excellent special effects. While the story slows down every now and then, overall this is a fast-paced and very watchable film thanks to strong work from Chris Pine and an unpredictable third act. 

The film is based on the true story of Bernie Webber (Chris Pine), who takes charge of a daring rescue mission to save the crew of the SS Pendleton, which has split in half and sunk in 90 feet of water. With a howling blizzard threatening to blow his small rescue boat off course, Bernie and his three man crew set sail to try and reach the sinking ship before its too late. Meanwhile, the Coast Guard has also dispatched a cutter to help, but it has suffered an mechanical failure and is dead in the water. It's up to Bernie to save the day, and he might not get back in time to save his own marriage in the process. 

"The Finest Hours" is a fairly by-the-numbers action/thriller, but it's a very well made and extremely watchable example of the genre. The story draws from real-life events which are unusual and dramatic enough on their own, and the filmmakers don't shy away from fleshing them out and adding plenty of action and suspense. Bernie's journey to rescue the sinking ship is given just as much attention (if not more) as the Coast Guard's efforts to get their large cutter working again. There's always something at stake, and just when it seems like things can't get any worse, they do. The third act in particular stands out for its many twists and turns, and excellent use of simultaneous action sequences. 

Chris Pine delivers one of his best performances yet as the stalwart and determined Bernie, giving the character a relatable everyman quality that makes you root for him from the start. He has excellent chemistry with Ben Foster, who almost steals the movie as the confident and teasing coxswain Richard. The two have great banter and a nice brotherly relationship which forms the heart of the movie. Thankfully, Bernie's personal life and the obstacles he faces are just as well developed as the rescue mission, giving the movie a good balance between action and character driven drama. 

The effects and cinematography are excellent, and there are some truly awe-inspiring shots of the rescue boats cutting through the giant waves. The blizzard is also used to great effect, constantly threatening

Training Day is a good movie. From the opening scene it draws you in and doesn't let up. It's a modern day film noir; a psychological thriller that doesn't let go. It's edge of your seat entertainment.

Denzel Washington plays Detective Alonzo, a veteran homicide detective who is grooming rookie Detective Ellis (Ethan Hawke) for the dangerous life he leads. On the surface it appears to be a standard "partner movie" but that's only on the surface. As the story unfolds it gets better and better. By the end, you realize that you've just witnessed a modern classic.

The story is tight, well written, and creative. The dialogue is excellent. The scenes are well directed and well acted. There isn't a false note in the whole movie. Denzel Washington gives one of his best performances. Ethan Hawke more than holds his own.

This movie easily holds its own against any of the "greats" from the past. It's up there with the best of them. This movie easily deserves the 6 stars that I give it.

This movie is genius! I haven't laughed this hard in a long time. Steve Carell is fantastic in his role as Andy. He is just so relatable and lovable. He makes you feel for him with his awkwardness and insecurities, and yet he is so charming and sweet. Rose Byrne is also great as the girl of his dreams. She is beautiful and yet so real and down-to-earth. This movie is just so much fun to watch. The 40-Year-Old Virgin is hilarious, sweet, and just an all-around great movie. Carell and Byrne are brilliant together. Highly recommended!

The sex scene toward the end between Donald and a nearly unrecognizable Matt Bomer as an extremely buff version of Ken is worth the price of admission all by itself. But, in fact, the entire movie is a delight, and a worthy successor to the first film. What was essentially a one-joke movie (with a great soundtrack) is now a much more fleshed out (no pun intended) romantic comedy with a message even if it is a bit heavy-handed at times. And the soundtrack is every bit as amazing as you would expect from a Magic Mike movie. All the main players from the first film are back, and the addition of Donald and a surprisingly good Andie MacDowell only add to the fun. This is easily the best romantic comedy of the year so far.

If you're wondering if you should see Magic Mike XXL in the theater or wait for DVD, see it in the theater. It's worth the price. I didn't think the first film warranted a 3D upgrade, but this one did. It's bright, colorful, and the 3D effects are actually worth the price of admission (and I don't say that about many movies). I don't want to give too much away, but there is a sequence at the end during the big dance number that is just hilarious, and it has to be seen in 3D. I don't want to give it away, but suffice it to say that what you think is going to happen at the end...doesn't.

The movie follows soldier ant Zach (voiced by Woody Allen), who's fed up with his same old, dull life in the colony. When he meets the princess of an alien colony, he sees it as his chance to break out of his rut and start over. The voice cast also features Sharon Stone, Sylvester Stallone, and Gene Hackman as Zach's best friend. The animation is top-notch, and the story is both funny and heartfelt. However, the movie's message about the importance of following your dreams is a bit on the nose. Overall, "Antz" is a fun and entertaining film that the whole family can enjoy.

Al Pacino delivers one of his greatest performances ever as Tony Montana, the Cuban refugee who becomes a powerful drug lord in Miami. This remake of the 1932 classic, based on an original script by Oliver Stone, expands upon that story by exploring the themes of immigration, greed, and guilty pleasures. Bolivian actress Penelope Cruz plays Tony's mistress in this modern noir film. With its vivid portrayal of the bloody violence and endless wealth, this film explores how Tony's ruthless pursuit of the American dream leads him down a path of greed and despair.

A sports drama centered on cross-country running, McFarland, USA is a formula film executed exceptionally well, thanks to the veteran director and the unbelievable true story that it's based on. While sports movies usually focus on well-known cities with affluent communities, this one focuses on a predominantly Latino high school from a small, economically challenged town. It is much more interesting and emotionally rewarding because of that fact.

The film is about a high school that is in danger of losing its football program due to funding. Tracy Yoach (who also wrote the film) plays James White, a new P.E. teacher who is introduced to the Hispanic culture of the town and decides to use this culture as part of an after-school program. Juan Pablo Paulino plays Thomas Valles, the fastest runner in the school who, despite his athletic ability, is reluctant to be a part of the new cross-country team.

White sees something in Valles and encourages him to not waste his God-given talent. Valles is slowed by family responsibilities that require him to prioritize his time, and White convinces him that running can be a way for him to escape the struggles he faces at home. The result is a fantastic story of how White and Valles rally the entire town to support the team, which goes on to have state-wide success and helps the school avoid shutting down.

Director Kevin Reynolds is a veteran filmmaker whose career seems to be based on sports movies, with credits including Risen, Sahara, and Glory. This is easily his best effort, mostly because it feels so authentic and homegrown. The screenplay is a little predictable, but still effective, and the story is positively inspirational. The real Thomas Valles, cross-country coach Jim White, and most of the other people portrayed in the film attended the screening I saw, and their presence made the experience even more rewarding.

McFarland, USA is a rare sports drama that really is based on the incredible accomplishments of a group of real people who overcame tremendous odds to achieve success. It's a film based on true equality, faith, and perseverance that deserves to be seen by a wide audience.

A funny, poignant, and ultimately uplifting story about a family's struggles, and how they cope with them. The movie is a little biased to the father and his wishes, but that's what makes it so interesting: it shows how each of the family members is affected by his obsession, and how they deal with it in their own ways. The ending is a bit predictable, but that's okay because the journey getting there is what matters.

The acting is top-notch, and the characters are well-developed and relatable. The script is also well-written, and the dialogue is often hilarious. The direction is also excellent, and the movie is well-paced and never boring.

A great movie for a family to watch together, or for anyone who enjoys a good comedy with a touch of drama. Highly recommended!

The Jersey is an American comedy television series, starring Courtney Cox Arquette, James Gandolfini, and Jeffrey Nordling, which debuted on November 29, 1999, on CBS. The show last aired on June 3, 2004.

Set in New York City, the show mixes surrealism and reality, using occasional fantasy sequences to explore the inner emotions of its characters. It is often associated with the mockumentary style, and is considered to be one of the first successful examples of this approach in an American television program.

The show's title refers to a customized yellow Jersey from the cycling race Tour de France that the main character, Tony Soprano, wears to remind himself of the goals in his life.

The show's protagonist and anti-hero is Tony Soprano (James Gandolfini), a businessman and Mafia boss who struggles to balance his family life with his role as the leader of a criminal organization, and tries to keep the different aspects of his life separate. He is frequently seen trying to keep his wife, Carmela (Courtney Cox Arquette), his daughter, Meadow (Jamie-Lynn Sigler), and his son, Anthony Jr. (Robert Iler), away from his criminal activities, but often fails. His mother, Livia (Nancy Marchand), is regularly seen at his house, causing problems between Tony and Carmela due to her overbearing presence. Tony has a history of infidelity, and has several affairs during the show's run. His best friend and loyal consigliere is Silvio Dante (Steven Van Zandt), and his closest confidant is his psychiatrist, Dr. Jennifer Melfi (Lorraine Bracco).

The show explores the difficulties of Tony's role as the leader of a criminal organization, and the impact it has on his family life. It also examines the relationships between members of the Soprano family, and the effects of their criminal activities on their relationships with each other. The show is famous for its dramatic scenes, dark humor, and its exploration of the human condition.

Phyllis Wallbank (3 September 1914  18 April 2020) was an English supercentenarian whose age has been validated by Guinness World Records. She was the oldest living person in England after the death of Alice Stevenson on 22 October 2019 until her own death on 18 April 2020.

Wallbank was born in 1914 in the Thurgoland area of Barnsley, South Yorkshire, England, to parents Walter (a tailor) and Annie (ne Goodchild). She had one older brother, Norman, who was born in 1912 and served in the Royal Air Force during the 1930s. Her family moved to the village of Elsecar, where she attended Elsecar Church School. She left school when she was 14 and started work at a factory that made parachutes. She also worked at the local pit and at the Rag Lane Colliery in Barnsley, where she operated one of the largest coal hauling trucks. She retired at the age of 70.

She married her husband, Albert, in 1937. He died in 1978. They had one child, a son named Keith, who was born in 1945. Keith died in 2015.

Wallbank became a supercentenarian in 2014, following her 109th birthday. On 13 April 2020, at the age of 105, she contracted COVID-19 during the pandemic. She died on 18 April 2020, at the age of 105.

Waterford began as a small collection of rural hamlets in the late Viking Age (c. 9141014 CE). Following the Norman invasion of Ireland in 116971, the island was divided into lordships and Waterford became the principal port of the south of Ireland. Following the enactment of the Statutes of Kilkenny in 1367, Waterford remained a lordship until it was incorporated as a royal city under Henry VIII in 1540. Following the Irish Rebellion of 1641, Ireland came under English rule and Waterford remained a city, though it was now regarded as only the "second city" of the island. Following the Acts of Union in 1800, Waterford became the second largest city, behind Dublin, in the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland.

Early in the 1170s, Norman nobles strengthened the natural defences of the river valley and built the first castle. The first charter was granted by King John in 1205. The fortified town developed as the main port of call for imports to Ireland from Europe. Wine, spices and textiles were traded for wool, hides and salmon. By the late 13th century, Waterford had become an important centre of trade with England and Continental Europe. The city was managed by a corporation of merchants who oversaw the port's development. Shipbuilding and exporting Irish wool to Europe began in the 14th century.

During the Reformation, Waterford remained a Catholic city. However, Bishop Richard Rawson was appointed as the Church of Ireland's bishop of Waterford by King Henry VIII. Rawson compliantly abandoned Catholicism and began the process of converting the city. In the resulting religious strife, Rawson was murdered in 1535. The Corporation of Merchants, who governed the city, defended Rawson's murder by claiming that he had been killed "for his evil and treacherous deeds".

In the Irish Rebellion of 1641, the city was seized by Confederate Catholics, however, it was regained by English Parliamentarian forces under the command of Oliver Cromwell in 1649. The city was later occupied by the French under the command of Lauzun in 1658. Following the Act of Settlement in 1662, Waterford and other Irish ports were declared closed to foreign vessels. However, this was repealed in 1669 and foreign trade resumed.

Following the Acts of Union in 1800, the city became part of the United Kingdom. It was granted a royal charter in 1802. In the 19th century, Waterford became the largest ship-building port in Ireland. The city's first newspaper, the Waterford Mail, began publication

Sisler High School is a high school in Winnipeg, Manitoba, Canada, and is a part of the River East Transcona School Division. Located at 91 Bufflaw Road in East Winnipeg, the school was named after former principal Elwood Leslie Sisler, and opened in 1973, serving students in the easternmost areas of Winnipeg. The school was designed by the firm of Ward & McDonald, and built by M.J. Electric at a cost of $2.3 million. The school opened with 850 students from East Kildonan, Transcona, and Elmwood.

In 1976, Sisler became affiliated with the University of Manitoba, offering university courses for its students. It is also affiliated with the University of Winnipeg.

In 1985, Sisler became the first high school in Manitoba to institute a mandatory laptop program, where every student was issued a laptop. The program was discontinued in 2009, due to issues with the laptops.

Sisler is known for its special education program, which accepts special needs students from across the city. The program accepts students at all grades, and helps them integrate into regular classes wherever possible.

The school offered the International Baccalaureate program, as well as a variety of clubs and activities, such as a chess club, a debate club, a drama club, a fitness club, a math club, a music club, a science club, and a soccer club.

In 2010, Sisler High School was designated as a UNESCO school, and is currently the only school in Manitoba to receive this designation. The school was selected because of its work on human rights and democracy, and its dedication to the United Nations Education, Scientific, and Cultural Organization (UNESCO).

In 2013, the school celebrated its 40th anniversary.

Hero envy is a structural bias that favors heroic personalities in individualist cultures, according to cultural anthropologist Joseph Campbell. It is a type of envy typically drawn towards those seen as better versions of oneself and is often attributed to comparisons of skill or ability among peers. Campbell claims that hero envy is the desire for the exciting, risky, and glamorous life of the hero, and that it is a major driver of human culture. Campbell's concept of hero envy is discussed in the psychological literature on envy, which cites it as an important concept for understanding the emotion.

Heroism tends to be culturally defined, and heroes may be real or mythical figures. Some heroes become celebrities. Not all heroes are saints, and some heroes may be considered villains. In fact, some villains are themselves envious of the heroes who defeat them, and derive some perverse satisfaction from being able to point out the hero's flaws and vulnerabilities. This distinguishes villainy from heroism, in that villains take a permissive attitude while heroes take a proactive one.

The term "hero" can also refer to superheroes, which are usually fictional characters that have superpowers and use them for good. These characters are often portrayed as being very brave and strong, and they often have a strong sense of justice and morality. It is not uncommon for people to envy superheroes, as they represent the ultimate in power and strength.

Envy is an emotion that can motivate people to improve themselves and achieve their goals. However, it can also lead to negative feelings and behaviors, such as resentment, jealousy, and spite. It is important to recognize and manage feelings of envy in order to live a happy and fulfilling life.

Colbie Caillat is an American singer and songwriter. She has sold over 6 million albums worldwide and has received numerous awards for her music. She has also received three Grammy Award nominations.

Caillat was born in Malibu, California, to Clair Afong, a singer, and Ken Caillat, a record producer. She has two older sisters, Coppelle and Coco, and a brother, Kenny. Caillat is partially of Chinese ancestry on her mother's side. She attended Malibu High School, where she met fellow musician Jason Mraz.

Caillat released her debut album, "Coco", in July 2007. The album included the hit single "Bubbly", which became a top-ten hit on the Billboard Hot 100 chart and was a top-five hit in the UK. In 2008, Caillat released her second album, " Breakthrough". This album included the hit single "Fallin' for You", which peaked at number one on the Billboard Hot 100 chart. " Breakthrough" has been certified platinum by the Recording Industry Association of America. In August 2009, Caillat released her third album, "All of You". In 2011, she released her fourth album, "Christmas in the Sand". In July 2015, she released her fifth album, "Southern Hemisphere".

In addition to her own music, Caillat has written songs for other artists, including Monica, Olivia Newton-John, and Julia Michaels. She has also appeared as a guest singer on albums by other artists, including Shawn Mendes' "Handwritten" and Andy Grammer's " Magazines or Novels".

Club de Berne is a colloquial term used to refer to a group of southern African countries that share a common currency and a common financial and monetary policy. The term was coined by the Swiss journalist Jean Ziegler in his book _La rupture du tabac_ in 1976, in which he suggested that Switzerland should follow the example of the "Club de Berne" and adopt a currency union with neighboring countries. Although the term is sometimes incorrectly referred to as the "Berne Club", it is not an organization and therefore has no membership, charter, leadership, or meetings.

The term "Club de Berne" refers to these nine countries which may be considered to be a currency bloc:

- Botswana
- Lesotho
- Namibia
- South Africa
- Swaziland
- Tanzania (1964-1966)
- Zambia (1964-1966)

These countries had been inserted into the CFA franc monetary system upon independence. They adopted the common currency in 1964 and were obliged to keep a fixed exchange rate with the French franc. The "Club de Berne" framework collapsed in 1966 when its members decided to adopt their own currencies.

Peter Griffin is the titular protagonist of the animated television series Family Guy. He is voiced by Seth MacFarlane and first appeared on television, along with the rest of the Griffin family, in the 15-minute short on December 20, 1998. MacFarlane would later pitch a show revolving around the family to Fox, culminating in the show's official pilot on October 6, 1999. The show was cancelled in 2002, but renewed in 2004 after Disney relinquished the rights to produce animated films based on Marvel Comics characters.

Peter Griffin is a less-than-intelligent overweight bald man who is extremely careless, unstable, naive, and a bit naive. He is also a bit hypocritical. However, he is extremely sympathetic and is a very loving husband and father. He does stupid things like smoking and drinking (and sometimes doing them while driving), but he always means well. Peter is also a devoted fan of the New England Patriots and is sometimes shown wearing a Tom Brady jersey.

He is the father of Chris, Stewie, and Brian, and is married to Lois. Peter's employer is the Pawtucket Brewery (later renamed Quahog Brewery), where he is a tour guide. In "Movin' Out", it is revealed that Peter is a member of the brewery's union. He is often shown drinking beer (he is, in fact, seen drinking beer while driving). Peter is generally depicted as being poor at his job (for example, in "The Kiss Seen Around the World" when he is fired for allowing the group of school children on his tour to drink beer), but he is very loyal to the brewery, having worked there since before the show's inception.

Nezak Huns refers to a people of north India who may have been a part of the Huna peoples who spoke the Tocharian languages. Alternative names for these peoples include Nisach, Nicha, Niaga, Etsatz, and Ezaks.

The Nezak Huns are known from the Kalasha inscriptions as well as by their mention in the Brahmi inscription of Kharagraha I (c. 380), where they are mentioned as enemies of the Gupta Empire. They are also mentioned in several other Indian sources.

The Nezak Huns are notable for having adopted the Indian martial art of Kalaripayattu, as well as for the Nezak king Mehama's victory over the Alchon Huns about 530 CE.

Andreas Maercker (born 18 December 1964) is a Swiss bobsledder who competed in the late 1980s and early 1990s. Competing in two Winter Olympics, he won the gold medal in the four-man event both in 1988 and 1992.

Maercker also won five medals at the FIBT World Championships with one gold (Two-man: 1991), two silvers (Four-man: 1989, 1991), and two bronzes (Two-man: 1987, Four-man: 1993).

Maercker retired after the 1994 season following the conclusion of a court case in which he was found guilty of doping violations. He was officially expelled from the Swiss Bobsleigh Federation in 1998.

The IOC reexamined samples from the 1988 Winter Olympics and found that Maercker had tested positive for anabolic steroids. Consequently, on 12 October 2007, he was disqualified from the 1988 Olympic four-man bobsleigh event and stripped of his gold medal.

Jo Armstead (born December 10, 1944 in Los Angeles, California) is an American soul singer and songwriter, who enjoyed considerable success in the 1960s and 1970s.

Armstead recorded for the Stax label and is best known for her 1967 hit single, "A Sweet Woman." She is the sister of singer and songwriter Eddie Floyd and the aunt of singer and songwriter Zuri Armstead.

Armstead suffered from polio as a child and recovered with assistance from Sister Rosetta Tharpe. She began her singing career in gospel music. After graduating high school, she joined a local gospel group, The Holy Wonders, for a short time. She then joined The Southern California Golden Angels, a well-known gospel group. It was while singing with them that she met and married singer and songwriter Jimmy Lewis in 1964. The couple moved to Detroit, Michigan, where Lewis took a job working for Ford Motor Company. Armstead stayed at home, raising their two children, and began writing songs. It was not long before she was signed to Stax Records.

In 1966, Armstead released her first single, "I Can't Stand Up Alone," written by her brother, Eddie Floyd, and Booker T. and the M.G.'s guitarist Steve Cropper. The song became a regional hit. She followed that up with "A Sweet Woman," which made it to the top 10 on the R&B charts and into the top 40 on the pop charts. In addition, Armstead's song "I'm Gonna Make You Love Me" was recorded by Wilson Pickett and became a Top 10 hit.

Armstead released a number of albums for Stax, including:

- Jo Armstead (1968)
- The Soul of Jo Armstead (1969)
- I Do Love You (1970)
- Jo Armstead's Greatest Hits (1971)

She also appeared on several albums with The Staple Singers, including:

- Soul Folk in Action (1966)
- The Staple Swingers (1967)
- Soul Party (1968)

Her marriage to Jimmy Lewis ended in divorce in 1969. She later married career FBI man, Donald Robinson. The couple moved to Washington, D.C., where she lived in semi-retirement, only performing occasionally. In the 1990s, she recorded a new album, but Stax went out of business before it could be released. The album was finally released in 2010.

Carole Quinton (6 October 1930  5 October 2021) was an English operatic soprano and opera director best known for her performances in the soprano roles of Wagner's operas, undertaken in the 1960s and early 1970s. She spent much of her career as the leading soprano at the Bayreuth Festival, performing under the direction of Pierre Boulez, Wieland Wagner, and Herbert von Karajan. She was regarded as "the greatest English soprano of her generation".

Quinton was born in Manchester, England in 1930. Her father was a doctor and her mother played the piano. She learned to play the piano as a child and studied music at the Royal Manchester College of Music. She appeared in concerts and recitals, and then became a member of the chorus of the Hall Orchestra. She also sang with the BBC Northern Orchestra and the BBC Symphony Orchestra. She made her solo debut in 1961 with the Oxford University Opera Club, as Lady Rich in Benjamin Britten's Gloriana. In the same year, she appeared at the Edinburgh Festival, as the Countess in The Marriage of Figaro.

Quinton became a member of the BBC Chorus and appeared on many of the corporation's broadcasts. She also sang at the Glyndebourne Festival and at the Holland Festival. She made her US debut in 1965, as Isolde in Wagner's Tristan und Isolde, with the Boston Symphony Orchestra, under the direction of Erich Leinsdorf. In the same year, she made her first appearance at the Bayreuth Festival, as Brnnhilde in Wagner's Gtterdmmerung. She went on to sing at Bayreuth for the next ten years, in roles including Isolde, Brnnhilde, and Kundry. Her other roles included Ortrud in Wagner's Lohengrin, the Old Countess in The Queen of Spades, and the Nurse in Boris Godunov.

In 1967, Quinton made her debut at the Royal Opera House, as the Old Countess. In the same year, she appeared at the Vienna Festival, as Kundry. She also sang at the Munich Festival, as the Nurse in Boris Godunov, and at the Maggio Musicale Fiorentino in Florence, as the Widow Begbick in Die Entfhrung aus dem Serail. In 1969, she made her debut at the Paris Opra, as Kundry, and at the New York Metropolitan Opera, as the Nurse in Boris Godunov.

Adele Girard (born February 16, 1975) is a French actress. She is best known for her roles as Helen Bohaker in the cult film The Red Sleeve, and as Camilla Montes in the French television series Les Petits Meurtres d'Agatha Christie.

Girard was born in Paris, and studied at the National Academy of Dramatic Arts in Paris. She has appeared in many stage productions, including plays by William Shakespeare, Arthur Miller, and Jean Genet. She has also worked in television and film, including the popular French series Sous le soleil and the film The Secret of the Grain.

In addition to her acting career, Girard is also a singer and has performed on stage and in concert. She has also written a children's book, titled La Bonne Etoile.

Girard won a Globe de Cristal Award for Best Female Newcomer for her role in The Red Sleeve in 2014.

"Girls on Boys" is the second single from American singer-songwriter Lana Del Rey's third studio album, Ultraviolence (2014). It was released on March 10, 2014 along with a music video. It was written by Lana Del Rey and Rick Nowels, and produced by the Black Keys' Dan Auerbach. Del Rey has said that the song was inspired by 1960s French pop and the work of Franoise Hardy.

The song's lyrics are a reflection on a summer romance between two teenagers. It has been described as "a coming-of-age rock song with haunting melodies and melancholy lyrics". Critical reception to the single was generally favorable, with many critics praising Del Rey's vocals and the song's production. 

"Girls on Boys" debuted at number 100 on the Billboard Hot 100, becoming her highest charting single at the time of release. It also debuted at number 39 on the Hot Rock Songs chart. The song has since become Del Rey's biggest hit in Ireland and New Zealand, peaking at number 16 in both countries. It was also a top 40 hit in Australia, Canada, and the United Kingdom. 

The music video for "Girls on Boys" was directed by Grant Singer and features a cameo appearance by actor Jaime King. It was released on March 10, 2014 and premiered on MTV's website immediately after. The video features Del Rey and her love interest spending a summer together in a national park. It was well received by critics, who noted the video's nostalgia and innocence. "Girls on Boys" has been performed by Del Rey on several occasions, including on The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon, The Late Show with Stephen Colbert, and at the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival. It was also included on the set list of her worldwide tour in support of Ultraviolence.

Critical reception
Critical reception to "Girls on Boys" was generally favorable. Time Out London described the single as "haunting" and "a coming-of-age rock song with haunting melodies and melancholy lyrics". The Boston Globe called it a "gorgeous, understated ballad", and The Guardian described it as "wistful" and "hypnotic". 

Spin magazine's Dan Weiss was less favorable, saying that the song "mostly serves to make [Del Rey] seem like a guest on her own record, as Auerbach's production gets in the way of her vocals". In a mixed review, The A.V. Club said that the single's "gentle

Akite Agnes (born 1934) is a female Ugandan activist for the rights of women, adolescents, and the poor. She is the founder of the non-governmental organization Forum for Women Educational and Legal Aid (FWELA), and has worked as its executive director since 1986. In 2010, she won the inaugural MTV Woman of the Year award.

Agnes was born in 1934 in Kaberamaido District, Uganda. She attended Makerere University, where she obtained a bachelor's degree in education. She later obtained a master's degree in philosophy from the University of Oxford in the United Kingdom. After graduating from Makerere University in the 1950s, she taught school for 16 years. She also served as a school inspector and as an adviser to the Ugandan Ministry of Education. She married engineer Henry Kalulu, and they had six children.

In 1986, Agnes founded FWELA. The organization's goals are to promote the rights of women, adolescents, and the poor, as well as to provide them with legal and educational aid. FWELA has since become one of the leading women's rights organizations in Uganda. Agnes has been the organization's executive director since its founding.

In 2010, Agnes won the inaugural MTV Woman of the Year award. She was recognized for her work in promoting the rights of women and adolescents in Uganda. She has also received the Uganda Presidential Medal for her work in education and the fight against AIDS.

"Wrangler" and "Cowboy" are terms used by the U.S. military in Hawaii to describe their insecticides and ACBs (insect growth regulators) against the caterpillars of the invasive alien moth, the brown tree snake, and the mosquito. "Wrangler" is also the term used by Arcata and Eureka, California for their integrated pest management (IPM) programs for the same insect. "Cowboy" is the term used by many other urban areas for their insecticides applied against the moth.

The term "moth wrangler" has been used to describe those involved with controlling the brown tree snake in Hawaii. It is also used by those who produce and spread the pheromone of the male brown tree snake as a means of population control. This is a widely used technique because the female brown tree snake only mates once, and if no male pheromone is detected, she will not mate. Male brown tree snakes are harmless to people; they are captured, chilled, and sent to a laboratory where their skins are removed and the pheromone is extracted. The pheromone is then put into "snake balls" which are spread around urban areas, attracting male snakes which then collide with the ball and die. The purpose of the balls is to reduce the population by making the males infertile.

The only major species of moth which is a pest in Hawaii is the brown tree snake. It was introduced into the islands around 1965, and rapidly became a major pest, killing almost all birds in the forests and urban areas. It is a major reason that Hawaii has no endemic birds, and many species of birds have been introduced to control the snake. The snake has also been seen on the U.S. mainland."

Elias Gyftopoulos (Greek:  oulos, April 29, 1941  July 16, 2001) was a Greek American academic, writer and critic. 

Gyftopoulos was best known for his work in the field of cultural theory and history, and his books and essays explored the relationship between culture, politics and identity. He was a professor of history at the University of California, Berkeley, and served as director of the Graduate Program in History there from 1989 to 1996. He was also a founding member of the interdisciplinary Program in Cultural Studies at Berkeley, and served as its director from 1997 to 1999. 

Gyftopoulos was born in Athens, Greece, and moved to the United States in 1963. He received his PhD in history from the University of California, Los Angeles in 1972. He was a member of the Greek Historical Society and the American Historical Association. He died in Athens on July 16, 2001, of a heart attack. He was 60 years old. 

Gyftopoulos's work focused on modern Greek history, and he was an expert on the history of Greece during the 19th and 20th centuries. He wrote several books on the subject, including "Modern Greece: Politics, Economics and Society" and "The Emergence of Modern Greece: From the War of Independence to the Reign of King Otto". He also wrote several books on the history of the United States, including "The Life and Times of Frederick Douglass" and "The History of the United States: From the Colonial Period to the Present". 

Gyftopoulos was a strong advocate for the study of history and the importance of understanding the past. He believed that history was a tool for understanding the present and shaping the future, and he encouraged his students to think critically about the past and to use history as a way to make sense of the world around them. 

Overall, Elias Gyftopoulos was a highly respected and influential historian and scholar who made significant contributions to the field of history and cultural studies.

John Rucho (born July 17, 1948) is an American politician who served as a North Carolina state senator from the 45th District from 1989 to 2016. Rucho was born in Raleigh, North Carolina. He is a 1966 graduate of Needham B. Broughton High School in Raleigh and a 1970 graduate of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. Rucho later became a businessman and developer. He was first elected to the state senate in 1988. He represented North Carolina's 45th Senate district, which includes portions of Wake and Harnett counties. Rucho served as the co-chair of the Senate Commerce Committee and as a member of the Senate Finance Committee. He also served as the Senate Majority Whip. Rucho did not seek re-election in the 2016 Senate District 45 primary.

During his tenure in the state senate, Rucho authored 498 bills that were signed into law. He led the effort to reduce taxes in North Carolina every year starting in 2013. He also authored legislation that made it easier for businesses to operate in North Carolina. In 2015, Rucho sponsored Senate Bill 809, known as Anna's Law, allowing emergency vehicles to proceed through red lights when responding to emergencies Ideal & Company, a beverage company, hired Rucho in 2019 as its vice president of government relations. Ideal & Company produces, bottles, and distributes about 450 million bottles of water annually. The company also manufactures bottles for the beverage industry. Rucho is a member of the Board of Directors of the North Carolina Business Council and the North Carolina Free Enterprise Foundation.
