He is a former member of the Board of Directors of the North Carolina Chamber of Commerce.

Sammarinese Armed Forces

The Sanmarinese Armed Forces (Italian: Forze Armate Sammarinesi) are the military forces of the Republic of San Marino. They consist of a modest contingent of troops, with strictly limited objectives and tasks. Despite this, the military traditions of the Sammarinese people can be traced back to the Middle Ages, being reinforced during the Republic's military engagements in the Italian mainland during the Renaissance.

Since the Middle Ages, the primary objective of the Sammarinese military has been the preservation of the independence and freedom of the Republic of San Marino. This has traditionally been achieved through a combination of diplomatic immunity and military defense. The military has also played a key role in the protection of the Republic's borders and the maintenance of public order.

Today, the Sammarinese Armed Forces consist of a small volunteer army and a ceremonial guard. These forces are tasked with continuing the traditional defensive and security roles of the military, as well as participating in humanitarian and peacekeeping operations.

The army is composed of a headquarters unit, three infantry companies, a logistical unit and a pedagogical unit. The army is equipped with light weapons and mortars. William Cunningham Dalyell (25 August 1867  18 October 1947) was a Scottish zoologist and paleontologist.

Dalyell was born in Edinburgh, Scotland. His father, Robert Boyle Dalyell (18361900), was a barrister and amateur zoologist, and his mother, Mary Susan Playfair, was the daughter of Professor William Playfair. His grandfather, Charles Alexander Campbell, was a director of the Bank of Scotland. On his mother's side, he was descended from the professor William Playfair, inventor of the line, bar, and pie charts.

Dalyell studied at Eton College, Trinity College, Cambridge (where he was a member of Cambridge University Footlights), and the Natural History Museum. He worked as a civil servant in the Patent Office and Office of Works from 1892 to 1912, and served as a Justice of the Peace and a Deputy Lieutenant of Wiltshire. He began to study zoology in 1901, and became a Fellow of the Zoological Society of London in 1903, and a Fellow of the Geological Society in 1909. He served as the President of the Geologists' Association from 1924 to 1926. In 1912 he left the civil service in order to focus on his research, and was elected a Fellow of the Royal Society in 1914. He served as the Society's Vice-President from 1935 to 1937, and as the President of the Zoological Society of London from 1937 to 1938. He was also a member of the American Philosophical Society.

Dalyell married Dorothy Constance Filmer in 1899, and they had two daughters, the elder of whom, Helen Dorothy Georgina Dalyell (19031990), married the historian H. Stuart Hughes.

Dalyell died in Oxford, England in 1947.

His nephew was the actor Gregor Fisher.

Michael "Mike" J. Quigley (/kwae/; born April 16, 1958) is an American politician and retired naval officer who has served as the United States representative for Illinois's 5th congressional district since 2009. A member of the Democratic Party, he served in the Illinois General Assembly from 1993 to 2009, rising to the rank of Minority Leader.

Quigley was born in Chicago and raised in the city's Bucktown neighborhood. He served in the United States Navy from 1976 to 1989 and retired as a lieutenant. He received a bachelor's degree in economics from the University of Chicago in 1983 and a master's degree in social service administration from the University of Chicago's School of Social Service Administration in 1989. After retiring from the Navy, Quigley worked as a director for the Illinois Department of Children and Family Services and as a community organizer for the Northwest Community Organization.

In 1992, Quigley was elected to the Illinois General Assembly, representing a district on Chicago's North Side. He served as the Democratic spokesperson for the Revenue Committee and as the chairman of the Veterans' Affairs Committee. In 2004, he was elected as the state's minority leader. He served in the General Assembly until he was elected to the United States House of Representatives in 2008.

Quigley represented Illinois's 5th congressional district in the United States House of Representatives from 2009 to 2013 and has served as the representative for Illinois's 4th congressional district since 2013. He is a member of the Democratic Party and has served as the co-chair of the Democratic National Committee's Veterans and Military Families Council since 2011.

"Bother" is the second single from the English band Hot Chip's debut album, Coming on Strong. It was released in March 2004 and peaked at number 67 on the UK Singles Chart. The song describes the discomfort of a boy around a girl he likes. It also appears on the album Haus der Kultur on the Southern Fried Records label. A music video was made for the single. In 2009 it was used in a television advertisement for the HTC Legend mobile phone.

"Bother" was originally released as a white label record in October 2003, six months before the release of Coming on Strong. This original version featured a synthesized string arrangement, and was produced by Hot Chip. Upon the release of Coming on Strong in January 2004, the band remade the song without the string arrangement, and released it as a single in March 2004. This version was also produced by the band. An extended play was released to promote the single, featuring five tracks: the original version of "Bother", the album version of "Bother", a live version of "Andromeda", and two new B-sides: "Alpha Beta" and "Pebble Beach". A 12" record was also released, featuring the album version of "Bother" and the original version of the song. Both releases were by Rough Trade Records, the band's record label. A CD was released in 2009 by EMI Records, featuring the original version of the song.

The song was well received by music critics. It was named one of the best tracks of 2004 by newspaper Philadelphia Inquirer, and in 2011, a Spin article named the song the 84th best of the 2000s.

The music video for "Bother" was directed by John Hillcoat, who later directed films such as The Road and Lawless. It features two people, a man and a woman, who are constantly moving in a large warehouse. The man is trying to impress the woman, but every time he approaches her, she moves away. They are both dressed in brightly coloured clothing. The man's clothes are orange and yellow, and the woman's are blue and pink. The man's hair is short and the woman's hair is long. The man is played by Edmund Constantin, and the woman is played by Samantha Evans.

Rodrigo Vlazquez (c. 1150  1204) was the feudal lord of Sobrosa in the Kingdom of Len and one of the most prominent Leonese knights and generals of the twelfth century. He is best known for his military exploits in the Reconquista, particularly his conquest of Cuenca in 1177 and his pivotal role in the Battle of Badajoz in 1184.

Born into a noble family, Vlazquez was educated at the court of Ferdinand II of Len in the city of Len. He was married to Maria Raimundes, daughter of Raimundes Menndez, with whom he had three children.

In 1177, Vlazquez led a small army in the conquest of Cuenca from the Moors. This victory brought him great fame and recognition, and he was rewarded with the title of "Liberator of Cuenca".

Two years later, in 1184, Vlazquez played a key role in the Battle of Badajoz, which resulted in the recapture of the city of Badajoz from the Moors. He led the left wing of the Leonese army and was responsible for the defeat of the Moorish general Al-Mutawakkil.

Following the battle, Vlazquez was rewarded with the title of "Conqueror of Badajoz". He was also granted the lands of the conquered city and the right to establish a feudal lordship there.

Over the next few years, Vlazquez focused on expanding his feudal holdings and strengthening his position in the Kingdom of Len. He received several more titles and honors from the king, including the title of "Count of Sobrosa" and the right to use the royal crest.

Vlazquez died in 1204 and was buried in the monastery of Sobrosa. His son, Rodrigo lvarez, succeeded him as feudal lord of Sobrosa and continued to expand the family's holdings in the kingdom.

Guy Washington Pentreath (23 October 1914  5 November 1987) was a British pilot and airline executive.

Pentreath was born in Kolkata, British India in 1914. After attending Haberdashers' Aske's Boys' School, he went to work for Shell Oil, where he trained as a pilot. He moved to Britain in 1938 and joined British Airways as a pilot, flying Hawker Hurricanes and other aircraft during World War II. He became captain of the British Airways fleet of Avro Yorks in 1947 and was subsequently promoted to captain of the Boeing 377 Stratocruiser fleet in 1949. He became general manager of British Airways in 1955 and served in that capacity until his retirement in 1971. He was also a member of the board of directors of Airport Authority of India in the 1960s and chairman of the British Aviation Insurance Group in the 1970s.

Pentreath died in Worthing, West Sussex, England in 1987.

The Kitayatsu Site is an archaeological site in Japan, located in Hakui City, Ishikawa Prefecture. The site is the remains of a large-scale settlement from the early Jmon period (40002500 BCE). It is the largest early Jmon period settlement ever found in Japan. The site was discovered in 2003 when the owner of the land, who had been farming the area for many years, found some archaeological artifacts while working in the fields. The site was excavated by the prefectural board of education in 2004 and 2005.

The remains of more than 250 pit dwellings and other features, including a possible burial ground and several large storage pits, were found at the site. The storage pits were found to contain a variety of artifacts, including Jmon pottery, stone tools, and bone tools. Many of the artifacts were found to be charred, suggesting that the settlement was destroyed by fire. A large number of artifacts, including many that were charred, were also found outside the settlement, suggesting that the fire was widespread and destroyed much of the settlement and its contents.

The site is significant because it provides a rare example of a large-scale settlement from the early Jmon period. Most other settlements from this period are small, temporary camps that were used for a short period of time and then abandoned. The Kitayatsu Site is also significant because it appears to have been destroyed by fire, which provides a rare opportunity to study the effects of fire on a Jmon period settlement. The site is currently being preserved and managed as a historic site by the Hakui City Board of Education.

BrazilUnited Kingdom relations are the international relations between the Kingdom of Brazil and the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland. Both countries are members of the United Nations, the World Trade Organization, the G20 and the Commonwealth of Nations. Both countries have embassies in the other country.

The United Kingdom and Brazil have a long history of diplomatic relations. In 1824, the United Kingdom was the first country to recognize the independence of Brazil. In 1932, the two countries signed a trade agreement. In the 20th century, both countries were part of the Western Bloc and strongly opposed to communism.

The United Kingdom and Brazil have close economic ties. The United Kingdom is one of the largest investors in Brazil, with a total investment of 24 billion in 2011. This makes the United Kingdom the second largest foreign investor in Brazil, after the United States. The two countries also have a strong trade relationship, with the United Kingdom being one of the largest exporters to Brazil.

The United Kingdom and Brazil have also worked closely together on international issues. Both countries are members of the UN Security Council and have worked together on issues such as the war in Iraq and the conflict in Syria.

Turks in the United Kingdom and British people in Turkey are people with Turkish or British nationality living in Turkey and the United Kingdom respectively.

British people in Turkey form one of the largest European populations in Turkey. There are estimated to be around 5,000 British citizens in Turkey. Most are retired people who have moved to Turkey to live out their retirement. There is also a large number of British people who own holiday homes in Turkey, particularly in the Aegean region and Istanbul. Due to its mild Mediterranean climate and laid-back lifestyle, many Britons have also chosen to relocate to Turkey's Aegean coast, particularly to the towns of Fethiye, ldeniz, and Hisarn, which has in turn created a large community of British people in those towns. Turks in the UK are a significant modern minority in the country, with Turkey being among the top countries of birth for the UK.

Starting in the 1960s, Turkey made a significant effort to hire Turkish professionals in the UK. Initially, these were university graduates who arrived in the UK for educational purposes, particularly in the fields of medicine, engineering, and architecture. Many of these early immigrants settled in the UK and started families. More recently, significant numbers of Turkish people have come to the UK as refugees, seeking asylum from the KurdishTurkish conflict, or for economic reasons. According to the 2001 UK census, 71,603 Turkish nationals were living in the UK at the time, making them the largest Muslim ethnic group in the country. However, the Office for National Statistics estimated that the number of Turkish nationals living in the UK in 2013 was 178,000, making them the fifth-largest foreign born population in the country. This figure has been increasing rapidly since the 1990s, partly due to the accession of Turkey to the European Union, an event which has led to a streamlining of the application process for Work and Residence Permits for Turkish people wishing to migrate to the UK. Turks are more concentrated in England than in the other countries of the UK. According to the 2011 census, 138,371 Turks live in England and 21,056 in Scotland, while Wales and Northern Ireland have smaller Turkish communities. Turks form the largest Muslim ethnic group in England and Scotland.

Wanalancet (c. 1619  c. 1684) was a sachem of themegantic Indians of New England, and later, a convert to Christianity. He became known as John Wakely.

Wanalancet was the son of Pyccut, chief of the709ics, or Penacooks, who ruled the area around the Merrimack River in what is now New Hampshire. In 1642, Pyccut made a treaty with the Massachusetts Bay Colony, allying himself with the English against the Iroquois, who were attempting to expand into New England.

In 1646, Wanalancet and his brother Cockenoe were captured by the Iroquois, who attempted to make them switch their allegiance. Cockenoe refused and was executed; Wanalancet pretended to agree, but raised a native army that defeated the Iroquois and forced them to retreat.

When King Philip's War broke out in 1675, Wanalancet initially remained neutral, but after a Christian native, John Sassamon, was murdered, he joined the fight against the English. When English captain John Hoar asked him why he was fighting, Wanalancet replied, "My Indians say, they have been hunting and getting their living quietly; if they be disturbed, they must defend themselves."

In 1676, Hoar convinced Wanalancet to attend a peace conference in Plymouth, but he arrived late, and when he heard that the Christian Indians were to be given two months to leave their homeland, he flew into a rage, yelling that the English had tricked him. The conference ended without a peace agreement.

Wanalancet died in 1684.

Jibril Yakubu (born 25 May 1997) is a Nigerian footballer who plays as a forward for Kuwaiti Division One club Tadamon.

He started his career with Nigerian side Kaduna United before moving to Lebanese Premier League club Akhaa Ahli Aley in 2018. In 2022, he joined Lebanese Premier League club Salam Zgharta. In January 2023, he signed for Tadamon in Kuwait.

Yakubu was called up for the Nigeria national under-20 football team for the 2015 FIFA U-20 World Cup. He scored one goal in the tournament before the team was knocked out in the quarter-final.

He was called up to the senior Nigeria national football team in March 2015 for a 2017 Africa Cup of Nations qualification match against Egypt. He came on as a substitute in the match, which Nigeria lost 3 nailed by Egypt.

The Elisha Bushnell House is a historic house museum in Stratford, Connecticut. The house was built in 1791 by George Washington's half-brother, Samuel. It is a prime example of Federal architecture and is most notable for its interior woodwork, especially the fireplace mantels and the carved staircase. 

In 1973, the house was restored to the 18201830 time period and opened to the public. The house was the first of Stratford's "must see" attractions for a summer tourism campaign in 1974. 

The Stratford Historical Society operates the house as a historic house museum. It is open weekly from mid-April through November.

Matthew "Matt" O'Dwyer (born 18 November 1984) is an Australian former representative rower and current national selector. He was a national champion and a world champion rower.

O'Dwyer was born in Melbourne. He attended St. Kevin's College, Melbourne where he completed his secondary education. He took up rowing as a cox at his school and moved into rowing from 2004 when he was nineteen years old. His senior club rowing has been from the Melbourne University Boat Club.

O'Dwyer's first state representation was in 2005 in a Victorian youth eight which contested the Noel Wilkinson Trophy in the Interstate Regatta within the Australian Rowing Championships. In 2006 he was selected in Victoria's youth four which won the national youth eight title. Then in 2007 he was again selected in a Victoria youth eight which won the national youth eight title. In 2008 he moved into the Victorian men's senior eight which contested and won the King's Cup at the Australian Championships. In 2009 he was in the stern of the Victorian eight which won the Kings Cup.

O'Dwyer first represented Australia in 2005 when he was selected to cox the youth eight which contested the World Rowing U23 Championships in Brandenburg. The boat finished in fifth place. In 2006 he was again selected as cox of the Australian youth eight for the U23 Championships in Amsterdam and that boat won the gold medal. In 2007 he was selected as cox of Australia's U23 coxed four for the World Championships in Glasgow. They won their heat and placed fifth in the final. In 2009 O'Dwyer was selected as cox of the Australian men's senior eight which contested the World Championships in Poznan. That boat won the silver medal.

O'Dwyer retired from competitive rowing in 2010. Later that year he was awarded the Melbourne University Blue. In 2011 he was co-coach of the Melbourne University Boat Club's women's squad. Then from 2016 to 2018 he was the director of coaching at Melbourne University. In 2018 he was also a selector for Rowing Australia's national team.

Highlands is a city in Harris County, Texas. It is part of the Houston-The Woodlands-Sugar Land metropolitan statistical area. The population was 7,931 at the 2010 census.RJ Stadium, home of the Highlanders, the lacrosse and football teams of Highland Village Elementary School, is in Highlands.

Highlands is located in Area Council District #4 and is served by Senator Paul Bettencourt, as well as by Representative Gene Wu.

Olivia Manning ne  Liathin (27 February 1908  20 July 1980) was an English writer of Irish Catholic descent, best known for her novel sequence The Balkan Trilogy and The Levant Trilogy.

She was born in Naini Tal, India, to an Irish father, Col. Charles Edward Manning, who was often away, serving in the British Army, and her mother, Mary Manning (ne Atkins), usually known as "Thea", whose intelligence and charm dominated the household. The Manning family moved to England when Olivia was a year old. They lived in metropolitan London and Manning attended schools in Harrow and Acton, but contracted polio at age nine, and attended school irregularly thereafter, relying on private tutors. She traveled with her family throughout England and Europe, particularly the Irish Republic, where she visited her uncle, the critic and poet Maurice Moilin, and her aunt, the writer Eileen Moirin (who wrote as Oliver Shee). About her childhood, Manning said that she thought it rather abnormal and "rather lonely".

In 1927, she married Ralphifer "Rafe" Good, a journalist for the Daily Mail. Manning worked as a fashion writerbriefly for the same newspaper and also as a book reviewer. Their only child, a son they named Oliver, was born in 1935. The marriage ended in 1941, when Good serve in World War II. 

During the war, Manning worked for the British Ministry of Information in Macedonia and afterwards in Egypt briefing pilots of the Royal Air Force on the Balkans. Her novel sequence The Balkan Trilogy and The Levant Trilogy are drawn from her experiences. The sequence was awarded the James Tait Black Memorial Prize for fiction in 1950. She also wrote several acclaimed stand-alone novels. She was a fellow of the Royal Society of Literature and a founding member of the Society of Authors.

Head-on engagement refers to the situation in which two aircraft, often aircraft of similar characteristics, are flying towards each other in opposite directions, intending to collide. The situation usually occurs in air-to-air combat, and the aircraft involved may be armed with air-to-air missiles or guns.

A head-on engagement can be a dangerous and unpredictable situation for both pilots. In the vast majority of cases, both aircraft will pass each other without incident, but in some cases, a collision may occur. This can be the result of a misjudgment of distance or speed, a malfunction of one of the aircraft's systems, or a deliberate action on the part of one of the pilots.

In the context of air-to-air combat, a head-on engagement can be a strategic move on the part of one of the pilots, as it can allow them to take advantage of their opponent's blind spot and fire on them without being seen. However, it can also be a risky move, as it can leave the pilot vulnerable to attack from behind. It's important for pilots to be aware of the risks and take appropriate measures to avoid a collision during a head-on engagement.

Darrick E. Antell (born August 26, 1964) is an American actor and model. He is best known for his role as the first Adam Carrington on the CBS soap opera Dynasty from 1981 to 1989.

Darrick Earl Antell was born in Santa Barbara, California, the son of Sharon and Earl Antell, a psychologist. His parents divorced when he was five years old. He and his mother then moved to San Francisco, where he attended Lick-Wilmerding High School. He began modeling at the age of eight for the Ford Agency. As a teenager, he appeared in a number of national commercials, including one for Pepsi, and had a small part in the film Star Trek: The Motion Picture playing a Klingon officer.

After appearing in Dynasty, Antell continued to work in television, film, and theater. He appeared in the films Weekend Warriors (1986) and Where the Day Takes You (1992), and had a guest role on the TV series Murder, She Wrote. His most recent screen credit was for the film The Perfect Wedding (2005).

Antell was married to actress Carole Ita White from 1991 to 1997. He married Kelly McCarthy in 1999. They have two children.

Jacques Boyceau (c. 1525  1565) was a French architect and designer of embroidery patterns, known for his work on the Palace of Fontainebleau. He was the father of the French painter and architect Jacques Boyceau de la Barauderie.

Little is known about Boyceau's early life. He is first mentioned in records as paying taxes in Paris in 1544, and is later mentioned as working on the Palace of Fontainebleau in 1552. He is known to have been a protg of the French king Henry II, and was favored by him. Boyceau designed many of the decorations in the Palace of Fontainebleau, including the famous horseshoe-shaped staircase. He also designed the embroidery patterns for the tapestries in the palace, which were made by the Flemish weaver Pieter Coecke.

Boyceau died in Paris in 1565. After his death, his son Jacques Boyceau de la Barauderie took over his work at the Palace of Fontainebleau, and completed many of his designs.

The Indigo King is a 2012 fantasy novel written by Susan Dennard. It is the third and final novel in the Something Strange and Deadly trilogy, succeeding the novels A Darkness Strange and Lovely and A Perilous Journey's End.

After returning from her trip to Paris in A Perilous Journey's End, Eleanor Fitt is happy to settle back into her routine now that the Spirit Court is at peace with the necromancers. However, that peace is short-lived as Eleanor is forced to flee Philadelphia in order to keep herself and her friends safe. While struggling to master her newfound powers as a Spirit Medium, Eleanor is also trying to come to terms with the feelings she has for the Spirit Hunter, Daniel.

When the Spirit Court learns of a powerful necromancer who has gained control of the Spirit World, Eleanor is the only one who can stop him. Now, with the help of her friends and her dangerous power, Eleanor must find a way to defeat the necromancer before it's too late.

The Indigo King received generally positive reviews from critics. Many praised the way the author was able to conclude the series while still leaving the door open for more stories set in the world she created.

Gifford Pinchot III (November 20, 1915  August 4, 2008) was an American conservationist, forester, and politician. He was born in New York City, the grandson of James Pinchot and the son of Amos Parker Pinchot, both of whom were influential in the conservation movement in the United States. After graduating from Yale University in 1937, he worked for the U.S. Forest Service and later became the director of the Yale University Forest School. He served as the chairman of the National Advisory Council on Environmental Quality from 1970 to 1972 and as the vice president of the Conservation Foundation from 1973 to 1979. He was also a member of the National Audubon Society's Board of Directors for nine years.

Pinchot was a member of the Republican Party and served as the lieutenant governor of Pennsylvania from 1963 to 1968 under Governor William Scranton. He ran for the United States Senate in 1968, but lost to the incumbent, Joseph S. Clark Jr. In 1971, he ran for the Republican nomination for governor, but lost to Milton J. Shapp, who went on to win the general election.

Pinchot was married to Ruth Pickering from 1938 until her death in 1994. They had four children. He died on August 4, 2008, at his home in Lansdowne, Pennsylvania.

Pinchot's grandfather, James Pinchot, was the father of conservation in the United States, and his father, Amos Pinchot, was an early advocate for the conservation of forests and was one of the founders of the Yale School of Forestry. Gifford Pinchot III was named after his uncle, Gifford Pinchot II, who was an Olympic champion in sailing and a forester like his brother, Amos.

Suryakanta Vyas (Bengali:  ) (c. 1933  14 September 2013) was a Bengali poet and writer. He was born in Bhuanpur village of Murshidabad district. His poems were first published in the Bengal Youth Festival in 1953. His first poem was "Amar Shawrish Maa". He was awarded an honorary D.Litt. by the University of Calcutta in 2011.

 Vyas was born into a family of Bengali Brahmins. His father was Ramkanta Vyas and his mother was named Radhika. He had five brothers and three sisters. Vyas suffered from polio in his leg from childhood and used a walking stick throughout his life. His left leg was 1.5 inches shorter than the right.

In 1954, Vyas's poem "Amar Shawrish Ma" was published in the annual magazine of the University of Calcutta. The poem was praised by the Bengali writers and poets of the time, including Shakti Chatterjee and Subhash Mukhopadhyay. This encouraged Vyas to write more poetry.

 Vyas's first poetry collection, "Suryakanta Vyas er Paksa", was published in 1958. The collection was well received by readers and critics. His second poetry collection, "Jeevan Darshan", was published in 1961. The collection was based on his experiences during a trip to Delhi. His most famous poem, "Haimanti", was published in 1973. The poem is about a woman who waits for her lover to return from war. The poem was inspired by a newspaper article about a woman who waited for her lover for many years. The poem was awarded the Bankim Puraskar in 1974.

In 1981, Vyas's poetry collection "Shyamali" was published. The collection was based on his experiences during a trip to Kashmir. His final poetry collection, "Akaalbodhan", was published in 1986. The collection was based on the concept of time.

Aside from poetry, Vyas also wrote novels, short stories, and essays. His most famous novel, "Bakul Katha", was published in 1957. Karma Automotive, LLC is an American automotive company founded in 2014 by Johan de Nysschen, previously a CEO of Cadillac. The company is headquartered in Irvine, California, and is a subsidiary of China's Wanxiang Group.

The company debuted its first car, the Karma Revero, in 2016. The Revero is an electric hybrid sedan that uses a dual electric motor drive system powered by a lithium-ion battery pack. It is ranked by the EPA as a midsize sedan, and it achieves 40 miles per gallon-equivalent (MPGe) city and 52 MPGe highway. A 33.4-kilowatt-hour (kWh) battery gives it a total electric driving range of 51 miles (82 km). The Revero was sold as the Karma Revero GT in 2021.

On May 19, 2020, Karma Automotive and Italian design/engineering company Pininfarina announced that they had entered into a joint venture to develop an electric hypercar that will be produced in very limited numbers. The yet-to-be-named EV is scheduled for delivery in 2022.

On October 26, 2020, Karma Automotive and Alibaba Group Holding Limited's internet financing platform, Tiancai Bureau announced that they will launch a comprehensive partnership to provide financial leasing services for Karma's automotive ecosystem. The partnership aims to support the "green travel, green energy and green technology" initiatives.

In January 2021, Karma Automotive launched its "Experience Excellence" program, promising that the company would work to fulfill orders for its vehicles in a timely manner and offer "an exceptional ownership experience." The company also announced that it is developing a "Global Retail Strategy" to expand its retail outlets beyond its current locations in California, Florida, Ontario, and Quebec.

In March 2021, Karma Automotive and Panthera Solutions Inc. announced that they had entered into a partnership to develop and deploy "new technologies and solutions" for electric vehicles. The partnership is intended to focus on "innovative" battery technology, powertrain systems, and "next-generation" vehicle architectures.

On March 31, 2021, Karma Automotive filed a registration statement on Form S-1 with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission relating to the proposed initial public offering of its ordinary shares. The number of shares to be offered and the price range for the proposed offering have not yet been determined.

Dean Cornwell (May 6, 1892  June 8, 1960) was an American artist best known for his painting, illustration, and mural work. He is recognized as one of the finest American muralists of the 20th century and as a major contributor to the art of illustration. His work is in the collections of many major museums, including the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Museum of Modern Art, the Library of Congress, and the Whitney Museum of American Art.

Cornwell was born in Lincoln, Nebraska, the eldest of four children. He studied art at the Chicago Art Institute and the Academy of Fine Arts in Chicago. In 1913 he began a career in illustration, working for such publications as Harper's Weekly, Ladies' Home Journal, and The Saturday Evening Post. His illustrations appeared in many books, including Mark Twain's A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur's Court (1923) and The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn (1924).

In 1924 Cornwell moved to New York City to work as a freelance artist. He began to receive commissions for murals, and his work came to the attention of the Public Works of Art Project, a New Deal agency that employed artists to create murals and other works of art for public buildings. He was hired to paint murals for the Hall of States at the 1939 New York World's Fair.

Cornwell's work is characterized by its bold use of color and form, and its blend of traditional and modern styles. His murals often feature large-scale figures and dramatic compositions, and his illustrations are known for their careful attention to detail and their ability to convey emotion and narrative. He was a master of various media, including oil painting, watercolor, and charcoal.

Lawrence Eagleburger (November 29, 1930  October 5, 2011) was an American diplomat and businessman. He was the 53rd secretary of state of the United States, serving from 1992 to 1993.

Eagleburger was born in Indianapolis, Indiana, and grew up in swelling hometown of Columbus, Indiana. His father, Lawrence Eagleburger Sr., was a machinist for the Baltimore & Ohio Railroad and later a captain in the Army Corps of Engineers before becoming a successful businessman and entrepreneur. His mother, the former Hazel Cox, was a housewife. Eagleburger graduated from Columbus High School in 1948 and then attended Yale University, where he was a member of Skull and Bones and graduated with a bachelor's degree in 1952. He then joined the U.S. Army Security Agency as a civilian employee and worked as a intelligence analyst in West Germany from 1953 to 1956. After returning to the United States, he entered Columbia Law School, where he earned a Juris Doctor degree in 1959.

Eagleburger began his career as an associate at the law firm of Simpson Thacher & Bartlett in New York City. He specialized in corporate law and worked on a variety of transactions, including the merger of Pan American Airways and National Airlines in 1965. In 1969, he left the firm to join the presidential campaign of Richard Nixon. After the campaign, he joined the U.S. Department of State as a political appointee and served as a liaison between the department and the White House. In 1971, he was appointed as the U.S. ambassador to Yugoslavia. He served in this position until 1974 and was credited with helping to improve relations between the United States and the Soviet Union. In 1974, he returned to the private sector and joined the investment bank of Shearson Lehman Brothers. He worked as a senior adviser and director of the firm until 1979.

In 1979, Eagleburger returned to the public sector to serve as the U.S. deputy secretary of state under President Jimmy Carter. He served in this position until 1981 and played a key role in the negotiation of the SALT II nuclear arms limitation treaty with the Soviet Union. In 1981, he again returned to the private sector and joined the consulting firm ofKissinger Associates, Inc., led by former U.S. Secretary of State Henry Kissinger. He worked as a senior adviser and director of the firm until 1992. In 1992, Eagleburger was nominated by President George H.W. Bush to serve as the U.S. secretary of state. Deferred inspection is the process whereby the United States Customs and Border Protection service defers the inspection of a train, ship, or truck to a later time, often by attaching a tag to the vehicle indicating that inspection will be required at a port of entry at a later time. This is useful for the CBP because it allows them to prioritize inspections, and it is also beneficial for carriers because it saves time. However, this process may also be exploited by drug smugglers, who may use the tags to transport illegal goods without inspection. In these cases, the CBP will typically either intercept the vehicle at the port of entry or the vehicle will arrive at its destination and the smugglers will disperse. Interdiction policies which target alternative ports of entry upon arrival, or secondary inspection stations at the port of entry, are meant to combat these tactics.

Whoa, Nelly! is the sixth studio album by American rapper Nelly, released on June 25, 2010 by Universal Motown and Derrty Records. It was originally titled "Brass Knuckles", but was changed to "Whoa, Nelly!" shortly before its release. Faced with low sales of his previous album, Brass Knuckles (2008), Nelly decided to experiment with a new sound grounded in hip hop and urban music on his next album. Work began in 2009, and Nelly enlisted producers such as J.U.S.T.I.C.E. League, Jim Jonsin, and Rico Love to work with him.

The album debuted at number four on the US Billboard 200 chart, selling 80,000 copies in its first week. Upon its release, Whoa, Nelly! received generally negative reviews from music critics, earning a 39 out of 100 rating on Metacritic. The album's sound and production were the main targets of criticism. As of November 2012, the album has sold 248,000 copies in the United States.

A sequel, titled M.O. (2012), was released six years later.

Alfonso Gmez-Reino Jr. (born July 12, 1999) is an American actor and singer. He is best known for his roles as Dexter Moreno in the Disney Channel series Bizaardvark, and as Oscar in the Netflix series Raising Dion.

Gmez was born in Miami, Florida, to Colombian parents Alfonso Gmez-Reino Sr. and Monica Gomez-Reino, and moved to Los Angeles as a child. He has one older sister, Amelia. He attended Oak Hills Elementary School in San Jose, California, and later attended online school in ninth grade.

Gmez made his television debut in a 2013 episode of Major Crimes. In 2016, he appeared in a recurring role as Diego on the TNT series The Last Ship. In the same year, he also appeared in the film Keanu, and played the role of Dylan on the Disney Channel series Stuck in the Middle.

In 2017, Gmez was cast in the starring role of Dexter in the Disney Channel series Bizaardvark. In 2019, he appeared in the film Next Gen, and was cast in the Netflix series Raising Dion, which was released in 2022.

Gmez's singing talents were first showcased on the second season of The Voice in 2016, where he sang "Sure Thing" by Miguel.

Frances Perkins (May 10, 1880  May 14, 1965) was an American political economist and workers' rights advocate who served as the fourth United States Secretary of Labor from 1933 to 1945, under President Franklin D. Roosevelt. She was the longest serving labor secretary in U.S. history and the first woman to serve in a presidential cabinet. Perkins developed a deep interest in the labor movement as a young woman after witnessing the horrific consequences of the 1911 Triangle Shirtwaist Factory fire in New York City, and soon joined the Industrial Workers of the World. She organized and led hundreds of workers in a strike against the sanitary belt manufacturer Groton Rubber Company where she worked as a factory supervisor. Perkins developed close relationships with many union organizers, including Rose Schneiderman, and became a skilled negotiator between management and labor. She also worked for the National Consumers League as executive secretary of the New York branch, and was appointed to the New York State Industrial Commission in 1918, investigating working conditions in factories around the state.

Perkins was appointed as U.S. Secretary of Labor by President Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1933, and was the principal architect of the New Deal's labor programs. She was the primary advocate for the Social Security Act, the Fair Labor Standards Act, and the Employment Act, all of which are still in force in 2021. As one of the most powerful members of the Roosevelt cabinet, she worked closely with President Roosevelt to craft his New Deal legislative agenda and was a strong advocate for the rights of workers, women, and the poor. Throughout the 1930s and 1940s, she served as an adviser to Roosevelt on economic and social policy. She resigned as labor secretary in 1945 and returned to academia.

Perkins was also a member of the National Consumers League, the American Association of Labor Legislation, the National Child Labor Committee, and the Women's Trade Union League. She received the Theodore Roosevelt Distinguished Service Medal in 1936 and the inaugural Benjamin Franklin Medal in Business and Public Policy in 1941. She was also awarded the highest civilian award in the United States, the Presidential Medal of Freedom, in 1946.

Busch Stadium is a baseball stadium located in St. Louis, Missouri, the home field of the St. Louis Cardinals of Major League Baseball. It has a capacity of 46,695 and has hosted the Major League Baseball All-Star Game, seven National League Championship Series and six World Series.

The stadium is located in downtown St. Louis, near the Gateway Arch, and was built from April 11, 2006, to April 4, 2009, on the site of the previous Busch Stadium, which opened in 1966 and closed in 2005. The first regular-season game at the new stadium was played on April 4, 2009, when the Cardinals hosted the Milwaukee Brewers.

The stadium is named for former Cardinals owner August Anheuser Busch, Jr., who had been in control of the team for more than 50 years, from 1953 to 1998. He was also a longtime president of the American Beverage Association and founder of the Anheuser-Busch Brewery. The brewery is located near the stadium, and its giant beer cans are a prominent feature of the stadium's exterior. The brewery is the largest brewer of beer in St. Louis and largest producer of alcoholic beverages in the state of Missouri.

Banjarmasin is the capital and largest city of South Kalimantan, on the island of Kalimantan, Indonesia. It is a major industrial center for the province, as well as a key regional center for economy, culture, and education. Located on the island's southeast coast, the city faces the Java Sea.

Banjarmasin is one of the oldest cities in Indonesia, with a history that dates back to the early Hindu kingdoms of Java and Sumatra. The city was founded in the early 17th century by the Dutch East India Company, who were attracted to the area's natural resources and strategic location. The city grew in importance during the Dutch colonial period, becoming a major center for the tobacco and rubber industries.

After Indonesia gained independence in the 1950s, Banjarmasin continued to grow and develop, becoming a major hub for the oil and gas industry. The city has a population of over 700,000 people, with a diverse mix of ethnic and cultural backgrounds, including Dayak, Javanese, Chinese, and Arabic.

Banjarmasin is known for its rich cultural heritage, including traditional dances, music, and crafts. The city is also home to a number of museums and historical sites, such as the Museum of South Kalimantan and the Islamic Center of Banjarmasin. The city is a popular tourist destination, with attractions including the floating markets, the city's many parks and gardens, and the nearby wetlands and forests.

Rio Ruidoso is a village in Lincoln County, New Mexico, United States. The population was 7,076 at the 2010 census. It is part of the Albuquerque Metropolitan Statistical Area.

Rio Ruidoso is located on the Rio Ruidoso, a river known for its sturdy breeding horses and whitewater rapids. The village is immediately adjacent to Alto, New Mexico, on U.S. Route 70, and about 5 mi (8 km) west of Ruidoso Downs, where the All American Futurity, the world's richest horse race, is run each year.

The village population has seen a great increase in population due to "affordable" retirement living. It is also a popular tourist destination, being in the mountains of southern New Mexico and having a mild mountain climate, with abundant sunshine and moderate rainfall. The village was recently featured in a pilot for the Travel Channel's "Best Places to Retire".

In poetry, a transcript is a poem that is created by copying words verbatim from another source. The source can be any text at all, but it is usually a nonliterary text such as a legal document, a technical manual, or a dictionary. 

The result is usually humorous, and if the source is well-chosen, it can make a point about language, and how meaning and understanding are created. It is a genre of found poetry.

Some poets who have used the transcriptive technique include Carl Sandburg, Ezra Pound, Marianne Moore, and Joel Oppenheimer. In Oppenheimer's case, transcripts of weather reports have inspired many of his poems. The tradition of transcriptive poetry can also be traced back to Taoist philosophy of the 6th century BCE, which believed that "proper speech" should be spontaneous and unpremeditated.
